title: Multi-Round Social Advertising: Ad Sequence Recommendation Via Influence Maximization

detail.title: Multi-Round Social Advertising: Ad Sequence Recommendation Via Influence Maximization
detail.abstract: The continuous evolution of social networking platform is reshaping people's lives. Compared to traditional advertising, social advertisements leverage the ``word-of-mouth effect'', swiftly spreading and exerting significant influence on social networks. Existing social advertising recommendation algorithms typically focus on individual user ad acceptance, neglecting the interconnections among ads. In reality, a user's response to an ad is often influenced by prior ad exposures, and associations of the content between products. In this paper, based on triggering model, we introduce the multi-round Social Advertising Sequence Influence Maximization (SASIM) problem from the perspective of recommendation platforms. The SASIM problem integrates influence spread within user networks and the promotional impact of ad connections. Depending on the user feedback from the previous round, we design two algorithms: the non-adaptive greedy algorithm and the adaptive greedy algorithm, which incorporate edge-based greedy strategies. These algorithms aim to select suitable ads and arrange them in an optimal sequence for specific users, for maximizing the revenue of the ad acceptance and influence spread. The experiments are conducted on various real-world datasets. The experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithms for the multi-round SASIM problem.

title: Autoregressive Market Basket Transformer
affiliations: University of Regensburg - Faculty of Business, Economics & Information Systems

detail.title: Autoregressive Market Basket Transformer
detail.abstract: We introduce the autoregressive transformer for the analysis of retail market baskets. We compare this transformer to benchmark models that also take dynamic effects into account, the multivariate logit model with category loyalties as additional predictors and three main variants of recurrent neural nets. We evaluate models by binary cross-entropies for a holdout sample. Among benchmark models the long-short term neural net attains the best cross-entropy value. However, this recurrent net is outperformed by the transformer with six embedding dimensions, two attention heads and four transformer blocks. Adding own effects of category-specific advertising to the transformer leads to a further improvement. We follow different approaches to interpret this transformer. We determine dynamic dependences between pairs of product categories based on proportional sampling using both original and increased estimated purchase probabilities. For our data the number of complementary dependences is much higher than the number of substitutive dependences. We show that these dependences differ from similarities computed from the static embeddings also estimated by the transformer. We illustrate the dynamics reproduced by the transformer by weekly purchase probabilities for selected product categories and household types. We derive marginal effects of category-specific advertising. These effects are at least moderate in ten of 31 product categories. As a rule, marginal effects in these ten categories differ between selected weeks.

detail.title: Foundations for Digital Twins
detail.abstract: The growing reliance on digital twins across industry brings with it interoperability challenges. Ontologies are a well-known strategy for addressing such challenges, though given the complexity of digital twins there are risks of ontologies reintroducing interoperability issues. To avoid such pitfalls, we defend characterizations of digital twins within the context of the Common Core Ontologies. We provide definitions and a design pattern relevant to the domain, and in doing so a foundation on which to build more sophisticated ontological content related and connected to digital twins.

title: The Pragmatics of Hybridity: A Grounded Theory of Method Integration in Software Engineering Projects
affiliations: University of East London

detail.title: The Pragmatics of Hybridity: A Grounded Theory of Method Integration in Software Engineering Projects
detail.abstract: While hybrid project management methodologies are increasingly adopted in software development, empirical research on their real-world integration remains fragmented and undertheorized. This study bridges the critical gap by examining how organisations systematically integrate traditional and agile frameworks in practice. Leveraging a constructivist grounded theory approach, we analyse a multinational IT consultancy’s hybrid software project through in-depth interviews, participant observations, and archival data. Our findings reveal contingent hybridity, a dynamic, context-driven process in which hybridity emerges not as a predetermined model but as an ongoing negotiation between governance and agility. Four key dimensions underpin this phenomenon: (1) structural anchoring, where PRINCE2 establishes governance scaffolding; (2) adaptive enactment, where Scrum and agile methods flexibly operate within structured constraints; (3) boundary work, involving translator roles and hybrid ceremonies to reconcile methodological divides; and (4) role hybridisation, where practitioners fluidly alternate between control-oriented and delivery-focused responsibilities. Challenging prescriptive hybrid frameworks, this study demonstrates that successful integration hinges on situational adaptation rather than standardised templates. Theoretically, we propose a process-oriented model of hybridisation, moving beyond static typologies to capture its emergent and contested nature. Practically, we offer actionable insights for organisations navigating the agility-control paradox. Ultimately, this research redefines hybrid project management as a negotiated practice, continuously shaped by context, power dynamics, and practitioner sensemaking, rather than a codified methodology.

title: When to Go Live? Optimal Channel Strategies Under Dual Effort Modes and Consumer Heterogeneity
affiliations: Southwest Jiaotong University, Southwest Jiaotong University and Southwest Jiaotong University

detail.title: When to Go Live? Optimal Channel Strategies Under Dual Effort Modes and Consumer Heterogeneity
detail.abstract: Live-stream commerce has transitioned from a supplementary tool to a core retail channel, making the manufacturer's adoption decisions critically important to avoid profit erosion and channel conflicts. This study develops a Stackelberg game model analyzing three channel structures (traditional channel O, live-stream channel S, and dual-channel OS) to investigate the joint effects of consumer motivation heterogeneity (hedonic vs. utilitarian) and streamer effort modes (promotion vs. development) on the manufacturer's optimal channel strategy formulation. Our analysis yields several findings. We demonstrate that marginal revenue in the live-stream channel can exceed that of the traditional channel, revealing structured price discrimination across consumer motivation types. The streamer exhibits nuanced effort strategies: prioritizing promotion effort at extreme consumer motivation ratios but shifting to development effort at a moderate ratio. Regarding channel strategies, we identify that promotion effort generates greater manufacturer benefits within a given channel, while the dual-channel structure proves superior under equivalent effort modes. Under equilibrium, each channel strategy can become optimal for the manufacturer under specific conditions, while the streamer's profit may be compromised under the manufacturer's preferred channel S or OS configurations. Although channel S introduces profit erosion through streamer participation, the manufacturer can strategically leverage it to incentivize promotion effort for profit maximization. However, the extended model reveals that channel S ceases to be manufacturer-optimal when the streamer endogenously balances promotion and development efforts, as the manufacturer loses the ability to unilaterally influence effort allocation.

title: Antecedents of Continued Usage of Mobile Wallets Payments Services in Tanzania: Buyers Perspectives from Major Public Markets in Daresaalam

detail.title: Antecedents of Continued Usage of Mobile Wallets Payments Services in Tanzania: Buyers Perspectives from Major Public Markets in Daresaalam
detail.abstract: This study examined the factors influencing the continued usage of mobile wallets in payment services in Tanzania. The research was grounded in the augmented Unified Theory of Acceptance and Use of Technology (UTAUT), which served as the theoretical framework. The model extended the original UTAUT by incorporating three additional constructs: perceived risk, perceived cost, and perceived value, as determinants of continued mobile wallet usage. Data were collected through a structured questionnaire, yielding 371 valid and reliable responses for analysis. Structural Equation Modeling (SEM) was employed to analyze the data. The findings revealed that perceived value, effort expectancy, and performance expectancy have a positive influence on the continued use of mobile wallet payment services in Dar es Salaam. Conversely, facilitating conditions, perceived cost, and perceived risk were found to have no significant impact on continued usage in the city's major public markets. The study offers several important implications for researchers, service providers, and policymakers, aimed at promoting sustainable and continued use of mobile payment services among users.

title: Exploring the Ecommerce Consumers Perceptions and Regulatory Laws: A Case Study of Feni
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: Exploring the Ecommerce Consumers Perceptions and Regulatory Laws: A Case Study of Feni
detail.abstract: The Bangladeshi ecommerce sector has witnessed considerable growth, fueled by more than 125 million internet users and an economy valued at upwards of 3 billion dollars, however there has been some delay in development of regulatory systems to address aspects of consumer protection, transaction assurance and legal liability. In Bangladesh there exist some regulations such as the Consumer Rights Protection Act (2009) and Digital Commerce Operation Guidelines (2021), however the implementation of these regulations are weak and overall literacy rates are very low. The existence of scams, product misrepresentation and problems with delays particularly in rural/semi-urban areas such as Feni are reflective of pockets of systemic loopholes in the ecommerce system as it stands. This study is based on consumer attitude towards online shopping and evaluates the adequacy of e-commerce policies based on qualitative examination of legal instruments and survey results from 30 participants. The results indicate that 56.67% prefer online shopping because it is more convenient to shop, but the main anxiety is fraud (63.3%) along with lack of knowledge of consumer legal protection (33.33%). The survey also highlighted; insufficient regulatory coordination, ineffective redressal mechanisms, and lack of consumer knowledge as major problems. Nevertheless, for a safe and sustainable e-commerce environment, the study proposes legal reforms, effective enforcement, and targeted consumer knowledge campaigns. The results will have positive implications for policymakers and businesses to work on increasing trust and reliability in the digital economy in Bangladesh.

title: Fixation or Exploration? A Psychology-Enhanced Dual Decoder Approach to Attribute-Aware Session-Based Recommendations
affiliations: Shanghai University of Finance and Economics - School of Information Management and Engineering, Shanghai University of Finance and Economics - School of Information Management and Engineering and Shanghai University of Finance and Economics

detail.title: Fixation or Exploration? A Psychology-Enhanced Dual Decoder Approach to Attribute-Aware Session-Based Recommendations
detail.abstract: Session-based recommendations (SBRs) play a pivotal role in reducing users’ information overload and fostering sales and revenue on e-commerce platforms. Understanding users' decision-making processes and preferences is crucial for the development of effective SBRs. Drawing insights from consumer behavior and psychology literature, we examine two key psychological states---fixed and exploratory states---that shape users’ behavior in evaluating product attributes. Specifically, the fixed state reflects an internal tendency to maintain consistency with past choices, while the exploratory state captures users’ inclination to seek various and novel options. Methodologically, we propose a novel Attribute-aware Session-based Recommendation method that innovatively distinguishes between the Fixed and Exploratory states, called ASR-FE. Our method features three novel components: (1) a time-weighted sequence variance mechanism that identifies users’ fixed and exploratory states for each attribute sequence, and two heterogeneous decoders---(2) a fixed state decoder and (3) an exploratory state decoder---to predict users’ attribute preferences based on the corresponding psychological states. Extensive experiments on two real-world datasets demonstrate that incorporating the fixed and exploratory states not only enhances recommendation accuracy but also improves the interpretability of our model, yielding crucial implications for e-commerce platforms.

detail.title: Exploring the Integration of Large Language Models in Industrial Test Maintenance Processes
detail.abstract: Much of the cost and effort required during the software testing process is invested in performing test maintenance---the addition, removal, or modification of test cases to keep the test suite in sync with the system-under-test or to otherwise improve its quality. Tool support could reduce the cost---and improve the quality---of test maintenance by automating aspects of the process or by providing guidance and support to developers. In this study, we explore the capabilities and applications of large language models (LLMs)---complex machine learning models adapted to textual analysis---to support test maintenance. We conducted a case study at Ericsson AB where we explore the triggers that indicate the need for test maintenance, the actions that LLMs can take, and the considerations that must be made when deploying LLMs in an industrial setting. We also propose and demonstrate a multi-agent architecture that can predict which tests require maintenance following a change to the source code. Collectively, these contributions advance our theoretical and practical understanding of how LLMs can be deployed to benefit industrial test maintenance processes.

title: The Algorithmic Divide: How Generative AI Rewrites the Rules of Pay
affiliations: Cheung Kong Graduate School of Business

detail.title: The Algorithmic Divide: How Generative AI Rewrites the Rules of Pay
detail.abstract: This paper develops a comprehensive theoretical framework to understand how Generative AI transforms organizational compensation structures. Unlike previous automation technologies that primarily aected employment levels, Gen-AI fundamentally alters optimal incentive provision across hierarchical levels. We show that Gen-AI creates asymmetric eects: enhancing managerial productivity through improved coordination while automating routine worker tasks. This necessitates divergent compensation strategiesincreasing performance sensitivity for managers while decreasing it for workers. The multi-dimensional nature of AI capabilities requires sophisticated contracts rewarding not just output but also learning contributions and knowledge creation. Dynamic learning eects create persistent and potentially accelerating compensation gaps, driven by dierential learning rates and capability-performance complementarities.

title: Is Our Chatbot Telling Lies? Assessing Correctness of an Llm-Based Dutch Support Chatbot

detail.title: Is Our Chatbot Telling Lies? Assessing Correctness of an Llm-Based Dutch Support Chatbot
detail.abstract: Companies support their customers using live chats and chatbots to gain their loyalty. AFAS is a Dutch company aiming to leverage the opportunity large language models (LLMs) offer to answer customer queries with minimal to no input from its customer support team. Adding to its complexity, it is unclear what makes a response correct, and that too in Dutch. Further, with minimal data available for training, the challenge is to identify whether an answer generated by a large language model is correct and do it on the fly. This study is the first to define the correctness of a response based on how the support team at AFAS makes decisions. It leverages literature on natural language generation and automated answer grading systems to automate the decision-making of the customer support team. We investigated questions requiring a binary response (e.g., Would it be possible to adjust tax rates manually?) or instructions (e.g., How would I adjust tax rate manually?) to test how close our automated approach reaches support rating. Our approach can identify wrong messages in 55% of the cases. This work shows the viability of automatically assessing when our chatbot tell lies.

title: Artificial Intelligence and the Development of Business Models in the Gaming Industry – Case Study

detail.title: Artificial Intelligence and the Development of Business Models in the Gaming Industry – Case Study
detail.abstract: SummaryPurposeThis article examines the impact of artificial intelligence (AI) on the evolution of business models in the video game industry. Its primary goal is to address the research gap regarding comprehensive analyses of how AI integration generates new business models, modifies existing ones, and impacts companies and players.Design/methodology/approachThe study combines a systematic literature review (SLR) of 56 Scopus publications on business models and AI applications, with qualitative empirical research using comparative case studies of Ubisoft (proactive generative AI adoption) and CD Projekt (cautious approach). Analysis criteria included strategic goals, creative control, and legal/ethical challenges.FindingsThe study demonstrates that AI creates opportunities for innovation, ranging from enhancing the behavior of non-player characters (NPCs) to generating content and personalizing gameplay. Ubisoft utilizes generative AI (Ghostwriter, NEO NPC) for NPC dialogue automation and dynamic interactions while preserving creator control, optimizing production, and enhancing immersion. CD Projekt avoids generative AI in core projects (e.g., The Witcher 4) due to legal/content quality risks, limiting AI to supportive roles (testing, voice replication of deceased actors). AI transforms business models through: production cost reduction, player experience personalization (20-30% retention increase), and novel monetization paths (NFT economies).OriginalityThis study aims to integrate SLR with an empirical comparison of polarized AI strategies in gaming. It reveals that the impact of AI's business model depends on the technological approach and risk tolerance, identifying concrete AI tools (e.g., dynamic pricing) that can revolutionize freemium models. By dissecting real-world cases (e.g., Ubisoft's "guardrails" for ethical AI and CD Projekt's copyright concerns), it highlights actionable pathways and barriers for studios navigating AI adoption, balancing innovation with creative control, ethics, and legal risks. This dual theoretical-empirical lens, combined with its focus on business model evolution rather than pure technology, positions the article as a pioneering framework for future research and industry strategy.

title: Webrecon: Adaptive Web Vulnerability Scanner with Ctf Integration

detail.title: Webrecon: Adaptive Web Vulnerability Scanner with Ctf Integration
detail.abstract: As times and challenges change, there is currently a greater need for secure, flexible and efficient exploitation tools. The traditional penetration testing frameworks are seen to be employing old detection methods and are almost monolithic in their construction, resulting in no provision for the verification of an exploit at run time. All these have rendered these systems less useful in today's cybersecurity workflow, as well as in the teaching curriculum. A next-generation, modular, and web application vulnerability detecting and exploitation framework was introduced to address the above-described limitations. Being a fully pluggable architecture, WebRecon is eminently customizable to any purpose—the payload, the scanning engine, and the exploitation script. On detection of any vulnerability, under real-time circumstances, the payload is launched immediately, testing with a high degree of precision and efficiency, based on context. The system detects and penetrates critical vulnerabilities arising from XSS, SQL Injection, Command Execution, and Directory Traversal. Being fast, it works wonderfully embedded within a CI/CD pipeline for testing, or also just for fast assessments, courtesy parallelized scanning and lightweight threading. To curb potential misuse of the system by someone with criminal ends, the framework has been containerized by Docker. This gives the ability to constrain and govern the execution environment and protects a possibility for either misconfiguration or irresponsible use, while keeping WebRecon sufficiently flexible for the ethical use case. It also features an optional CTF Automation.

title: AI Jurors vs. Human Judgments: Assessing Auditor Responsibility in an Era of AI-Assisted Audits

detail.title: AI Jurors vs. Human Judgments: Assessing Auditor Responsibility in an Era of AI-Assisted Audits

declarations.funderStatement: This research was supported by JSPS KAKENHI Grant Number 22K18541 and 24K00310.

detail.abstract: This study investigates how Large Language Models (LLMs) make subjective judgments by comparing their evaluations with human assessments in audit failure scenarios. As AI integration in accounting and auditing accelerates, understanding LLM judgment, particularly in ethical dilemmas, is crucial. Using a juror decisionmaking task, I compared human responsibility judgments regarding audit failures with those from LLMs imbued with human "personas." The findings of the preregistered study reveal that LLMs assign less auditor responsibility and react more strongly to contextual cues, such as client AI-driven fraud, compared to humans, whose judgments appear more subtly influenced by psychological factors and social norms. Notably, both humans and LLMs identified the auditor's choice to use AI as a key basis for responsibility. This research contributes to AI "persona" studies, behavioral accounting by highlighting AI-human judgment divergence, and offers practical insights for AI policy and implementation in auditing.

detail.abstract: Automated prediction of trending news faces persistent challenges, including the inadequacy of static knowledge bases to reflect the dynamic nature of event contexts, the obfuscation of feature contributions due to simplistic multimodal fusion, and biases in predictions arising from class imbalance. This study introduces the DREAM framework, an innovative framework that incorporates dynamic knowledge graph for the real-time extraction of contextual entity-relation information, employs gated attention mechanisms to assign varying weights to diverse textual and structural features, and utilises cost-sensitive optimisation to address data imbalance issues. Comprehensive experimental results indicate that the DREAM outperforms existing state-of-the-art models in terms of accuracy, while thorough ablation studies affirm the necessity of its architectural components. The framework enhances interpretability through attention-based analysis of modality preferences and Shapley-based quantification of entity impacts, thereby uncovering decision-making patterns specific to various domains. Notably, the DREAM demonstrates consistent performance in tail domains characterised by extreme data scarcity, thereby establishing a novel paradigm for transparent and adaptive news analytics. This research effectively integrates neural representation learning with structured knowledge reasoning, providing valuable insights for practical editorial applications.

detail.abstract: The lack of digitalization in data exchange between companies and inspection solution providers negatively affects monetary transactions between stakeholders. Blockchain and Smart Contract technologies, as well as microservices installed on the equipment, will allow for the automatic exchange of information between participants in the inspection service license.New business models focused on usage, volume, or period-based licenses can change the offerings provided by non-destructive inspection solutions companies. By focusing their equipment offerings on licensed services, the initial investment in the purchase of the solution can be reduced, shortening the return on investment compared to a perpetual license. detail.title: On-Device Large Language Model-Powered Construction Intelligent Copilot for On-Site Tutorials
detail.abstract: Real-time technical tutorials are essential for low-skilled construction workers, but persistent challenges including inefficient communication and disorganized documents hinder knowledge transmission. Large language models (LLMs) demonstrate potential in addressing this issue, but existing chatbots like ChatGPT rely on cloud services, limiting their on-site application. This paper combines lightweight LLMs with edge computing to propose an offline AI copilot framework for construction tutorials. It is divided into a web UI and a backend with four layers: interaction, agent, engine, and OS layer. A three-stage workflow is designed to guide lightweight LLMs in tool use and multiple optimization strategies are employed to improve system efficiency. The copilot was deployed on a smartphone and a simulation experiment was conducted to verify its performance. The results demonstrate the copilot provides accurate responses to queries about different tasks with acceptable interaction latency. It improves on-site management and advances the application of LLMs in civil engineering.

title: How Have Smartphones Changed the Structure of Online Content Consumption?
affiliations: Indiana University - Kelley School of Business, Kelley School of Business, Indiana University and National Bureau of Economic Research (NBER), Harvard University - Technology & Operations Management Unit

detail.title: How Have Smartphones Changed the Structure of Online Content Consumption?
detail.abstract: Smartphones have become the primary medium for consuming online content globally. Despite this significant change in how content is consumed, little is known about whether and how the introduction of mobile devices as a means of online content consumption, in addition to home computers, has impacted the way content is consumed. In this paper, we empirically analyze the distribution of session lengths and the variety of online consumption for both mobile devices and home computers. The analyses utilize data on home computer consumption in 2008 and 2019, as well as data on mobile consumption from 2019. We find little change in the variety of consumption on home computers between 2008 and 2019. It also shows that mobile platforms are associated with shorter, more frequent sessions and more concentrated consumption patterns compared to home devices. As users spend more time online via mobile devices, they tend to focus on a limited set of high-utility apps or websites, resulting in reduced variety compared to home computer usage. Taken together, the results suggest that the introduction of smartphones had little effect on the allocation patterns of home computer consumption, while encouraging a more concentrated pattern of use on mobile devices.

title: The More Aesthetic, the Better? The Impact of Photo Aesthetics on Perceived Review Helpfulness
affiliations: Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin Institute of Technology, Tilburg University and Harbin Institute of Technology

detail.title: The More Aesthetic, the Better? The Impact of Photo Aesthetics on Perceived Review Helpfulness
detail.abstract: Review helpfulness is crucial for assessing the quality of online reviews and mitigating information overload. Although numerous studies have explored the impact of textual and reviewer characteristics on review helpfulness, the role of photo aesthetics remains important but underexplored. This study addresses this gap by investigating the impact of photo aesthetics on perceived review helpfulness and its underlying mediating effects. The hotel review data from TripAdvisor.com exhibit an inverted U-shaped effect of photo aesthetics on perceived review helpfulness, in which review text length moderates this relationship. To further validate this causal relationship and explore the underlying mediating effects, an experimental study is conducted. The experimental results confirm the causal impact of photo aesthetics on perceived review helpfulness and reveal that perceived pleasure, reviewer effort and review authenticity mediate the relationship. These novel insights challenge the notion that "the more aesthetic, the better" for review photos, offering new theoretical and practical implications.

title: A Learning-Guided Multi-Objective Approach for Energy-Oriented Hybrid Flow Shop Scheduling with Limited Buffers
affiliations: Chongqing College of Electronic Engineering, Chongqing University, Northeastern University and University of Newcastle

detail.title: A Learning-Guided Multi-Objective Approach for Energy-Oriented Hybrid Flow Shop Scheduling with Limited Buffers
detail.abstract: To support the goal of sustainable manufacturing, energy-efficient production scheduling problems have been studied extensively over the past decade. The energy-oriented hybrid flow shop scheduling problem with limited buffers (EO-HFSP-LB) is commonly observed in real-world manufacturing environments, especially in energy-intensive sectors such as steel, cement, and aluminum manufacturing. In this paper, we investigate an EO-HFSP-LB that simultaneously minizines total weighted tardiness (TWT) and non-processing energy (NPE), two conflicting and non-regular objectives. To address this problem, we propose a learning-guided multi-objective evolutionary algorithm (LgMOEA) that can efficiently search for Pareto-optimal solutions by leveraging problem-specific knowledge. The main components of LgMOEA include: (1) a forward-backward scheduling procedure for solution decoding; (2) objective-guided genetic and neighborhood operators to effectively explore and exploit the solution space; and (3) a learning-guided operator selection module that dynamically balances exploration and exploitation. The proposed algorithm is evaluated on 25 well-synthesized benchmark instances. Computational results show that (1) the LgMOEA outperforms state-of-the-art multi-objective algorithms in terms of hypervolume, spacing, and success rate; and (2) the learning module provides a more effective balance than random operator selection. The source code of LgMOEA is made available at: https://github.com/janason/Soft-Scheduling/tree/master/LgMOEA.

title: Counter-Narrative Themes
affiliations: Northwestern University and Northwestern University

detail.title: Counter-Narrative Themes
detail.abstract: This essay responds to calls for greater use of counter-narratives in bioethics to address racial injustice and broaden representation. The authors argue that hesitancy among bioethicists to promote unfamiliar narratives—due to fears of reinforcing stereotypes or being insensitive—can be mitigated through engagement with narrative identity theory. Drawing on psychological research, they outline narrative themes such as contamination, redemption, agency, and communion as interpretive tools for sensitively understanding experiences of injustice. The paper proposes that recognizing shared thematic structures between personal and marginalized experiences can promote more empathetic and responsible discourse in bioethics.

title: Managerial Insight and "Optimal" Algorithms
affiliations: Darla Moore School of Business, University of South Carolina

detail.title: Managerial Insight and "Optimal" Algorithms
detail.abstract: Work is increasingly being completed by humans and algorithms, in collaboration. A relative strength of humans in this partnership is their insight: private information that is relevant to the task but not available to computerized systems. I introduce a flexible model of managerial insight that accepts any distribution of demand, an advantage over alternative models, and apply it to the newsvendor setting. The optimal policy in this setting is theoretically straightforward but difficult for managers to implement directly. I propose a novel method called FIND that leverages historical forecasts to convert a point estimate of demand into a conditional probability distribution. In eight experiments, FIND outperforms all other ordering regimes considered over a broad range of conditions. To model subtle, unstructured demand signals, the last four experiments convey managerial insight non-quantitatively using images, colors, and tones. FIND performs equally well with these perceptual signals as it does with more traditional numerical signals.

title: Director Primacy to the Hilt in the Public Benefit Corporation
affiliations: Santa Clara University - School of Law

detail.title: Director Primacy to the Hilt in the Public Benefit Corporation
detail.abstract: This essay identifies an overlooked feature of the public benefit corporation (PBC) as compared to ordinary corporate design: its radical amplification of director authority. Contrary to prevailing assumptions that PBCs dilute corporate power in favor of broader stakeholder governance, PBC statutes actually entrench and extend director primacy beyond its expression in traditional corporate law. Directors of PBCs are granted wide discretion to define and pursue plural corporate purposes while facing minimal accountability from shareholders or other stakeholders. The essay explores the theoretical and practical implications of this regime, including its potential to intensify, rather than restrain, the exercise of corporate power, and offers a new explanation for why profit-maximizing actors might be drawn to investment in the PBC form.

title: Distributionally Robust Optimization is a Multi-Objective Problem
affiliations: Chuo University - Department of Data Science for Business Innovation, Sauder School of Business, University of British Columbia and National University of Singapore (NUS) - Department of Decision Sciences

detail.title: Distributionally Robust Optimization is a Multi-Objective Problem
detail.abstract: Distributionally Robust Optimization (DRO) is a worst-case approach to decision making when there is model uncertainty. Though formulated as a single-objective problem, we show that it is intrinsically multi-objective in that DRO solutions map out a near-Pareto-optimal frontier between expected cost and a measure of robustness called worst-case sensitivity (WCS). We take this as the starting point and explore robust decision making through a multi-objective lens. We show that WCS is a measure of spread and derive WCS for a collection of uncertainty sets commonly used in DRO. These sensitivity measures identify the errors against which the nominal expected cost is most vulnerable and the uncertainty set for the worst-case problem that most effectively mitigates it. The associated mean-sensitivity frontier is used to select its size. The multi-objective perspective provides a quantitative measure of robustness and a sensitivity-based approach to addressing important conceptual gaps in DRO-how to choose the family and size of uncertainty sets for a given cost distribution, and how this affects the solution.

title: Liquidity Optimization in Gross Settlement Systems with Quantum Reordering: Application to Target2
affiliations: Government of Canada - Bank of Canada, Government of Canada - Bank of Canada, Bank of Italy, Bank of Italy, Bank of Italy, Bank of Italy and Bank of Italy

detail.title: Liquidity Optimization in Gross Settlement Systems with Quantum Reordering: Application to Target2
detail.abstract: We build upon the research of McMahon et al. (2024), which demonstrated the effectiveness of reordering payments using a hybrid quantum solver in improving the liquidity efficiency of Canada’s high-value payments system (HVPS). In this work, we apply the technique to the Italian segment of TARGET2, the Eurosystem’s HVPS, using the Constrained Quadratic Model (CQM) solver provided by D-Wave. This application achieves improvements in optimizing payment batches of size 70 and 140, showing daily average liquidity savings of respectively EUR 23 million and EUR 38 million over a 35 days sample. We benchmark the CQM solver results against those obtained using a simulated annealing algorithm (SAA) under the same time constraints, finding comparable liquidity savings for batch sizes of 70 and 140 payments. Subsequently, the SAA is extended to handle batch sizes of up to 700 payments, a scale that is challenging for current quantum hardware, demonstrating a more than tenfold increase in liquidity savings. Lastly, we introduce a machine learning framework to identify batch features that enhance liquidity savings with the CQM reordering algorithm. We find that batch optimizability increases with the number of participants acting as both senders and receivers, as well as the number of unique receivers within the batch.

title: Institutional Dynamics of Purchasing and Supply Management Development: A Process Study of Stakeholder Influence
affiliations: Copenhagen Business School - Department of Operations Management, MOL Group and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Institutional Dynamics of Purchasing and Supply Management Development: A Process Study of Stakeholder Influence
detail.abstract: Functional development in purchasing and supply management (PSM) has proven challenging for many organisations despite the strategic advantages it can provide. In this paper, we study how organisational stakeholders both enable and constrain the development of the PSM function through evolving patterns of institutional work. We integrate institutional theory with a processual perspective to examine how stakeholders navigate competing institutional logics and shape PSM's legitimacy over time through an in-depth longitudinal case study in the pharmaceutical industry. Our analysis reveals three distinct developmental phases, each characterised by different configurations of institutional logics, forms of institutional work (defensive and enabling), and legitimacy dynamics. This study contributes to the literature exploring functional development within PSM in two important ways. First, we demonstrate that successful PSM development requires not the replacement of existing institutional logics but their hybridisation, achieved through institutional work that evolves from coercive to collaborative approaches over time. Second, we show how selective institutionalisation—achieving embedded influence in specific domains whilst accepting exclusion from others—may represent optimal accommodation in pluralistic organisational contexts. Our processual analysis reveals PSM development as an ongoing institutional accomplishment requiring continuous negotiation rather than linear progression toward a predetermined end state.

title: Motivation Without Supervision Experimental Evidence from Rural Public Servants in Ethiopia
affiliations: International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI), University of Bordeaux and International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI)

detail.title: Motivation Without Supervision Experimental Evidence from Rural Public Servants in Ethiopia
detail.abstract: In low-supervision settings, can increased work performance of frontline agents increase their work motivation? We study this question in a lab-in-the-field experiment with 237 Ethiopian extension agents (DAs), exogenously enhancing task competence and varying payment schemes. While average effects are null, among medium-ability agents, competence boosts performance comparably to piece-rate incentives. Combining both yields diminishing returns. We relate this finding to results from a national RCT where DAs’ increased their efforts in tasks that are not subject to managerial oversights and related rewards. Our findings underscore the promise—and limits—of leveraging intrinsic motivation to improve service delivery in resource-constrained contexts.

title: Generative Artificial Intelligence Adoption in Higher Education: Findings from a Longitudinal Cross-Lagged Study
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Generative Artificial Intelligence Adoption in Higher Education: Findings from a Longitudinal Cross-Lagged Study
detail.abstract: This study investigates how the factors influencing higher education employees’ motivation to adopt generative artificial intelligence (GenAI) evolve over time. Specifically, it examines the temporal dynamics of trust, behavioral intention, and actual use behavior through a cross-lagged panel design. The research was conducted in the context of a pilot program at a University of Applied Sciences (UAS), where 42 teachers and researchers were given the opportunity to experiment with Microsoft Copilot over a three-month period. The study tested a model grounded in technology adoption theory, focusing on both enabling and inhibiting perceptions, and the professional environment as antecedents to GenAI use behavior. While the cross-sectional analysis yielded mixed results regarding the relationship between antecedents, trust and behavioral intention, all autoregressive paths for the key antecedents were statistically significant. However, contrary to expectations, the cross-lagged paths between constructs were not statistically significant. These findings suggest that the proposed directional influences between antecedents do not transfer to trust, behavioral intention and use behavior over time. The results highlight the complexity of GenAI adoption in higher education and call for further longitudinal research to better understand the conditions under which key factors translate into sustained use.

title: Facing Faculty Fears About AI
affiliations: University of Missouri School of Law

detail.title: Facing Faculty Fears About AI

publicationDetails.detailsText: University of Missouri School of Law Legal Studies Research Paper No. 2025-34
publicationDetails.journalName: University of Missouri School of Law Legal Studies Research Paper Series

detail.abstract:
This essay addresses a widespread but rarely voiced concern among faculty:  the fear of appearing uninformed, unprepared, or even outmatched by students when incorporating AI into their teaching.  While worries about cheating, hallucinations, de-skilling, and loss of control are legitimate, this essay encourages faculty to shift from fear to curiosity.  It argues that acknowledging uncertainty can strengthen faculty–student relationships and model the curiosity and humility we hope to cultivate in students.

It outlines two general strategies for faculty: restricting AI use when students need to build foundational skills, and requiring it when students are ready to develop professional judgment using AI tools.  Both are appropriate in different courses and contexts.  The essay emphasizes that both approaches require some AI literacy, and offers suggestions for how faculty can build confidence with AI and adapt existing assignments.

The essay offers concrete strategies, sample language for AI policies in a wide range of courses, and practical examples of how faculty can design assignments that foster learning while using AI responsibly.  It outlines approaches faculty might take depending on course goals – from restricting AI in first-year writing and doctrinal classes to encouraging thoughtful experimentation in upper-level skills, clinical, and seminar courses.

It reminds readers that we are still early in the AI innovation and collective learning curve, and that what now feels intimidating may soon feel familiar – just as Zoom now does.  Ultimately, the piece reframes AI not as a threat to faculty authority, but as a new opportunity to connect, experiment, and grow with students.

title: Sinai's Legacy: How the Torah Reshaped Human Society
affiliations: City University of New York (CUNY) - Koppelman School of Business and Independent

detail.title: Sinai's Legacy: How the Torah Reshaped Human Society
detail.abstract: The Torah stands as a transformative text that has significantly shaped human history and business practices. Written over three millennia ago, it established foundational ethical principles that remain relevant today. The document advanced revolutionary concepts including compassion for society's most vulnerable members, welcoming strangers, accountability in organizational leadership, purpose-driven governance, protection of animals, environmental conservation, commitment to social justice, humility in leadership, healing-centered solutions, the power of restorative practices, rejecting superstition, cultivating a direct relationship with God, and fundamental respect for human worth. These forward-thinking principles challenged existing social conventions and continue to influence the development of civilization and ethical business conduct.

title: A Long Tunnel Multi-Section Variable Speed Limit Control Based on Reinforcement Learning
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: A Long Tunnel Multi-Section Variable Speed Limit Control Based on Reinforcement Learning
detail.abstract: To enhance traffic safety and operational efficiency in long tunnels, we propose a long tunnel multi-section variable speed limit control system based on reinforcement learning. First, to effectively reflect driver behaviors in various sections of long tunnels (e.g., entrance/exit and middle sections), a multi-section intelligent driver model for long tunnels incorporating the effects of tunnel lighting is developed, which accounts for the influence of illuminance reduction coefficients at tunnel entrances/exits on driving behavior, as well as the impact of stroboscopic effects in the middle section on driver fatigue. Furthermore, a model analyzing the effects of variable speed limit control on drivers' desired speed and acceleration is designed based on the microscopic traffic flow model. Second, a reinforcement learning-based multi-section variable speed limit control method is presented for long tunnels, to effectively capture heterogeneous traffic conditions while preventing dimensional explosion induced by microscopic traffic data, a macroscopic traffic state sampling method is developed, additionally, reward metrics based on microscopic vehicle trajectory data is formulated, including speed dispersion and average travel time, which can reflect the  traffic safety and operational efficiency  Finally, a simulation system is developed based on actual traffic data and tunnel illuminance data collected from the Beiru Tunnel in Shanxi Province to validate the feasibility and effectiveness of the proposed method. Experimental results demonstrate that, under various traffic demand scenarios, the VSL control method significantly reduces the average inter-vehicle speed difference by 12.15%  and decreases the average travel time per vehicle by 6.61%  compared to fixed speed limit strategies.

title: Multinational Firms and Cross-Border Mergers: Theory and Evidence
affiliations: University of Southern California - Marshall School of Business

detail.title: Multinational Firms and Cross-Border Mergers: Theory and Evidence
detail.abstract: Multinational firms play a pivotal role in the global economy, yet economic and finance research has largely examined them in isolation. Economic theory focuses on trade and multinational activity but gives relatively little attention to cross-border mergers, while finance research emphasizes empirical studies of mergers but rarely integrates broader economic theories. This chapter aims to synthesize these two literatures into a unified framework for understanding multinational firms and cross-border mergers. The discussion is organized around the decision-making process of multinational firms, from choosing to operate internationally to selecting between greenfield investment and mergers. This framework reveals the theoretical and empirical evidence on the drivers of multinational production, including productivity gains, knowledge transfers, and market frictions. The findings highlight the commonality between the two literatures, but also suggests that greater integration between economic theory and finance research will generate a deeper understanding of the role of multinational firms in the global economy.

title: Probabilistic Forecasting Reveals a Silent Collapse of Archaeological Heritage in Peru's Chillón Valley
affiliations: Universidad Privada del Norte and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Probabilistic Forecasting Reveals a Silent Collapse of Archaeological Heritage in Peru's Chillón Valley
detail.abstract: Unregulated land-use change is accelerating the loss of archaeological heritage, yet quantitative forecasts of site disappearance remain rare. We present an open, Python-based pipeline that converts two decades (2000 – 2023) of satellite-derived loss trajectories for 56 pre-Hispanic sites in Peru’s peri-urban Chillón Valley into probabilistic collapse forecasts. After filtering for adequate temporal coverage, 33 sites were modelled with ordinary least-squares regressions whose parameter uncertainty was propagated through 10 000 Monte-Carlo draws. Under a business-as-usual assumption—recent degradation rates persist—median disappearance years and 95 % credible intervals place six sites as already lost, eight at high risk (< 15 years), and the remainder in mid- and late-century risk tiers. Kernel-density visualization of the full 2000 – 2025 loss record reveals three valley-wide degradation phases: initial stability (2000 – 2005), acceleration (2005 – 2015) and late-wave intensification (2015 – 2025). The framework shows how retrospective mapping and forward-looking uncertainty jointly prioritize intervention, while the peri-urban context cautions against uncritical generalization to dissimilar landscapes. All code and data are openly archived to foster replication and adaptation.

title: Pml-Based Quantification of Evapotranspiration Changes Induced by Vegetation Restoration in the Loess Plateau
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, North China University of Water Resources and Electric Power, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Clemson University and Xi’an University of Technology

detail.title: Pml-Based Quantification of Evapotranspiration Changes Induced by Vegetation Restoration in the Loess Plateau
detail.abstract: The Loess Plateau (LP), a typical semi-arid region in China, has experienced significant vegetation cover increase due to large-scale vegetation restoration since the 1990s, which may alter regional water balance by affecting evapotranspiration (ET). Assessing the impact of vegetation restoration on ET and its driving mechanisms is crucial for balancing ecological improvement and water resource management in the LP. This study employed the modified Penman-Monteith-Leuning (PML) model combined with a detrending method to estimate ET changes in six typical basins of the LP from 2000 to 2019. The PML model, after parameter calibration, showed good performance in ET simulation (NSE>0.8, R2>0.9) as validated by the PML_V2 dataset and water balance method. Results indicate that annual ET increased significantly in all six basins during the study period, with the Wuding River Basin showing the largest increase (3.50 mm/yr, p< 0.05). Summer ET accounted for more than 40% of the annual total, making it the primary contributor to annual ET variations. Leaf Area Index (LAI) exhibited the strongest correlation with ET, acting as the dominant driver of ET changes. The cumulative contribution of LAI linear growth induced by vegetation restoration to ET increases ranged from 357 to 493 mm across the basins. Spatially, the relatively humid Guanzhong Plain and southern basins (Beiluo and Fen River Basins) had the largest ET increases, while northern basins with limited precipitation (Kuye and Wuding River Basins) showed smaller increases, reflecting the regulatory role of water supply in ET dynamics. This study clarifies the impact of vegetation restoration on ET and hydrological processes in the LP, providing a scientific basis for optimizing vegetation restoration strategies and coordinating ecological protection with sustainable water resource management.

title: Rethinking the Penology of Imprisonment: The Case of Palestinian Security Prisoners in Israel
affiliations: The Academic Center for Law and Science and University of Illinois at Chicago

detail.title: Rethinking the Penology of Imprisonment: The Case of Palestinian Security Prisoners in Israel
detail.abstract: This article examines the considerations involved in the confinement conditions of Palestinian security violators in Israeli prisons. It challenges the suitability of prevailing penological frameworks to explain security prisoners and argues for a counterterrorism approach. The study reviews security prisoners' rights and privileges, and how the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and global anti-terrorism efforts shape and reshape prison conditions. It highlights contentious debates around "deserved" prison conditions, especially following the October 7 Hamas attack, and subsequent calls for harsher treatment. The article concludes that confinement policies have implications beyond prison walls and are closely intertwined with broader political and security considerations.

title: Measuring Carbon Intensity in Real-Time: MES-Driven Approaches for Decarbonized Manufacturing

detail.title: Measuring Carbon Intensity in Real-Time: MES-Driven Approaches for Decarbonized Manufacturing

detail.abstract: Manufacturers are under growing regulatory and stakeholder pressure to reduce their carbon emissions and report environmental performance in near real-time. Despite the adoption of advanced automation, most factories still rely on lagging, siloed carbon tracking systems that fail to provide actionable insights. This white paper introduces a vendor-neutral, modular framework that enables real-time carbon intensity (CI) monitoring within Manufacturing Execution Systems (MES). By embedding CI as a live KPI and linking MES data to ESG platforms via secure APIs, manufacturers can not only identify emissions anomalies but also trigger corrective action during operations. A simulation modeled on an FMCG packaging environment demonstrated a 22% CI reduction within one shift and automated ESG synchronization within 30 seconds. This framework offers a scalable, intelligent path toward decarbonization aligned with Industry 5.0.

title: Decision-oriented Leadership in Artificial Intelligence Milieu

detail.title: Decision-oriented Leadership in Artificial Intelligence Milieu
detail.abstract: This paper examines the decision making dynamics of a leader in a World now being flooded with forces of artificial intelligence. The paper envelops the traditional leadership models and steers towards neuro-leadership. The paper examines how neuro-biology has made a foray into neuro-management as far as decision making by leaders are concerned. An experiment on eye tracking ahs been conducted to observe the decision trends.

title: An Experiment on Behavior in Queues∗
affiliations: Washington University in St. Louis, Washington University in St. Louis, Washington University in St. Louis and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: An Experiment on Behavior in Queues∗
detail.abstract: In a dynamic allocation setup, we experimentally study agents’ choices under the First-In-First-Out (FIFO) and Last-In-First-Out (LIFO) queuing protocols. We find that agents are nearly rational under FIFO but tend to be overselective under LIFO. In the model that anchors our experiment, we show that the magnitude of such an excessively selective bias reduces the welfare performance gap between FIFO and LIFO. As strategic complementarities under LIFO can reinforce overly selective behavior, we show that such bias persists in a supplemental treatment where subjects interact with non-strategic robots.

title: Matching with Two Overlapping Types: A Mechanism Design Analysis of French College Admissions
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Matching with Two Overlapping Types: A Mechanism Design Analysis of French College Admissions
detail.abstract: This paper analyzes the centralized college admissions system in France, known as Parcoursup, which is based on an iterative version of the College-Proposing Deferred Acceptance (CDA) algorithm. In this mechanism, candidates (each of whom may have up to two traits for a given institution) are matched to two types of institutions: regular and boarding schools (i.e., institutions offering dormitory spots). We identify a key flaw in Parcoursup: institutional preferences are adjusted only once prior to the algorithm’s execution to incorporate affirmative action objectives. This static adjustment leads to violations of stability, even in simple matching environments.To address this, we propose a new mechanism, the Stage-Fair CDA (SF-CDA), which dynamically incorporates affirmative action using novel stable choice rules grounded in a social choice framework. Simulations based on Parcoursup 2022 data show that: (i) SF-CDA produces a stable outcome in 65% of instances and is always more stable than the current system, which is never stable; (ii) SF-CDA increases the number of reserved seats filled for each of two target traits (by 4.5% and 0.3%). Finally, we estimate that under the current system, approximately 8.6% of candidates (76,000) experience justified envy, whereas under SF-CDA this percentage would drop 40-fold to 0.2%.

The purposes of the article are to highlight the peculiarities of the English approach; discuss their significance for facilitating corporate restructuring in the UK; and finally assessing the likelihood of London remaining one of the leading restructuring centres in the world after Brexit.

title: Floating Charges and Moral Hazard: Finding Fairness for Involuntary and Vulnerable Stakeholders
affiliations: University of Derby - School of Law and Criminology

detail.title: Floating Charges and Moral Hazard: Finding Fairness for Involuntary and Vulnerable Stakeholders
detail.abstract: The floating charge as a concept undoubtedly affords a considerable amount of preference and control to the creditor who owns it and to the debtor which can continue to deal with the charged assets, and to potentially dissipate them in the normal course of business. Such power may overshadow any preferences and priorities available to vulnerable stakeholders, such as employees, and certainly over involuntary creditors such as tort victims, as there is no limitation on how such charged assets can be dealt with until and unless the collective format of insolvency and restructuring are put into place at a time of financial distress. The purpose of this Chapter is to explore the socio-legal aspects of the floating charge as it affects, specifically, employees, and asks the question as to whether it is possible to achieve fairness by a set priority position, or whether it could be open to abuse due to moral hazards created by the power inherent in the device however and wherever a line is drawn.

title: Digital Sovereigns: Big Tech’s and Nation-State Influence
affiliations: Norwich University (NU)

detail.title: Digital Sovereigns: Big Tech’s and Nation-State Influence
detail.abstract: Technology companies have gained unprecedented power and influence in recent years, resembling quasi-nation-states globally. Corporations with trillion-dollar market capitalizations are no longer just providers of digital services; they now wield immense economic power, influence global infrastructure, and significantly impact political and social dynamics. This thesis examines how these corporations have transcended traditional business models, adopting characteristics typically associated with sovereign states. They now enforce regulations, shape public discourse, and influence legal frameworks in various countries. This shift presents unique challenges, including the undermining of democratic governance, the exacerbation of economic inequalities, and the enabling of unregulated data exploitation and privacy violations. The study will examine critical instances of tech companies acting as quasi-governmental bodies and assess the risks associated with unchecked corporate influence in global governance. Ultimately, the thesis aims to propose policy frameworks and regulatory interventions to curb the overreach of tech giants, restoring the balance between democratic institutions and corporate power and ensuring that the digital future aligns with the public good rather than creating Frankenstein-like monsters.

title: Demographic Reconstruction and Electoral Roll Inflation: Estimating the Legitimate Voter Base in Bihar, India (2025)

detail.title: Demographic Reconstruction and Electoral Roll Inflation: Estimating the Legitimate Voter Base in Bihar, India (2025)
detail.abstract: This paper presents a demographic reconstruction of the legitimate voter base in the Indian state of Bihar for the year 2025. Motivated by concerns over the integrity of electoral rolls in high-migration regions, we develop a three-part accounting framework grounded in official data sources. We estimate the number of surviving voters from the 2003 post-intensive review electoral roll using age-cohort-specific mortality rates; we then add new eligible voters born between 1985 and 2007, adjusting for survival to 2025; and finally, we deduct net permanent outmigration over the 2003-2025 period. Using conservative assumptions throughout, we find that the number of legitimate voters stands at approximately 7.12 crore, compared to the official roll of 7.89 crore, implying an inflation of 9.7 percent.

detail.title: Why We Delay: A Meta-Analytic Investigation of Motivational Quality and Procrastination Patterns
detail.abstract: This study explored the relationship between different types of motivation and procrastination within the framework of Self-Determination Theory. A total of 155 effect sizes from 64 independent studies (N = 28,019) were synthesized through meta-analysis. Overall, the correlation between motivation and procrastination was small and not statistically significant. Disaggregated analyses revealed clearer patterns: intrinsic motivation was negatively associated with procrastination, whereas extrinsic motivation showed no significant association. The relationship between motivation and procrastination was clearly demonstrated within the framework of Self-Determination Theory. Controlled motivation and amotivation were positively associated with procrastination, whereas autonomous motivation was negatively related to procrastinatory behaviors. Patterns also varied by procrastination type. Academic and passive procrastination shared similar patterns: negatively correlated with intrinsic and autonomous motivation, and positively correlated with extrinsic and controlled motivation. In contrast, active procrastination was positively associated with intrinsic and autonomous motivation and negatively associated with controlled motivation. General procrastination showed no significant relation to the extrinsic motivation included controlled motivation. These findings highlight the importance of motivational quality as well as the specific characteristics of procrastination in understanding procrastinatory behavior.

detail.abstract: With the increasing demand for thinner, lighter, and more compact terminal electronic products, the packaging of MicroSD cards has similarly trended toward ultra-thin designs. This development presents significant challenges for packaging manufacturers, particularly in achieving high packaging yields. This study investigates the COB-type MicroSD cards produced by a company with a focus on the wire bond process—a critical stage contributing to yield loss. Firstly, we investigated the main failure modes in the wire bond process. Then we designed a full factorial experiment, and we performed effect analysis to find out the main factors affecting the defects, analyzed the main effects and interaction effects, and optimized the model to find the proper parameters setting. title: Settlement Agreements under the Brazilian Betting Law
affiliations: Universidade de Brasília (UnB), University of Chicago and University of Pennsylvania

detail.title: Settlement Agreements under the Brazilian Betting Law
detail.abstract: The enactment of Law No. 14,790/2023 marked the beginning of a new regulatory era for Brazil’s fixed-odds betting market. The regulatory framework, enforced by the Secretariat for Prizes and Betting of the Ministry of Finance (SPA/MF), provides for administrative penalties and introduces the possibility of entering into settlement agreements—referred to as “Termos de Compromisso”—to resolve administrative enforcement actions. This article explores the legal nature, eligibility requirements, and practical implications of these agreements, as well as the stages of negotiation and enforcement mechanisms. We argue that the SPA/MF’s adoption of a non-confessional, non-cooperative model of settlement is a strategic choice that encourages regulatory compliance while reducing litigation costs. Drawing comparisons with similar instruments used by other Brazilian authorities, such as CADE and CGU, we identify opportunities and challenges associated with the development of negotiated solutions in the betting sector.

title: CAMELS C in Practice: Evolution from CAMEL, Regulatory Drivers, Empirical Insights, and Strategic Imperatives for India's Banking Sector
affiliations: ICFAI Business School (IBS) Hyderabad, India

detail.title: CAMELS C in Practice: Evolution from CAMEL, Regulatory Drivers, Empirical Insights, and Strategic Imperatives for India's Banking Sector
detail.abstract: This paper traces the evolution of India's banking supervision framework from the traditional CAMEL model (Capital, Asset Quality, Management, Earnings, Liquidity) to the expanded CAMELS C paradigm, which explicitly incorporates Systems (including IT) and Compliance as critical pillars. Driven by chronic non-performing assets (NPAs), governance failures, and emerging risks such as cyber threats and digital banking vulnerabilities, India has gradually adapted global best practices-including the Basel accords and FDIC's CAMELS system-to its unique institutional context. The study employs illustrative cases (PMC Bank, Yes Bank, IL&FS, DHFL) and RBI's interventions (Prompt Corrective Action, cyber guidelines) to demonstrate how each CAMELS C component functions in practice, highlighting sharper triggers for regulatory action and depositor safeguards. Empirical insights reveal how the CAMELS C framework helped preempt or mitigate crises by tying supervisory actions to breaches in capital, asset quality, and compliance norms. However, challenges persist in data gaps in smaller banks, subjective assessments of management and systems quality, and emerging overlaps with ESG and climate risk frameworks. The paper also discusses India's progression toward digital, risk-based supervision (RBS 2.0) that leverages big data and AI, and anticipates future integration of environmental and sustainability metrics, potentially evolving CAMELS C into a "CAMELS E" framework. Strategic recommendations call for the RBI to increase transparency by publishing more CAMELS-like indicators, strengthen data and cybersecurity oversight, and incorporate ESG risks systematically. Banks, especially PSBs and cooperatives , are urged to upgrade governance, proactively manage compliance, and stress-test for liquidity and cyber threats. Depositors and investors are advised to deepen their scrutiny beyond financial ratios to include governance and IT resilience. The overarching aim is to reinforce financial stability, depositor protection, and global confidence in India's banking sector through a more holistic supervisory architecture rooted in past lessons and future risks.

title: Do Penalties Promote Responsible Operations? Evidence from the U.S. Mining Industry
affiliations: York University - Schulich School of Business and IESE Business School

detail.title: Do Penalties Promote Responsible Operations? Evidence from the U.S. Mining Industry
detail.abstract: Financial penalties—fines levied for violations found during site inspections—are widely used to encourage responsible operations, such as compliance with labor and environmental standards or with supplier codes of conduct. However, the effectiveness of penalties in achieving this objective remains unclear. In this paper, we empirically investigate whether higher penalties lead to more responsible operations using a large, granular dataset from the U.S. mining industry. Our identification strategy exploits a policy shock that sharply increased the penalty amounts for health and safety infractions in the mines. We find that higher penalties had, at best, a modest effect on responsible operations. While there was some decrease in violations, which was heterogeneous across mine types, we find no evidence of a decrease in accidents or injuries at mines that faced higher fines. We identify several mechanisms driving this null effect. First, the violations that decreased were unrelated to the root causes of accidents. Second, operational complexity does not explain the heterogeneity across mines, but labor market power does: penalties were least effective in counties where the mining industry is a dominant employer. Third, we identify an unanticipated and unintended consequence of higher penalties that compromised their effectiveness: mining companies strategically contested the higher fines in court, which led to discounted payments, delay in payment times, and an overflow of the court's operating capacity. By examining the mechanisms through which higher penalties (fail to) promote responsible operations, our work offers insights that can be generalized to contexts beyond mining (e.g., global supply chains).

title: NEGOTIATING INEQUALITY: A NEW FRAMEWORK FOR EQUITY IN SALARY NEGOTIATIONS
affiliations: and Indiana University - Kelley School of Business - Department of Business Law

detail.title: NEGOTIATING INEQUALITY: A NEW FRAMEWORK FOR EQUITY IN SALARY NEGOTIATIONS
detail.abstract: This Article reveals a clear doctrinal and practical imperative to rethink negotiation-based pay disparities under the Equal Pay Act. On the doctrinal side, courts remain divided on whether an employer can invoke an employee’s stronger bargaining or mere willingness to accept less as a “factor other than sex.” As this Article shows, negotiation prowess or acquiescence is not the sort of factor Congress intended to legitimize with the catch-all. Equally compelling is the empirical insight that negotiation is far from a gender-neutral practice. Women face a well-documented double-bind in salary negotiations. They are often socially penalized for asserting themselves, which understandably makes many women hesitant to negotiate, and when they do negotiate, they frequently achieve worse outcomes than their male counterparts. What may appear on the surface as an individual’s “choice” or skill in negotiating is, in truth, heavily mediated by gendered social dynamics. This Article’s review of the social science literature exposes negotiation as a site of structural inequality, where equal merit does not translate into equal reward because the process itself is skewed by bias. Given these insights, and under the Ninth Circuit’s framework in Rizo v. Yovino, negotiation should be unequivocally disallowed as an affirmative defense, either by itself or in combination with other factors. This will reaffirm fidelity to the EPA’s mandate that equal work deserves equal pay.

detail.title: Shipper-Centric Short-Term Vehicle Capacity Requirement Planning for First-Mile Bulk-Commodity Delivery
detail.abstract: This study considers the short-term vehicle capacity requirement planning problem from the shipper’s perspective, driven by the rapidly increasing demand for transporting bulk commodities in first mile logistics. The problem is to determine the types and quantities of vehicles and assign them to regions. The objective is to minimize the total costs associated with transport and additional stop costs. This problem is formulated as a mixed-integer programming model to reflect practical logistics constraints. This proposes two matheuristic algorithms to solve this problem. The relax-and-fix heuristic constructs an initial solution by progressively relaxing and fixing subsets of decision variables, while the fix-and-optimize heuristic improves this solution through iterative local optimization, refixing certain variables. Based on synthetic and real data from a South Korean context, computational experiments show that these proposed algorithms consistently produce acceptable quality solutions within a reasonable computation time. Scenario analyses provide further practical insights for shippers by incorporating real-world operational constraints.

detail.abstract: Background. Combat-related dementia is an underexplored yet increasingly relevant phenomenon of cognitive decline among military personnel exposed to combat stress, blast injuries, and traumatic brain injury (TBI). The aim of this study is to identify the main clinical and epidemiological variants of combat-related dementia and to construct a stratification model for predicting its progression. Methods. A retrospective, single-center cohort study included 206 veterans who underwent rehabilitation at the Nodus Neurorehabilitation Center between 2014 and 2024. The sample was stratified into three groups: (A) organic dementia following TBI; (B) dementia without TBI, PTSD, or organic brain changes; (C) dementia with a history of PTSD / blast trauma / psychotrauma. The mean cognitive status scores (MOCA/MMSE) were 23.4 (SD 2.7) in group A, 25.8 (SD 2.1) in group B, and 26.3 (SD 1.9) in group C; ERP and EEG parameters were analyzed in parallel. Ordinal and binary logistic regression were applied to identify risk factors. Results. Three clinically distinct trajectories of cognitive decline were identified. Group A exhibited an organic type of dementia with a clear correlation between MMSE scores and ERP markers. Group B showed a pattern of functional fronto-limbic decompensation with inconsistent electrophysiological dynamics. In group C, cognitive impairment manifested as functional fronto-limbic decompensation without distinct morphological substrate but with characteristic ERP alterations. The key prognostic factors were age and duration of deployment in combat zones: deployment exceeding 14 months was associated with nearly a threefold increase in the risk of dementia progression. Conclusions. A novel epidemiological model of combat-related dementia is proposed, conceptualizing it as a multifactorial cognitive syndrome combining both organic and functional impairments. The presented results may form the basis for future strategies of diagnostics and the development of both targeted veteran rehabilitation programs and broader health policy initiatives. The identified clinical phenotypes are essential for an interdisciplinary approach to cognitive screening, management, and prevention of dementia in military populations under conditions of modern hybrid warfare.

title: Should We Fear Personalized Pricing?
