detail.title: Should We Fear Personalized Pricing?

publicationDetails.detailsText: George Mason Law & Economics Research Paper No. 25-10
publicationDetails.journalName: Antonin Scalia Law School, George Mason University, Law & Economics Research Paper Series

detail.abstract: The practice of personalized pricing involves using information about a consumer to more accurately estimate an individual’s willingness-to-pay for a product to calibrate pricing to that individual. If the practice grows, what does this imply for consumer welfare—particularly for digital markets where there is an abundance of user data? While some consumers may end up enjoying lower prices and having greater access to markets, other consumers will likely end up paying higher prices relative to the counterfactual, that is, a world without personalized pricing but likely some other forms of price discrimination. Nonetheless, it is unlikely that all consumers are made worse off relative to the counterfactual. Additionally, there are reasons that mitigate the concern that the practice of personalize pricing will grow. First, there could be competitive pressure to not engage in the practice—as firms that explicitly avoid personalized pricing will have a competitive advantage in the eyes of consumers. Relatedly, firms that do engage in personalized pricing will likely be stigmatized in the market, which creates a strong disincentive to widely adopt the practice.

title: Proposing a Digital Supply Chain Control System in the Stock Market: A Strategic Solution for Bangladesh and Other Developing Countries
affiliations: Metropolitan University Sylhet, Bangladesh

detail.title: Proposing a Digital Supply Chain Control System in the Stock Market: A Strategic Solution for Bangladesh and Other Developing Countries
detail.abstract: This study addresses the critical challenge of request syndicates in developing countries like Bangladesh, where artificial manipulation of essential commodity prices through hoarding and force dislocations creates profitable insecurity and consumer difficulty. The purpose of this exploration is to design and estimate a digital force chain control system that ensures price stability and translucency across the entire product trip from import to end-seller.. The methodology integrates qualitative approaches (stakeholder interviews, case studies of force chain vulnerabilities) with quantitative ways (real-time sale tracking algorithms, data analytics for force-demand matching) to develop a smart card-based monitoring result. Crucial findings demonstrate that this system effectively prevents stock manipulation by digitally recording every sale, automatically detecting disagreement, and enabling immediate nonsupervisory intervention. The exploration provides value by offering a scalable, tech-driven approach to strike black-demand networks while icing fair pricing. Still, limitations include perpetration costs, technological abandonment walls, and implicit resistance from settled syndicates. Practical counteraccusations suggest this model can empower governments with practicable request oversight tools while helping businesses operate further transparently. Social counteraccusations punctuate reduced profitable inequality, protection of low-income consumers from price shocks, and strengthened public trust in request systems. This study presents a replicable frame for developing nations floundering with analogous request manipulation challenges.

detail.title: No Time to Attend? Effects of Family-Friendly Meeting Hours in Politics
detail.abstract: The challenge of balancing family life with work obligations beyond conventional hours is recognized as a significant driver of gender disparities. I leverage novel data on political meetings in Norway to investigate how session timing affects attendance. Despite outcry that evening meetings hinder women's political participation, I find that 'family-friendly' hours alone are unlikely to be a game changer for most women. Instead, they increase absences by almost 30% among politicians with inflexible daytime commitments. The results have important policy implications for institutional scheduling and suggest that efforts to address women's underrepresentation might be more effectively directed elsewhere.

detail.title: Beyond Words: The Challenge of Measuring Financial Text Across Borders

publicationDetails.detailsText: Journal of International Business Studies, Forthcoming

detail.abstract: Dictionary-based methods are widely used to assess the information content of corporate disclosures, yet they are primarily developed within the U.S. context. This study applies a popular U.S.-based dictionary approach to analyze the disclosure sentiment of 200,960 earnings call transcripts across 85 countries. While disclosure sentiment is positively associated with short-window stock returns globally, the relationship is approximately 30% weaker for non-U.S. firms. Drawing on cultural accounting theory, we find that cultural differences play a central role in explaining this disparity. In terms of practical implications, we find that sentiment-based trading strategies are effective for U.S. firms and for non-U.S. firms operating in culturally similar environments, but not for firms from culturally distant countries. To address potential endogeneity, we use linguistic features as instrumental variables reflecting historical cultural values. Additionally, we apply a machine learning model trained on U.S. data, which continues to uncover cultural limitations when used internationally. Our findings underscore the importance of institutional and cultural context in international textual analysis and highlight the limitations of applying U.S.-centric empirical methods globally. The development of culturally sensitive and contextualized empirical approaches has the potential to advance the measurement and understanding of financial communication in international settings.

title: The Writings of Mulk Raj Anand: A Realistic Approach On Social Awareness
affiliations: A.M.B.S Mahavidyalaya

detail.title: The Writings of Mulk Raj Anand: A Realistic Approach On Social Awareness
detail.abstract:
This paper attempts to analyze the social problems of India in the light of thewritings of Mulk Raj Anand. His first novel ‘Untouchable’, written in1935, is a highly chargedintellectual discourse on the Karmic illusion of work and unsociability and his second novel‘Coolie’, is a humanistic discourse on the subject of human labor. While Bakha’s complicated existence as an untouchable is situated in the varnashrama structure of Hinduism, Munoo’s fate as a rickshaw-puller is tied to his dehumanizing work as a Coolie.The fact remains that Bakha & Munoo( hero-anti-hero of Untouchable & Coolie) are helpless laborers, whose work has been permanently devalued and misappropriated.

As a matter of fact, Mulk Raj Anand has aptly explained the socialproblems of Indian sub-continent in a great extent and aroused social awareness. It is argued that the metaphors of ‘Untouchable’ & ‘Coolie’ are universal metaphors of the history, sociology and metaphysics of human sufferings and of man’s humanity to fellowmen. Mulk Raj Anand stretches the metaphors of untouchable & coolie to suggest that we all are untouchables and coolies.

The debate on casteism & untouchability from Gandhi to Ambedkar and to the present times is still very much alive in the post-independence India. Really, this paper justifies the legal remedies in achieving social justice and equality not only theoretically, but making it a practical approach, where the poorest of the poor can get equal opportunities in a better manner.

title: The Multi-Period Vehicle Routing Problem with Minimum Utilization Constraints
affiliations: Technische Universität München (TUM) - TUM School of Management, Technische Universität München (TUM) - TUM School of Management and Technische Universität München (TUM) - TUM School of Management

detail.title: The Multi-Period Vehicle Routing Problem with Minimum Utilization Constraints
detail.abstract: The daily planning of customer delivery routes is a critical task for logistics service providers, where planners focus on maximizing resource efficiency and total transportation costs. Common approaches for modeling these goals include complex, difficult-to-estimate fleet usage costs. In this paper, we simplify the modeling of such cost structures by introducing an easy-to-understand minimum truckload utilization rule that aligns well with best practices in real-world delivery scenarios. We formulate the multi-period vehicle routing problem with minimum utilization constraints (MPVRP-MUC) to create efficient routes while minimizing unfulfilled customer requests within the desired delivery periods. We ensure feasibility despite fixed minimum vehicle loads by allowing request shifts to future periods. We decompose the MPVRP-MUC by periods and solve each single-period VRP-MUC by a Hybrid Genetic Search algorithm (HGS-VRP-MUC). This integrates a Variable Neighborhood Search (VNS) procedure along with a repair mechanism to maintain solution feasibility. The numerical study shows that the HGS-VRP-MUC approach continuously achieves optimal results for instances with up to 80 customers. Furthermore, we conduct multi-period simulations to analyze the influence of minimum utilization constraints, where the number of vehicles over 10 periods can be reduced by up to 12%, and the total distance is reduced by 3.5% while still serving over 90% of the total demand in every period.

title: Improving Column Complementarity in a Restricted Master Heuristic with a Grasp-Guided Completion Application to the Vehicle Routing Problem with Stochastic Demands
affiliations: Polytechnique Montreal, Polytechnique Montréal, Polytechnique Montréal and Interuniversity Research Centre on Enterprise Networks, Logistics and Transportation (CIRRELT)

detail.title: Improving Column Complementarity in a Restricted Master Heuristic with a Grasp-Guided Completion Application to the Vehicle Routing Problem with Stochastic Demands
detail.abstract: Many combinatorial optimization problems, such as vehicle and crew scheduling, can be modeled using path-flow formulations, where each variable represents a feasible route. A major challenge in these formulations lies in efficiently generating high-quality integer solutions from a model with exponentially many variables. We propose a hybrid restricted master heuristic that combines column generation with a greedy randomized adaptive search procedure (GRASP) to improve solution quality in these settings. The method first uses dynamic programming-based pricing to generate routes guided by dual variables from the linear relaxation. It then applies GRASP to complete partial solutions and introduce new routes that complement those with positive reduced costs, thereby improving column complementarity before solving the resulting model as a mixed-integer program. This integration leverages both the global guidance of column generation and the diversification strength of GRASP. We illustrate the approach on the vehicle routing problem with stochastic demands, where customer demands are modeled as random variables revealed upon arrival. Experimental results on 40 benchmark instances with up to 60 customers show that the method reliably produces high-quality solutions, achieving optimality gaps below 5% in all cases and averaging under 2% within 5 minutes of computation, with a higher proportion of best solutions returned than any other variant considered.Keywords: vehicle routing, stochastic demands, restricted master heuristic,GRASPEmail addressesgael-simon.reynal@polymtl.ca (Ga¨el REYNAL), quentin.cappart@polymtl.ca (Quentin CAPPART), guy.desaulniers@polymtl.ca(Guy DESAULNIERS), louis-martin.rousseau@polymtl.ca (Louis-Martin ROUSSEAU)Preprint submitted to Computers and Operations Research July 17, 2025mark instances with up to 60 customers show that the method reliably produces high-quality solutions, achieving optimality gaps below 5% in all cases and averaging under 2% within 5 minutes of computation, with a higher proportion of best solutions returned than any other variant considered.

title: Scheduling Method of Distributed Energy Storage Considering Flexibility and Economy of Active Distribution Network
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and China Agricultural University

detail.title: Scheduling Method of Distributed Energy Storage Considering Flexibility and Economy of Active Distribution Network
detail.abstract: As one of the solutions to address the shortage of fossil fuels, distributed generators(DGs) have been widely integrated into active distribution networks(ADN). At the same time, it inevitably brings flexibility issues such as trend reversal and voltage violation. In recent years, distributed energy storage(DES) experiences rapid growth and is widely applied in ADN. When DES is integrated, it can effectively smooth the fluctuations brought by DGs and improve the economy and flexibility of ADN. In order to incorporate DES into a unified scheduling scheme, a collaborative scheduling method for DES managed by power grid companies is proposed, considering system economy and flexibility. Firstly, regarding the evaluation of the operation of ADN, steady state model of ADN including time-series analysis model of DES and power flow constraints is introduced. Then for the optimization schedule of DES, a steady-state mathematical model considering different objective functions is constructed. The fast solving algorithm is further introduced. Finally, an analysis was conducted on the modified IEEE 33-node test system to validate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Building Operational Resilience in Mixed-Model Assembly Line: A Digital Twin Approach
affiliations: University of Florence, Polytechnic University of Milan, Polytechnic University of Milan and University of Florence

detail.title: Building Operational Resilience in Mixed-Model Assembly Line: A Digital Twin Approach
detail.abstract: Disruptions in mixed-model assembly lines pose significant challenges for industries operating in high-variability environments. These challenges are particularly acute in sectors such as fashion, where SKU alternation, high customization, and dynamic production requirements complicate operational resilience. To address these complexities, this paper proposes a digital twin (DT) application framework aimed at identifying and mitigating operational disruptions. The framework was validated through a case study in the fashion industry, demonstrating its effectiveness in managing disruptions such as machine failures and quality issues. From a theoretical perspective, the study classifies disruptions within Supply Chain Operations Management (SCOM) dimensions, distinguishing between operational and supply chain levels. Furthermore, the framework contributes to the ongoing discourse on DTs by offering validated insights into their role in managing operational disruptions in mixed-model assembly lines. More broadly, it situates itself within the ongoing conversation on how Industry 4.0 technologies, such as DTs, act as enablers for the transition toward Industry 5.0. Specifically, this study underscores the role of DTs as key facilitators of resilience, a foundational pillar of Industry 5.0. From a managerial perspective, company’s performance is improved through the proposed structured approach to managing disruptions. By integrating information across systems and transforming raw data into actionable insights, it enhances resilience through informed decision-making and recovery action evaluation via simulation-optimization. This focus on resilience and optimization positions the framework as a comprehensive tool for navigating the complexities of modern production environments. Future research could expand its applicability to supply chain-level disruptions, broadening its impact across key supply chain nodes.

title: A Comparative Study of Taiwanese Firm's Pr Configurations in the Philippines, Vietnam, and China

detail.title: A Comparative Study of Taiwanese Firm's Pr Configurations in the Philippines, Vietnam, and China
detail.abstract: For overseas enterprises, Public Relations is an important function to obtain resources under uncertainties. Since Taiwanese firms' investments in the Philippines, Vietnam, and China are on the rise by the day, this research tries to understand their PR strategies based on the aspect of Configuration Theory. In the end, using the data collected from on-site observations, Content Analysis, and the Delphi method, we determined the PR configurations of Taiwanese firms in the Philippines, Vietnam, and China. We also compare these configurations and give some suggestions for further studies.

title: Perception Economy: How Currency of Collective Beliefs Redefines Organizational Value and Power
affiliations: University of Portsmouth

detail.title: Perception Economy: How Currency of Collective Beliefs Redefines Organizational Value and Power
detail.abstract: In the digital age, where narratives and reputations increasingly dictate material outcomes, this article theorizes perception not merely as a cognitive process but as a systemic currency that constitutes organizational value and power. While prior research acknowledges perception’s role in legitimacy or branding, it under-theorizes perception as a dynamic, transferable resource operating within a perception economy—a market-like system where collective interpretations are traded, accumulated, and converted into tangible outcomes. Integrating social constructionism, economic sociology, and sensemaking literatures, we define perception currency as the aggregate value assigned to entities (e.g., firms, leaders, ideas) through socially validated beliefs. This currency is characterized by its fungibility (convertible into financial capital or influence), transferability (traded via narratives and digital platforms), and accumulability (reinforced through consistency or eroded by dissonance).

title: Knowledge-Based Framework for Addressing Alternative Optima In Dea-Based Project Portfolio Selection of Ic Design Projects: An Empirical Study

detail.title: Knowledge-Based Framework for Addressing Alternative Optima In Dea-Based Project Portfolio Selection of Ic Design Projects: An Empirical Study
detail.abstract: This study addresses the critical gap in systematic project portfolio management mechanisms for supporting bidding decisions in the semiconductor integrated circuit (IC) design service industry, considering revenue, technological positioning, and capacity constraints. The specific research questions are as follows: (1) How can efficiency assessment be integrated with capacity planning to improve project portfolio decision quality? (2) How can the issue of multiple weight solutions in the DEA-CCR model be resolved when decision-making units achieve an efficiency score of one, while maintaining ranking stability? To answer these questions, we construct the UNISON framework as follows. First, a knowledge-driven DEA-CCR model is used to evaluate project efficiencies. Second, cross-efficiency sensitivity analysis identifies and adjusts invariant weights and slack variables to stabilize rankings. Third, a multidimensional knapsack formulation integrates each project’s development duration and available R&D capacity into a single optimization problem. A case study of 15 candidate projects from a Taiwanese semiconductor IC design service firm validates this framework. The results demonstrate that, compared to the conventional GPM-oriented method, UNISON achieves a 3.71% increase in total revenue, attains the highest ratings in technological depth and breadth, and effectively alleviates scheduling bottlenecks.

title: A Hybrid Fuzzy Genetic Algorithm with Tabu Search for Led Surface Mount Technology Scheduling Problem
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and National Tsing Hua University

detail.title: A Hybrid Fuzzy Genetic Algorithm with Tabu Search for Led Surface Mount Technology Scheduling Problem
detail.abstract: With the rapid advancement of AI and IoT technologies, the demand for smart displays has surged, driving fast growth in the LED industry. To meet the increasing demand for high-brightness, high-resolution LED applications, Surface Mount Technology (SMT) has become indispensable in LED manufacturing. However, the high-mix, low-volume nature of LED production has made SMT processes increasingly complex. To enhance production efficiency and shorten lead times, this study proposes a Hybrid Fuzzy Genetic Algorithm with Tabu Search (HFGATS) to optimize SMT scheduling, which can be characterized as a flow shop scheduling problem (FSSP). Previous studies on FSSP seldom consider the combination of factors such as material availability, production line balancing, machine availability, designated machine constraints and dependent setup time constraints. This study addresses this gap by incorporating real-world production factors, integrating fuzzy logic controllers to dynamically adjust scheduling parameters, and deploying tabu search as a local search mechanism to enhance adaptability to practical manufacturing environments. Through empirical validation in a Taiwanese LED manufacturing company, results demonstrate that the proposed HFGATS can effectively find near-optimal solutions, significantly reduce tardiness, and improve resource utilization and production efficiency.

title: Optimizing Environmental Flow Trade-Offs for Sustainable Hydropower in a Himalayan Reservoir, Dudhkoshi Storage Hydroelectric Project
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Tribhuvan University - Institute of Engineering Pulchowk Campus and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Optimizing Environmental Flow Trade-Offs for Sustainable Hydropower in a Himalayan Reservoir, Dudhkoshi Storage Hydroelectric Project
detail.abstract: The increasing population and intensifying climate change in the central Himalayas necessitate a sustainable water resources management. Optimizing reservoir operations is crucial for effective water management, maintaining a balance among multiple objectives such as energy generation, irrigation, flood control, and ecological sustainability. This study evaluates the reservoir operation strategies in Dudhkoshi Storage Hydroelectric Project (DKSHEP) for energy maximization ensuring the environmental flow (e-flow) requirement. Using hybrid Particle Swarm Optimization and Grey Wolf Optimization (PSOGWO) algorithm, this study analyzes the optimized operation under seven choices for e-flow assessment method. The results show that e-flow allocations vary, with DOED and MMFM prioritizing energy output (3318 and 3291 GWh, respectively) but risking environmental degradation, while methods such as Tessman method lower total energy by 35% due to high environmental release. In dewatered reach, post-dam flow alteration (up to -38% in wet-season) can have both positive and negative impact in downstream ecosystems until the confluence with the Sunkoshi River. This study underscores the need for detailed analysis of hydrology, downstream impacts, and aquatic biology, while recommending MMFM and ADM for their balance of operational efficiency and environmental protection. This study can aid in decision making for sustainable development in the central Himalayas considering water, energy, and environment nexus.

title: Residential Satisfaction Among Public Housing Residents
affiliations: University of Rhode Island, University of Maryland and University of Maryland

detail.title: Residential Satisfaction Among Public Housing Residents
detail.abstract: Using an original survey of public housing residents in a New England state, we make the case that surveys of public housing residents can help us understand the unique experiences, social situations, needs, and preferences of those residents and create policies that reflect those lived realities. While policy makers often assert that the housing insecure are better served in scattered site housing in low poverty neighborhoods, we find that residents have good reasons to prefer staying in public housing. To the extent that the residents prefer to move out of public housing, we find that in our sample, preferences for moving out of site based housing is driven by poor experiences with management and not because of geographic access to services or relationships with neighbors. This suggests that public housing facilities could be improved through investments in public housing management-occupant relations. We conclude that surveys of public housing residents could allow policy makers to take a proactive approach to addressing residents’ issues while drawing on strengths of current facilities, rather than applying a one size fits all public housing policy based on historic policy issues.

title: Multi-Algorithm Collaboration and Dynamic Feature Mining for Carbon Market Price Forecasting Model

detail.title: Multi-Algorithm Collaboration and Dynamic Feature Mining for Carbon Market Price Forecasting Model
detail.abstract: Driven by global climate change and carbon neutrality goals, accurate carbon price forecasting is critical for policy-making and market decisions. However, carbon markets are characterized by strong nonlinearity, non-stationarity, and intertwined multiple factors, limiting the accuracy of existing models. To address this, this study proposes the moCEEMDAN-Attention-BiLSTM-Random Forest hybrid model, with key improvements and advantages as follows:First, the improved moCEEMDAN decomposes carbon price data from Hubei and Guangdong. Combined with sample entropy, it reconstructs components into high- and low-frequency sequences, effectively resolving mode mixing in raw signals and enhancing targeted feature extraction.Second, Random Forest is introduced for feature selection, eliminating redundancy to simplify the model and improve input effectiveness.The constructed Attention-BiLSTM-Random Forest framework focuses on key time-series features via the attention mechanism and optimizes nonlinear fitting through Random Forest, significantly boosting prediction accuracy.Additionally, the Morris method and multi-scenario simulations enable dynamic sensitivity analysis and reveal carbon price fluctuation patterns, breaking the limitations of static forecasting.Results confirm that the model exhibits significant advantages in prediction accuracy and dynamic feature analysis. It provides a new technical path and theoretical support for carbon price forecasting, offers a scientific basis for policy-making and market decisions, and holds important practical value for promoting stable carbon market development.

title: Energy–Carbon–Value Coupling Regulation Decision Model for Multi-Park Integrated Energy Systems
affiliations: Chongqing University of Posts and Telecommunications, Chongqing University of Posts and Telecommunications, Chongqing University of Posts and Telecommunications, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Chongqing University of Posts and Telecommunications and Chongqing University

detail.title: Energy–Carbon–Value Coupling Regulation Decision Model for Multi-Park Integrated Energy Systems
detail.abstract: Under the global imperatives of carbon reduction and energy transition, the coupling among internal agents within Park Integrated Energy Systems (PIES) has grown increasingly complex. Efficiently leveraging external multi-energy markets while flexibly mobilizing internal multiple agents to enhance energy efficiency, remedy supply shortfalls, and achieve precise carbon-emission control thus holds significant research value. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a two-layer game-theoretic model incorporating carbon-emission factors to optimize both external and internal operations of PIES. First, an energy–carbon coupled emission accounting model is developed to explicitly capture carbon-emission transfers resulting from multi-agent energy transactions, enabling accurate system-wide carbon accounting. Second, a Stackelberg game model is formulated to optimize interactions between the upper-level energy network and park systems, while a cooperative game model is constructed to attain internal optimization within PIES. In addition, a multi-agent cooperative game revenue-allocation mechanism is designed to quantify each agent’s marginal contribution to the alliance’s economic and environmental benefits. Multi-scenario simulations demonstrate that cooperation among PIES markedly improves internal supply–demand matching, reduces carbon-emission intensity, and enhances competitiveness in the upper-level Stackelberg game, thereby harmonizing economic and low-carbon objectives.

title: Traffic and Demand Management Using Dynamic Pricing with Route Reservations
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and University of Cyprus

detail.title: Traffic and Demand Management Using Dynamic Pricing with Route Reservations
detail.abstract: Many cities aim at developing sustainable transportation systems, which can facilitate the efficient transfer of people and goods, foster economic growth, reduce the negative environmental effects of mobility, and overall, enhance citizens' well-being. We hereby propose a Dynamic Pricing framework with Route Reservations (DPRR) as an advanced traffic and demand management platform to assist in addressing a number of strategic goals with respect to sustainability in transportation. DPRR utilizes route reservations and applies dynamic pricing as a control mechanism to implicitly affect users' decision-making, aiming to yield desirable traffic conditions aligned with various user- or system-oriented objectives. At the same time, numerous spatiotemporal route options are available to users any time, providing them with the desired freedom of choice. Users act rationally, ultimately choosing the spatiotemporal route that minimizes their disutility. We conduct a series of simulations that demonstrate how the proposed architecture can be parameterized to serve, among others, social optimum, revenue-focused, as well as regulated throughput goals of environmental consequences, aiming to discourage users from overusing the road network and therefore promote the use of alternative, environmentally-friendly transportation means.

title: The Interplay between Member Satisfaction and Social Influence in Shaping Group Cohesion and Migration
affiliations: Wageningen University & Research and Wageningen University & Research

detail.title: The Interplay between Member Satisfaction and Social Influence in Shaping Group Cohesion and Migration
detail.abstract: This study explores the dynamics of individuals' decisions to leave social groups, focusing on two primary forces: satisfaction within the current group and attraction to other groups, which emerges from shared information about the satisfaction of their members. Satisfaction within a group is defined as the outcome of weighted positive feedback received from interpersonal interactions over time. Individuals store feedback in memory, and recent feedback is weighted higher, leading to satisfaction being dynamically influenced by recent experiences. Hence, satisfaction within a group is shaped by interpersonal interactions, memory, and learning, while attraction to other groups arises from shared knowledge about the satisfaction levels of members in those groups, transmitted through the social network.Using agent-based modeling, we simulate how these forces influence individual behavior, group cohesion, and the formation of broader social patterns. The model examines how individuals weigh their current satisfaction against perceived benefits in other groups, leading to decisions about whether to stay or migrate. Tested across Fully Connected (FC) and Preferential Attachment (PA) network structures, this approach provides insights into the dynamics of group formation and migration, with applications for understanding collective behavior in various social and environmental contexts.

title: Cascading Failure Blocking Strategy for Highway Energy Systems Considering Load Classification ⋆
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Cascading Failure Blocking Strategy for Highway Energy Systems Considering Load Classification ⋆

keywords.keywords: Blocking control ， Cascading failure ，Load prioritization ，Transportation-Energy Integration

detail.abstract: In the operation and maintenance of expressways, critical loads such as emergency firefighting, surveillance, and communication systems have extremely low tolerance for power outages, necessitating the development of a secure defense system adapted to new power systems in transportation. To address this, a cascading failure mitigation control method considering load prioritization is proposed. A control model integrating load grading with cascading failure analysis and multi-stage blocking strategies is established. Initial fault identification is conducted based on voltage fluctuation, load rate, and branch power proportion. Functional indicators, including power flow limit violations and transmission efficiency, and structural indicators, such as line betweenness and network average efficiency, are selected. A combined weighting strategy based on the Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) and the Technique for Order Preference by Similarity to Ideal Solution (TOPSIS) is employed to determine the fault propagation paths. The multi-stage blocking strategy aims to minimize the probability of cascading failures and associated losses by adjusting generator outputs, curtailing renewable energy, and shedding non-critical loads. Case studies demonstrate that the proposed model effectively reduces system losses and fault probabilities at each stage while ensuring uninterrupted power supply to critical loads, validating the economic and reliable performance of the control strategy.

title: Friendship as Pedagogy: Rehumanizing Management Education in the Era of Ai
affiliations: University of Calgary

detail.title: Friendship as Pedagogy: Rehumanizing Management Education in the Era of Ai
detail.abstract: As artificial intelligence (AI) increasingly automates analytical tasks, the value of human-centered skills, such as empathy, collaboration, and ethical judgment, has risen dramatically in business education. At the same time, university students report high levels of stress, isolation, and disengagement. This paper explores the role of friendship-support satisfaction as a deliberate, scalable pedagogical lever for improving student well-being and re-humanizing management education in an AI-shaped economy. Anchored in social support theory and psychological safety research, this study examines the influence of perceived friendship support on stress among undergraduate business students. Drawing on a convergent mixed-methods study of 443 students, including both quantitative survey data and qualitative narrative responses, this study shows that friendship-support satisfaction significantly predicts lower stress, with psychological safety serving as a partial mediator. Thematic analysis reveals three key mechanisms: emotional sanctuary, collective efficacy, and positive emotional spirals. We propose a Friendship Teaching Toolbox integrating four classroom-tested interventions to strengthen peer connection, promote inclusive collaboration, and develop the relational capacities students need for AI-augmented leadership and learning.

title: Boardroom Gender Diversity and Corporate Sustainability Practices: A Decade-Long Bibliometric and Systematic Review for Guiding Future Research and Policy
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, University of Sindh and University of Portsmouth - Faculty of Business - Department of Economics

detail.title: Boardroom Gender Diversity and Corporate Sustainability Practices: A Decade-Long Bibliometric and Systematic Review for Guiding Future Research and Policy

keywords: Directions for Future Research and Practice

detail.abstract: This study evaluates the direct and indirect relationship between boardroom gender diversity (BGD) and corporate sustainability practices (CSP) through a Bibliometric Analysis (BA) and Systematic Literature Review (SLR) of 180 articles indexed in Scopus, published between 2013 and 2024. The BA revealed that existing research is scarce, relates to a small number of researchers, universities, journals, and countries. However, the academic interest is growing, as evidenced by an upsurge in citations and publication trends. The SLR revealed that prior literature is incongruent due to several reasons, including the dissimilar operationalization of key constructs and insufficient attention to the different numerical representations of female directors (tokenism and critical mass), as well as their personal educational and professional attributes. The inclusion or exclusion of important aspects closely related to the BGD and CSP, or their association, relying more on moderation than mediation, dissimilarity in moderators, mediators, and regression estimators, and an exclusive focus on quantitative research (overlooking qualitative and mixed methods research) are other reasons for the prior inconsistent findings. Underrepresentation of some countries and sectors, rarely probed variations in county-specific characteristics (such as governance quality, human development indicators, legal, political, social, cultural, and religious factors) despite the context sensitive nature of the inquiry, and addressing endogeneity in a limited number of studies, with different internal and external IVs may also be the rationales behind previous incongruent outcomes. Overall, the study enriches the literature, theory, methodology, and practice in several ways.

title: The Link between ESG Practices and International Expansion: The Moderating Role of Gender Diversity in the Boardroom
affiliations: Rey Juan Carlos University, Rey Juan Carlos University and Universidad Rey Juan Carlos - Facultad de Ciencias Jurisdicas y Sociales

detail.title: The Link between ESG Practices and International Expansion: The Moderating Role of Gender Diversity in the Boardroom
detail.abstract: AbstractPurpose: This study investigates how corporate sustainability practices, indicated by ESG performance, and board gender diversity influence firm internationalization. By examining these governance and strategic factors together, the paper aims to enhance understanding of how internal organizational elements shape global market engagement.Design:  The empirical analysis utilizes an unbalanced panel dataset of 22,098 firm-year observations from 2015 to 2022 across four major global regions. A panel Tobit regression model is applied to address the censored nature of the dependent variable (internationalization ratio). The study explores both direct and interaction effects, incorporating linear and non-linear specifications while conducting robustness checks through alternative models and subsample analyses based on ESG and diversity quartiles.Findings: The results indicate that ESG performance and board gender diversity have a positive influence on firm internationalization. However, the relationship between gender diversity and internationalization is inverted U-shaped, showing diminishing returns beyond a certain point. While aggregate model interaction effects between ESG and gender diversity are not statistically significant, subsample analyses reveal that high ESG performance enhances the positive impact of board diversity, and vice versa.Originality: The paper contributes to the international business and corporate governance literature by demonstrating that the effects of ESG and gender diversity on internationalization are non-linear and context-dependent, highlighting the need for integrated governance approaches that align sustainability and inclusion with strategic international goals.

title: How Climate Change Shapes Firm Risk-Taking Behavior: Evidence from Investment and Environmental Channels
affiliations: Nyenrode Business University and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: How Climate Change Shapes Firm Risk-Taking Behavior: Evidence from Investment and Environmental Channels
detail.abstract: This study investigates the relationship between climate change exposure and corporate risk-taking employing a large cross-country dataset of 3,992 firms over the period of 2002-2022. We provide novel evidence that firms with higher climate change exposure are likely to reduce their corporate risk-taking. Our baseline results remain robust and consistent when applying entropy balancing to our sample, utilizing a quasi-natural experiment based on the Paris Agreement as an exogenous shock, and employing an instrumental variable approach. Next, as a novel contribution, we identify two separate transmission mechanisms, i.e., investment behavior and environmental practices, through which climate change exposure affects corporate risk-taking. Higher exposure leads to lower R&D intensity and improved investment efficiency, while also enhancing environmental performance and innovation, all of which contribute to more prudent risk-taking behavior. Finally, we provide novel evidence that information asymmetry and governance positively moderate the negative association between climate change exposure and corporate risk-taking. This finding suggests that stronger governance and reduced information asymmetry (higher transparency) at both the firm and country level can attenuate the negative impact of climate change exposure on corporate risk-taking. Overall, our results suggest that while climate change exposure tends to reduce corporate risk-taking, the strength of this effect substantially depends on the informational and governance context in which firms operate.

title: Expert Elicitation Study for Sustainable Small Hydropower (Sshp) Planning Using Mcda Techniques
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Expert Elicitation Study for Sustainable Small Hydropower (Sshp) Planning Using Mcda Techniques
detail.abstract: A B S T R A C TThe process of siting Sustainable Small Hydropower (SSHP) involves complex decision-making, including social, economic, environmental, and technical (SEET) factors. This paper employs expert elicitation (EE) to provide guidance for siting SSHPs. In doing so, it sets a priority order for identified Main criteria (MC) and Subcriteria (SC), while enhancing good sustainability practice during the developing phase of SSHP site.Utilizing Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) and Weighted Product Model (WPM), we compute criterion weights for consensus Pairwise Comparison Matrices (PCMs) aggregated using Row Geometric Mean Method for MC and SC. The PCMs consistencies were evaluated using Geometric Consistency Index (GCI), while AHP and WPM models resilience were determined through sensitivity analyses (SA).Result reveals that the 42 seasoned experts rank the MC in order of importance as follows: Technical, Economic, Environmental, and Social. The GCI obtained are 0.005 and 0.0238, indicating reliable PCM. MC SA shows complete robustness at 100%, whereas SC robustness registers at 63.14% and 93.71%, for AHP and WPM, respectively. The most critical performance measure presents technical and elevation/slope as the most sensitive (MS) MC and SC, respectively. Most Critical Criteria detects zero sensitivity for MC, while the SC produces protected ecological zone as the most sensitive SC. This novel study combines EE and MCDA methods to uniquely identify MS SSHP planning factors and provide stakeholders with the first comprehensive, actionable, and intelligent decision framework guide for achieving SSHP.

title: Adaptive Public Transport Network Optimization for Time-Varying Road Conditions
affiliations: Institut Polytechnique de Paris, Telecom SudParis and Institut Polytechnique de Paris

detail.title: Adaptive Public Transport Network Optimization for Time-Varying Road Conditions
detail.abstract: Public Transport (PT) has always been designed to optimize performance under nominal conditions (of traffic and demand). However, actual conditions during operation very often differ from the nominal ones, which degrade the real performance of PT. Current adaptation approaches consist in corrective actions, such as stop-skipping, which are ineffective faced with large or frequent condition deviations. In those cases, an approach for a deeper redesign of the network might be needed.%This paper is the first to introduce a framework to redesign a PT network in real time, to keep high user- and operator-related performance, even when faced with highly uncertain traffic conditions. To this aim, we adopt a predict-then-optimize approach: PT lines are redesigned to adapt to predicted traffic conditions, via an effective algorithm based on Non-dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm III. We avoid excessive network modifications, by ensuring high Jaccard similarity between the original network and the redesigned one. To account for the impact of the prediction errors in the quality of the redesigned network, we fit an error model on a Diffusion Convolutional Recurrent Neural Network on real data.%Results on the Mandl's network show improvements of up to 97% passenger travel time and 37% operational cost, while preserving 79\% of the original network structure, compared to the optimal nominal static network. These results suggest the importance of going beyond the inflexibility of current PT design approaches, toward a continuous and adaptive redesign.

title: Charting Corporate Sustainability Forward: ESG Reporting and the Future of Climate Adaptation in Ghana
affiliations: University of Surrey, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Charting Corporate Sustainability Forward: ESG Reporting and the Future of Climate Adaptation in Ghana
detail.abstract: This paper explores the concept of double materiality in Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) reporting as a critical framework for enhancing corporate contributions to local climate adaptation and resilience in Ghana. It contextualizes the role of Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) within Ghana's socio-economic landscape by focusing on the potential for multinational subsidiaries to advance local adaptation initiatives by adopting a qualitative, multi-method research design to investigate the role ESG reporting in shaping corporate sustainability and climate adaptation strategies within Ghana's petroleum sector. Unlike the Global North, which benefits from targeted regulations and institutional capacities to effectively monitor ESG reporting, the paper observes that the Global South, including Ghana, faces significant challenges in optimizing corporate partnerships for adaptation initiatives. In this regard, the paper advances an enhanced ESG reporting framework that integrates the concept of double materiality by embedding community resilience initiatives into corporate sustainability strategies. Given the fragmented regulatory landscape in Ghana, the paper proposes a comprehensive National ESG Compliance Framework to harmonize institutional mandates and align corporate operations with national climate goals and global ESG standards.

title: Probabilistic Shift-Share Analysis of World Industrial Patterns, 1995-2019

detail.title: Probabilistic Shift-Share Analysis of World Industrial Patterns, 1995-2019
detail.abstract:
This paper revisits Shift-Share and Constant Market Share Analysis by introducing a maximum entropy prior to replace ad hoc weighting schemes, assuming a uniform distribution of sectors. The resulting decomposition is additive and exact over discrete time periods, eliminating the need for a residual term. Both composition and competitiveness effects are derived from deviations relative to neutral expected growth.

Applying the method to global manufacturing data (1995–2019) for 76 countries at current and constant prices, the analysis distinguishes developed and developing countries trajectories. Adjustments for home bias and demand structure deepen the insight. Compared with traditional approaches, this probabilistic SSA confirms competitiveness as the main driver of industrial growth, with methodological implications for structural analysis and policy.

title: Super-Dicta

detail.title: Super-Dicta

publicationDetails.detailsText: Fordham Law Legal Studies Research Paper Forthcoming
publicationDetails.journalName: Fordham Law School Legal Studies Research Paper Series

detail.abstract:
A weird thing happens when a conscientious, rational judge lacks certainty and has the humility to know it: she will often decide cases for reasons that differ from the reasons in her opinions. To illustrate, suppose she thinks it’s 50/50 whether Defendant’s copying infringed or was fair use. She could rationally flip a coin. But if she does, and she finds for Defendant, it will not be because of fair use. Rather, it will be because she thought it was 50/50 whether the copying was fair use—and the coin landed tails.

Coin-flip cases are rare, but uncertainty is not. There are more sophisticated tools for responding rationally when the judge’s doubts about what she ought to do are not in complete equipoise. And so, the point remains: when a judge is uncertain about what she ought to do and is rational in pursuit of that aim, the actual reason for her decision and the ratio decidendi will diverge. And unlike much of the literature arguing we cannot take opinions at face value, the phenomenon I describe arises from anti-cynical premises: a judge who aims at what is right. 

I call the judge’s actual reasoning “Super-Dicta.” Super-Dicta is so-called because it is super important: it is directly necessary to the decision—and not just causally, but as part of a judge’s rationale. But even though it is the decisive reasoning, it would appear to have the status of dicta: whether expressed, or not, Super-Dicta is not purely objective, limited to law or facts. It encompasses the judge’s subjective reasoning based on her uncertainty. That is, it is reasoning that resolves a case that is hard for the judge, not just hard. 

Should Super-Dicta appear in an opinion? That normative question is probably moot, at least if understood as one of substantive jurisprudence. While a coin flip may be rational, disclosing it is not. Accordingly, a judge responding rationally to uncertainty will not disclose that in her opinion. And if she tries, the resulting legal standard would turn on an odd consideration: facts about the judge, namely, that she is uncertain and the extent of her doubts. The result: judicial opinions—at least those by mere mortals—can be transparent or objective, but not both. So-called “hard case” doctrines must be revisited in this light.

title: Does ESG Performance Hinder Product Innovation?
affiliations: FGV EAESP - Sao Paulo School of Business Administration, University of Liverpool - Management School (ULMS) and Northeastern University - D'Amore-McKim School of Business

detail.title: Does ESG Performance Hinder Product Innovation?
detail.abstract: As more firms embrace sustainability goals, a critical question emerges: does ESG hurt product innovation? Drawing on the attention-based view of the firm, we argue that while ESG performance requires significant managerial attention, potentially crowding out focus on product innovation. We test our framework using a panel of 457 publicly listed U.S. firms over 15 years (2007-2021), comprising 19,340 firm-quarter observations. We find that ESG performance is negatively associated with product innovation and that this relationship depends on three contextual factors. R&D intensity enables better capability alignment mitigating the negative association. Firms that face intense competition are better equipped to innovate due to external pressures to differentiate their products. In contrast, high ROA that carries more resource slack implies that firms may become more risk-averse, reinforcing the negative effect. Our findings shed light on the hidden and unintended consequences of ESG performance and offer guidance on how firms can align purpose with innovation ambition.
