detail.abstract: Background: Brazilian Butt Lift (BBL) popularity has collided with mounting safety headlines, yet the degree to which safety sentiment changes consumer interest remains unclear. Methods: Google Keyword Planner search-volume data for six metros (Los Angeles, Houston, Miami, Dallas, Atlanta, New York City) were collected for June 2024-May 2025. Two keyword groups were compared: "Core-BBL" (e.g., "bbl surgery," "brazilian butt lift cost") and "Safety-BBL" (e.g., "safe bbl," "bbl death," "bbl risks"). YoY change and the Safety/Core ratio were calculated. Results: Overall BBL search interest declined 6.1 % YoY, but Safety-BBL queries rose +18.4 %. Miami and Los Angeles showed the largest Safety/Core ratios (0.37 and 0.34), while Dallas and Atlanta remained lowest (0.17 and 0.15). A spike in Safety-BBL searches (+42 %) followed a March 2025 national news cycle on BBL fatalities. Conclusion: Rising safety-related keyword share-especially in legacy BBL markets-indicates growing consumer risk awareness. Clinics should address safety FAQs and accreditation transparently in marketing content.

title: How Does Artificial Intelligence Affect Firms' Green Total Factor Productivity: Evidence from Chinese Listed Companies
affiliations: Guangxi University and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: How Does Artificial Intelligence Affect Firms' Green Total Factor Productivity: Evidence from Chinese Listed Companies
detail.abstract: In the context of rapid artificial intelligence (AI) development, the mechanisms by which AI application affects green productivity (GTFP) within firms remain unclear. This paper conducts an empirical study on the relationship between the application level of artificial intelligence and green total factor productivity of Chinese listed companies from 2007 to 2022, yielding the following conclusions. (1)There is an inverted U-shaped relationship between AI application levels and firms' GTFP, which remains robust after a series of robustness checks. (2)Regarding the mediating effect, AI promotes the green transformation of firm management, thereby enhancing green productivity; however, as the degree of AI application deepens, the efficiency of green technology research and development will decrease, which will hinder the continuous improvement of green total factor productivity. (3)In terms of the moderating effect, the talent aggregation in the firm's region and higher levels of corporate governance weaken the inverted U-shaped relationship between AI and GTFP, making the relationship curve flatter. (4)Concerning heterogeneity, the inverted U-shaped relationship is more pronounced in firms with high environmental regulation, high emissions, and high financing constraints. Corporate governance exerts a better moderating effect in firms with low environmental regulation, low emissions, and low financing constraints; whereas regional talent aggregation plays a more significant moderating role in firms with high environmental regulation, high emissions, and low financing constraints. (5)Through a macro-level mapping analysis of firms' AI applications, it is found that the inverted U-shaped relationship between AI and GTFP can better explain the two distinct mechanisms at the regional level, rooted in differences in regional factor mobility and inter-firm connectivity.

title: Reduced Tillage and Cover Crop Effects on Soil Moisture and Infiltration
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, Mississippi State University, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Mississippi State University, Cotton Incorporated, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Reduced Tillage and Cover Crop Effects on Soil Moisture and Infiltration
detail.abstract: Cropping systems that conserve soil moisture are needed to improve yield or reduce irrigation water demand. This study assessed the ability of different tillage systems, subsoiling, and cover crops to conserve soil moisture, reduce soil water depletion, and augment infiltration in cotton (Gossypium hirsutum L.) production on a Dubbs silt loam (Typic Hapludalfs) and a Bosket very fine sandy loam (Mollic Hapludalfs). Conventionally tilled soils had ≥59% lower soil matric potential (less moisture; P>F = 5.41×10−8) than conservation practices before irrigation. Cover crops increased soil moisture (-20 kPa) compared to winter fallow (-34 kPa). All conservation practices improved season-long soil moisture by ≥-19 kPa over conventional tillage (P>F = 3.8×10−12). Each Mg ha−1 increase in preplant biomass raised soil matric potential by ≥7.3 kPa. Irrigation at -80 kPa to replenish soil moisture did not alter treatment differences. The conventional method (control) required irrigation every year with up to 7.81cm more supplemental irrigation than the studied conservation practices. Cover crop treatments did not require irrigation at least 2 out of the 3 seasons in the experiment. Cost savings from reduced irrigation of up to $18 ha-1 do not fully compensate for crop yield penalties. Infiltration rates on bed tops increased by 23% with cover crops (P>F = 0.0627). Cover crops and subsoiling enhanced infiltrated rainfall by 13% (P>F = 0.003) and 16% (P>F = 0.009), respectively, compared to winter fallow. Reduced tillage and cover crops improve season-long soil moisture and infiltration, offering a viable strategy for conserving irrigation water.

title: First Fired, Last Hired, and Lower Paid : Re-Employment Outcomes among Displaced Workers with Disabilities, 2007-2021
affiliations: University of Alberta - Department of Sociology and University of Toronto

detail.title: First Fired, Last Hired, and Lower Paid : Re-Employment Outcomes among Displaced Workers with Disabilities, 2007-2021
detail.abstract: People with disabilities continue to face significant barriers in the labor market. They are also more likely to experience job displacement, involuntary job loss typically resulting from broader exogenous forces (e.g., automation, economic downturns) that make workers no longer needed. What happens to displaced workers with disabilities? Do they find new jobs, and if they do, what jobs are they? We study re-employment outcomes among displaced workers with disabilities using data from the 2010, 2012, 2014, 2018, 2020, and 2022 waves of the Current Population Survey Displaced Worker Supplement. We find that in addition to higher rates of displacement, workers with disabilities took longer to be re-employed than workers without disabilities with a decreased hazard for re-employment of about 30%. For those who found new jobs, earnings losses upon re-employment were 18% greater for people with disabilities when compared to those without disabilities. Although the relationship between disability and time-to-re-employment did not vary significantly over time, earnings differences between people with and without disabilities were smaller during the pandemic.

title: Variable Annuity Portfolio Valuation with Shapley Additive Explanations
affiliations: University of New South Wales (UNSW), University of New South Wales (UNSW), University of New South Wales (UNSW) - ARC Centre of Excellence in Population Ageing Research (CEPAR) and University of New South Wales; ARC Centre of Excellence in Population Ageing Research and School of Risk & Actuarial Studies

detail.title: Variable Annuity Portfolio Valuation with Shapley Additive Explanations
detail.abstract: This paper proposes a new metamodeling framework for valuing variable annuity (VA) portfolios that utilizes SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP) to select a representative sample in an explainable manner. When applying metamodeling techniques to principle-based VA portfolio valuation, selecting a representative sample with clear and explainable criteria is necessary. The proposed approach involves (i) training a surrogate neural network with existing valuations for the same portfolio across multiple market scenarios and (ii) decomposing the overall risk of a VA contract into clearly separated contributions from each risk driver using SHapley Additive exPlanations. This decomposition results in an informative and explainable representation of the VA contract data, which can later be used to select the representative sample under a new market scenario. Furthermore, by fine-tuning the surrogate neural network with the selected representative sample, the proposed method offers a systematic way to improve the neural network’s performance in the new market scenario. Our numerical analyses show that the proposed method outperforms conventional methods in the existing literature in prediction accuracy and goodness of fit.

title: The Green Premium Puzzle: Empirical Evidence from Climate-friendly Food Products
affiliations: Faculty of Economics, Chulalongkorn University, Chulalongkorn University, Chulalongkorn University and Chulalongkorn University

detail.title: The Green Premium Puzzle: Empirical Evidence from Climate-friendly Food Products

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.
declarations.funderStatement: This Quick Win research project is supported by Ratchadapiseksompotch Fund Chulalongkorn University.

detail.abstract: This paper investigates whether climate-friendly food products command a price premium in consumer markets. Using product-level data from a supermarket in Sweden, we examine the relationship between front-of-package climate impact scores and retail prices, controlling for product size, nutritional content, and fixed effects. Contrary to the intuitive expectation of a positive green premium, we find no evidence that climate-friendly products are priced higher. In some product categories, products with better climate scores are in fact associated with lower prices, suggesting a negative premium-an outcome that gives rise to what we refer to as the green premium puzzle. We argue that market frictions-such as competing consumer priorities, psychological distance from climate issues, and skepticism toward environmental labeling-may suppress the price signals intended to reward sustainable consumption. These findings offer important insights for producers, retailers, and policymakers seeking to align climate goals with effective market incentives in the transition toward a more sustainable society.

title: The Indus Divide: River Geopolitics, Water Wars, Human Cost
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: The Indus Divide: River Geopolitics, Water Wars, Human Cost
detail.abstract:
This book, "The Indus Divide," offers a comprehensive analysis of the escalating water conflict between India and Pakistan, centered on the Indus River. The narrative originates with the historic 1960 Indus Waters Treaty, a World Bank-brokered agreement that apportioned the river's waters and has, for decades, served as a fragile instrument of peace. The text examines the treaty's initial success and the subsequent erosion of its authority, citing the contentious development of dams such as Kishanganga and Baglihar as key points of friction.

A significant portion of the work is dedicated to a detailed examination of a hypothetical 2025 crisis, triggered by a terror attack in Pahalgam, which leads to India's suspension of the treaty. This event precipitates a rapid escalation of military and diplomatic tensions. The book meticulously explores the practical implications of India's strategy to control the water flow, presenting a technical assessment of its existing dam infrastructure and its limited capacity for substantial water storage.

Furthermore, the study delves into the profound humanitarian and economic consequences for Pakistan, a nation where the Indus system sustains over 90% of its agriculture and supports 40% of its workforce. The potential for severe food shortages, widespread blackouts, and famine is critically assessed. The analysis is compounded by the looming threat of climate change, which introduces greater unpredictability through extreme flooding and drought cycles.

Distinct from conventional political histories of the India-Pakistan conflict, this book integrates historical context with rigorous technical and economic data. It provides a nuanced, balanced perspective that scrutinizes the feasibility of unilateral actions and their far-reaching impacts. Concluding with a forward-looking approach, the book proposes a range of solutions, including the renegotiation of the treaty, the implementation of more efficient water management practices, and the fostering of bilateral cooperation. This work is intended for policymakers, scholars, and a general audience seeking a deeply informed, multifaceted understanding of one of the world's most critical water disputes.

title: The Heterogeneous Effects of Historical Mission Exposure and Indigenous Development
affiliations: George Mason University - Department of Economics

detail.title: The Heterogeneous Effects of Historical Mission Exposure and Indigenous Development
detail.abstract: The colonization of the New World was heavily intertwined with the Catholicization of the Americas. This paper seeks to understand the interactions between Native Americans and the missionaries, and what long run effects the missions may have had. Using historical census data and records on missionary-indigenous encounters, I test the long-run economic effects of historical exposure to Catholicism by employing an instrumental variable strategy. I then test the human capital mechanism from previous literature. I then propose that heterogeneous effects may not be driven by Catholic orders, but by the imperial power that employs the missionaries. My paper shows that wider imperial institutions may be interacting with local conditions or second-order institutional effects. The violent strategies of the Spanish and the diplomatic ways of the French change the growth of indigenous populations in America.

title: From Wallets to Wall Street: Behavioral Shifts and the Financialization of Bitcoin
affiliations: Southern illinois university carbondale

detail.title: From Wallets to Wall Street: Behavioral Shifts and the Financialization of Bitcoin
detail.abstract: This paper examines how the launch of spot Bitcoin ETFs has reshaped individual engagement with the Bitcoin ecosystem. Using ETF flow data, blockchain wallet metrics, and proxies for investor attention, I show that cumulative ETF flows crowd out direct on-chain activity, indicating a shift away from decentralized participation. The introduction of the ETF is associated with wider bid-ask spreads, particularly during periods of heightened volatility. Leveraging an instrumental variables approach with lagged attention, I find that flows exert downward pressure on Bitcoin price levels. While longer-window volatility discourages wallet usage, this effect is partially offset when user interest is elevated. The findings suggest that financialization diminishes user-driven engagement and alters the structure of cryptocurrency markets.

title: Green Finance Development in Russian Financial and Corporate Sectors
affiliations: Hokkaido University

detail.title: Green Finance Development in Russian Financial and Corporate Sectors
detail.abstract: This study aims to shed light on the current state and overall structure of Russia’s green finance market by examining corporate capital structures through the lens of "green" initiatives and by analysing the institutional developments surrounding green finance. Russia's green finance market has taken shape only in recent years. In August 2019, the Moscow Exchange introduced a dedicated listing segment for green bonds, prompting a surge in green bond issuances by Russian corporations and financial institutions. Moreover, the Bank of Russia’s easing of capital requirements in 2022—specifically in relation to green assets—as well as Sberbank’s reduction of lending rates for green loans, have further contributed to the advancement of the country’s green finance sector. Nevertheless, existing research on Russia’s financial markets has predominantly focused on themes such as the relationship between resource prices and interest/exchange rates, the transmission mechanisms of monetary policy, and the structural features of a bank-centred financial system. As green finance—including green bonds and green loans—remains a relatively novel area of inquiry, and given that the formation and development of this market in Russia has only occurred over the past few years, academic studies in this field remain scarce, and even a comprehensive mapping of the market has yet to be undertaken. Accordingly, this paper seeks to provide a systematic overview of Russia’s green finance market by delving into financial sector and corporate capital actions from a green finance perspective and by assessing the country’s institutional development in this area. This study adopts both quantitative and qualitative approaches to examine Russia’s green finance landscape. By focusing on "green" as an analytical entry point—one largely absent from prior research—and by conducting a comprehensive analysis that goes beyond case studies of individual firms to include the behaviour of other market participants and the broader institutional context, this research contributes a novel perspective to the study of the Russian economy and financial markets.

title: The (Shifting) Audience of Energy Law
affiliations: King’s College London

detail.title: The (Shifting) Audience of Energy Law
detail.abstract: Our energy system is undergoing key shifts. These shifts have profound implications for energy Law and Governance. The Article underscores one facet of the shift, by applying the concept of audience. The term 'audience' of law refers, broadly, to all the individuals, companies, institutions, and other actors for whom the law is intended or whose actions the law seeks to influence. The Article shows how a shift in the audience of energy law is underway and underscores the implications of that shift for energy law-making and institutional design.

title: Kernel Learning for Mean-Variance Trading Strategies
affiliations: Imperial College London - Department of Mathematics, Imperial College London and Mathematical Institute, University of Oxford and Oxford Man Institute

detail.title: Kernel Learning for Mean-Variance Trading Strategies
detail.abstract: In this article, we develop a kernel-based framework for constructing dynamic, pathdependent trading strategies under a mean-variance optimisation criterion. Building on the theoretical results of (Muca Cirone and Salvi, 2025), we parameterise trading strategies as functions in a reproducing kernel Hilbert space (RKHS), enabling a flexible and non-Markovian approach to optimal portfolio problems. We compare this with the signature-based framework of (Futter, Horvath, Wiese, 2023) and demonstrate that both significantly outperform classical Markovian methods when the asset dynamics or predictive signals exhibit temporal dependencies for both synthetic and market-data examples. Using kernels in this context provides significant modelling flexibility, as the choice of feature embedding can range from randomised signatures to the final layers of neural network architectures. Crucially, our framework retains closed-form solutions and provides an alternative to gradient-based optimisation.

title: Predictive Zonal Heating with Machine Learning: A ChatGPT-Based Model for Simulating Resident Behaviour in Smart HVAC Systems
affiliations: University of Oxford - Department of Engineering Science, State University of New York (SUNY) - University at Buffalo and University of Oxford - Department of Engineering Science

detail.title: Predictive Zonal Heating with Machine Learning: A ChatGPT-Based Model for Simulating Resident Behaviour in Smart HVAC Systems
detail.abstract: Efficient and adaptive residential climate control remains a critical challenge in the context of rising energy costs and increasing sustainability requirements. This study introduces an AI-driven predictive zonal heating model that utilizes synthetic occupant behavioral data generated by ChatGPT to optimize room-level heating. The model achieves next-state prediction accuracies of 64.68% for single occupant households and 73.20% for family households. TRNSYS-based simulations conducted for ten cities across Europe and the United States indicate that heating demand varies significantly with building material, with timber constructions exhibiting the lowest energy consumption and stone constructions the highest. A comparative evaluation of three HVAC strategies, including traditional continuous heating (BAU), manual smart control (S1), and the proposed AI-based zoning system (S2), shows that S2 reduces energy consumption by up to 73.16% for single-occupant households and 46.35% for family households relative to BAU. Compared with S1, S2 delivers additional savings of 40.83% to 67.63% for single occupants and 15.02% to 22.15% for families. Over a four-week simulation, single-occupant households achieved weekly energy cost savings of 29.71 to 72.49 USD and carbon emission reductions of 1.64 to 80.23 kg CO₂, while family households achieved savings of 30.05 to 80.38 USD and reductions of 1.73 to 74.38 kg CO₂. These results demonstrate the potential of AI-enabled zonal heating to significantly improve energy efficiency, mitigate environmental impact, and enhance occupant comfort without manual intervention.

title: Economic Relationship Between Team Success and Financial Investments Within NCAA Basketball Teams in the Big East Conference
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: Economic Relationship Between Team Success and Financial Investments Within NCAA Basketball Teams in the Big East Conference

declarations.declarationOfInterest: Over the past several decades, the National Collegiate Athletics Association, also referred to as NCAA, has evolved into a multibillion-dollar industry and one of the most popular and widely viewed sports organizations. Basketball, in particular, has seen a spike in attention from fans, media, and stakeholders and has emerged as one of the most popular, revenue-generating sports. This increase in value of the industry made me wonder and want to explore if the money allocated to teams’ in the NCAA had an effect on their performance.
declarations.ethicsApproval: It is important to note that regarding the ethical considerations, the study and all subsequent material have been approved by an informal school-based IRB.

detail.abstract: This research examines the relationship between economic factors and athletic success among NCAA Division 1 men's basketball teams, specifically focusing on the Big East Conference. While previous studies have broadly analyzed general correlations between financial resources and athletic success, this research narrows the scope to assess how specific factors-including but not limited to NIL (Name, Image, and Likeness) funding, ticket revenue, return on investment, and revenue-relate to team winning percentages. The research question is: What are the winning percentages of college basketball teams in the Big East Conference, in relation to their economics (tax dollars paid, tuition, or revenue made from sports events)? This topic is especially relevant as NIL policies and changing revenue structures are reshaping college athletics. To answer this question, a correlational research design and quantitative method were used to conduct the research by gathering economic data and analyzing the relationship between financial investment and winning percentages. The findings suggest that while general financial investment does not guarantee higher winning percentages, targeted spending-particularly in areas like NIL deals and athletic-specific contributions-has a stronger correlation with success. These results are important because they can help athletic directors, administrators, and policymakers optimize both team success and economic gain by understanding the key factors that contribute to performance.

title: Does FinTech Foster Financial Access and Usage? Evidence from Select Major Economies
affiliations: Reserve Bank of India and Reserve Bank of India

detail.title: Does FinTech Foster Financial Access and Usage? Evidence from Select Major Economies
detail.abstract: Exponential growth of FinTech over the past decade makes policymakers ponder if it enhances financial access and usage. We analyze this linkage across 33 major developed and developing nations, for 2014, 2017 and 2021, using static panel model with wild bootstrap. While in the developed nations, FinTech positively influences financial access but has insignificant impact on financial usage, in the developing nations, FinTech is insignificant on both financial access and usage. Results remain robust across different choice of response variables, model specifications and estimation procedures. Interestingly, FinTech penetration level plays significant moderating impact in this nexus as positive influence is noted in countries of higher FinTech penetration (major advanced economies as well as India, China, Brazil and Indonesia), while other countries show insignificant impact.

title: Firm Relocation: Its Heterogeneous Effects on Photovoltaic Development in China
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Xi’an University of Science and Technology

detail.title: Firm Relocation: Its Heterogeneous Effects on Photovoltaic Development in China
detail.abstract: Understanding the impact of firm relocation on photovoltaic (PV) development is critically important for informed policymaking. This study utilizes spatial econometric models and multiple mediation analysis to examine the dynamic and spatial impacts of firm relocation across four strategic industries—renewable energy, advanced materials, information technology (IT), and equipment manufacturing—on photovoltaic installed capacity (PIC) and photovoltaic utilization rate (PUR) in 30 Chinese provinces from 2016 to 2023.Results reveal that the inflow of renewable energy firms significantly increases PIC in destination regions, although the effect exhibits diminishing marginal returns. Conversely, the outflow of renewable energy firms positively influences PUR in origin regions. The outflow of advanced materials firms boosts PIC not only locally but also in adjacent provinces. The relocation effects of equipment manufacturing firms—both inflows and outflows—mirror those observed in the renewable energy sector, underscoring the strong interdependence between these two industries. The inflow of IT firms not only enhances local PUR but also produces significant spatial spillover effects, raising PUR in neighboring provinces. This effect is particularly pronounced in western provinces participating in the “Eastern Data, Western Computing” initiative, highlighting the electricity-intensive characteristics of high-energy-demand industries.

title: The Latinos of New York: New Immigrants Maintaining the City
affiliations: American University

detail.title: The Latinos of New York: New Immigrants Maintaining the City
detail.abstract: This paper concerns both immigrants to New York City from Latin America and the Spanish-speaking Caribbean, Latinos born in the city who move away, as well as those born in other parts of the country who move into the city. It describes the role of Latino migrants in New York’s local culture, with a particular emphasis on the contributions of Latinos to the city’s population and economic growth. Despite their significant role in New York City’s metropolitan area, popular discussions of New York rarely take Latinos into account. New York's Latin population is comprised of diverse national origins, with major populations from Puerto Rico, the Dominican Republic, Mexico, Central America, and South America. The city has played a crucial role in creating, defining, redefining, and broadcasting Latinidad to the East Coast and the broader United States. How second-generation and third-generation Latinos fare in the city will deeply shape the future of both the city and the country. Along with Asians and Africans, people with origins in Latin America and the Caribbean have taken a similar role to that played in the past by Irish, Italian, and Eastern European Jewish immigrants. These newer immigrants from Latin America and elsewhere are simultaneously remaking and reproducing the culture and social fabric of New York. Maintaining the city as a hub for business and innovation and a magnet for people (including other Latinos) from across the country and around the world.

title: With a Little Help from My Friends: Mortgage Lending Around Us Elections
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: With a Little Help from My Friends: Mortgage Lending Around Us Elections
detail.abstract: We examine how banks strategically adjust credit allocation according to US electoral cycles. Banks with political access increase their mortgage portfolio by US$43 billion, particularly in districts with moderately contested elections. However, the level of mortgages does not change in districts with tight elections or districts where candidates sweep the vote. Banks also prefer to expand credit in districts where prevalent characteristics (reelecting incumbents, majority demographics, brand new house-buying mortgage applications) tend to define the elections. Our results emphasise political access as a critical factor for banks’ market value and the importance of authorities monitoring politically connected banks.

title: Migration, Urbanization, and Inclusion
affiliations: American University, Universitat Pompeu Fabra (UPF) and University of Hartford

detail.title: Migration, Urbanization, and Inclusion
detail.abstract:
Cities and migration are deeply intertwined. In this paper, we provide a longue-durée global overview of the connection between the social processes of migration and urbanization. It draws on publications from multiple disciplines. It puts contemporary discussions about migrants arriving in cities into a wide perspective and historical context. Despite panicking statements in the media, immigration is a process as old as cities themselves. The takeaway is that one
cannot have healthy cities without continuous immigration. We touch upon the relationship between migration and urbanization throughout history and provide some case studies from around the world. We discuss cities as creators of a common culture and identity while acting as factories of race/ethnicity markers by creating social boundaries that exclude certain newcomers and established dwellers while including most others.

title: Excluded at the Edges: Urban Peripheries and the Stigmatization of Space in France
affiliations: American University

detail.title: Excluded at the Edges: Urban Peripheries and the Stigmatization of Space in France
detail.abstract:
This paper is based on ten months of non-participant observation, in-depth interviews, and surveys with immigrants and natives in the Paris metropolitan
area. Despite popular representations of spatial closure, Parisian banlieues are places where social and cultural boundaries are created and crossed by actual
contact between different social groups. Although the paper focuses on Paris, the issues discussed are relevant to all urban spaces where diverse populations
come into contact. The paper challenges the view that ghettos, barrios, or banlieues are self-contained spatial social units or closed-off systems. While these areas are indeed spatial containers of social stigma and exclusion, there is continuous interaction amongst immigrants, students, working-class people, middle-class professionals, and visible minorities. The social value that these interactions acquire depends on local historical precedents and the larger political context. This paper argues that the notions of “the ghetto” or “the banlieue” can only be fully understood when explicitly seen in relation to the spaces that surround them, exemplifying the relational nature of the core/periphery relationship.

title: Decentralized Insurance Mechanisms: A Game-Theoretic Model for Risk Distribution in Blockchain Ecosystems
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Decentralized Insurance Mechanisms: A Game-Theoretic Model for Risk Distribution in Blockchain Ecosystems
detail.abstract: Through the emergence of Blockchain technology, Decentralized insurance, a Peer to Peer, P2P system that eliminates intermediaries through risk pooling, premium allocation and claim verification is made possible with the help of smart contracts. In this paper, we propose a game theoretic framework for analyzing decentralized insurance ecosystems with respect to risk distribution efficiency and participant incentives in trustless environments. We employ Nash equilibrium and utility maximization principles to derive optimal premium and payout structures, integrating blockchain’s transparency and immutability as key enablers. A numerical simulation with 100 agents across 1,000 iterations reveals that decentralized insurance achieves up to 20% higher efficiency than centralized models, with reduced adverse selection and administrative costs. Sensitivity analyses explore the impact of risk heterogeneity, reputation scores, and blockchain transaction costs on system performance. The results highlight significant advantages in equity and cost-effectiveness but underscore challenges such as scalability, governance, and moral hazard. Theoretical contributions include a novel application of cooperative and non-cooperative game theory to Insurtech, while practical implications suggest pathways for integrating decentralized insurance into regulatory frameworks and blockchain platforms. This study bridges gaps in the literature on decentralized finance (DeFi) and insurance economics, offering a robust foundation for future empirical validations. We conclude with recommendations for hybrid models combining centralized oversight with decentralized execution, addressing limitations in current blockchain infrastructure.

title: Climate Change Risk and Financial Stability in BRICS Countries: The Moderating Role of Climate Finance
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Climate Change Risk and Financial Stability in BRICS Countries: The Moderating Role of Climate Finance
detail.abstract: This study examines the nexus between climate change financial stability in BRICS nations (Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa) with reference to the moderating role of climate finance. Utilizing a dynamic panel (GMM) approach in the estimation over the period 2000 to 2023, the paper examines the direct impact of CO₂ emissions on the 3 key aspects of financial stability. FDI, FVI and, FSI. The results show that CO₂ emission has a negative impact on financial development, no significant effect on financial vulnerability, and an unanticipated positive association with financial soundness indicating the possibility of short-run industrial benefits at the cost of long-run risk. Additionally, climate finance substantially mitigates the negative impact of emissions on financial development and does not show a moderation impact on vulnerability and soundness measures. The lack of Russian climate finance data and low participation in global climate finance-related action present an important constraint of the generalizability of the moderation effects. Results highlight the need to strengthen the climate finance architecture and institutional engagement to support sustainable financial resilience in emerging countries. This paper is one of the first attempts in the literature to combine the environmental and financial aspects in one empirical framework, and it provides some significant policy implications with respect to climate adaptation and financial governance in the Global South.

title: Wildfires and Financial Markets: High-Frequency Evidence from U.S. Stock Indices
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, Tunis El Manar University, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Prince Sultan University - College of Business Administration

detail.title: Wildfires and Financial Markets: High-Frequency Evidence from U.S. Stock Indices
detail.abstract: This study examines short-term financial impact of the California wildfires on major U.S. stock indices, using 5-minute  data. Employing Wavelet Quantile Correlation and Frequency Quantile Vector Autoregression, we analyze volatility spillovers and interconnectedness. We reveal an immediate volatility surge, with VIX exhibiting strong negative co-movements with stocks, reinforcing its role as  risk barometer. Short-term spillovers exceeded long-term effects, driven by panic-driven trading and liquidity. NASDAQ and Russell 3000 saw sharper declines. As the crisis unfolded, systemic risk stabilized, with sectoral responses diverging over time. We highlight the importance risk monitoring, trading strategies, and regulatory safeguards in mitigating climate-induced financial disruptions.

title: Family-Propelled Migration and the Appearance of Social Networks
affiliations: American University and University of Pennsylvania

detail.title: Family-Propelled Migration and the Appearance of Social Networks
detail.abstract: This chapter discusses several ideas about social networks and family-propelled migration. It engages the author’s recent work on family separation and reunification of youth migrants, as well as new findings from a project about refugee resettlement. The chapter combines various literatures about the causes and consequences of migration to show how family-propelled migration operates as a useful and generative concept when attempting to understand the complex dynamics of migration today. It concludes with a multi-tiered explanation of how community integration is helped or hindered, and broad policy analysis with suggestions for how societies can help migrant families integrate into their communities.

title: Public Choice Theory and Law

detail.title: Public Choice Theory and Law

publicationDetails.journalName: Antonin Scalia Law School, George Mason University, Law & Economics Research Paper Series

publicationDetails.detailsText: Entry In Elgar Concise Encyclopedia Of Legal Theory And Philosophy (Forthcoming)

detail.abstract: Public choice theory applies economic principles—especially rational self-interest, incentive structures, and methodological individualism—to the study of political and legal institutions. While traditionally used to explain legislative and regulatory behavior, this entry explores how public choice insights apply more broadly across the legal landscape. Concepts such as concentrated benefits and dispersed costs, rational ignorance, and rent-seeking help explain how legal actors—judges, litigants, bureaucrats, and interest groups—interact within institutional constraints. The entry examines how these dynamics shape the evolution of litigation, the behavior of administrative agencies, and even constitutional change. By grounding legal processes in the same incentive-driven analysis used in economics, public choice theory offers a powerful explanatory framework for why legal outcomes often diverge from publicly stated goals.

detail.title: 팬데믹 이후 국제사회의 불평등 현황과 한국의 개발 협력 과제(Post-Pandemic Inequality in Education and Its Implications on Korea’s Development Cooperation)

publicationDetails.journalName: Korea Institute for International Economic Policy (KIEP) Research Paper Series

detail.abstract: The persistent global inequality crisis has long been a critical social issue due to its substantial economic and social cost. Despite continuous international efforts to mitigate inequality, the issue remains severe. The outbreak of COVID-19 and associated lockdown measures have further exacerbated inequality in various forms, including poverty rates, gender-based labor gaps, and educational gaps. Moreover, global inequality is expected to intensify further due to multiple post-pandemic crises like inflation, climate change, and conflicts.

title: Transportation Infrastructure, Market Access, and Deforestation
affiliations: San Diego State University, Gordon S Lang School of Business and Economics, University of Guelph, Guelph, Canada and University of Toronto

detail.title: Transportation Infrastructure, Market Access, and Deforestation
detail.abstract: We study the impacts of transportation infrastructure improvements on forest loss in Uganda between 2008 and 2021, leveraging a large-scale national road upgrade program. We combine high-resolution panel data on deforestation with changes in travel times to major markets resulting from road improvements. Exploiting quasi-random variation in the timing of project completion to isolate unanticipated market access shocks, we find that improved market access led to increased local forest loss. These effects are not driven by agriculture, mining, or construction. Instead, deforestation is driven by rural charcoal producers who clear trees to supply high-price urban markets. Our results highlight the important role that natural resource access and forest-product price differentials can play in shaping the general equilibrium effects of transportation infrastructure investments.

title: Rights Architecture For Legal Organizations
affiliations: The University of Alabama School of Law

detail.title: Rights Architecture For Legal Organizations
detail.abstract:
Corporate law cannot provide coherent answers to its most basic questions. Courts struggle to explain what rights shareholders possess, what duties directors owe, and whose authority controls when shareholders and management disagree. When directors routinely refuse shareholder demands in operational decisions or governance disputes, legal theory and doctrine offer confused metaphors about “ownership” and “control” rather than analytical precision about rights and duties.

This doctrinal crisis reflects a deeper theoretical failure. Legal relations involving multiple parties within organizational structures operate beyond the analytical boundaries that our existing individual-focused rights theory has established. From corporate governance disputes to partnership conflicts, from international organizations to trust administration, the law lacks the theoretical framework necessary to describe how rights function when groups act collectively.

This Article proposes a theoretical framework to fill this void by using corporate law as a case study. The central discovery is that aggregate legal relations require new conceptions of rights that defy traditional bilateral arrangements.

When directors manage corporate assets, they owe compound duties to the corporation that legally require consideration of shareholder interests without making shareholders the primary rightsholders. Shareholders correspondingly possess participatory rights—not rights that would enable outcome control, but legally protected interests in the decision-making process, which otherwise serves the corporation as the primary rightsholder. The shareholders enjoy participatory privileges to actively engage in the governance of the firm, while customers, employees, and other third parties have participatory no-rights to legally interfere with that freedom. 

The policy implications of the participatory rights architecture are broad and impactful. Using corporate law as a test case for the proposed theory’s normative value, the Article demonstrates how one can resolve corporate law’s most persistent puzzles by applying this theory. The notorious direct-derivative lawsuit distinction becomes straightforward: derivative suits enforce corporate rights, and direct suits enforce shareholder traditional and participatory rights. The perplexing doctrines of controlling shareholder obligations become the systematic conversion of participatory privileges into compound duties. The boundaries of corporate limited liability are drawn by references to the rights structures that shareholders assume.

This Article thus provides both theoretical breakthrough and doctrinal transformation, offering the tools necessary to understand how rights operate in corporate law specifically, and laws of legal organizations more broadly.

title: The Texas Employment Mirage: Statistical Artifacts, Fiscal Transfers, and the Political Economy of Regional Development Claims
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: The Texas Employment Mirage: Statistical Artifacts, Fiscal Transfers, and the Political Economy of Regional Development Claims
detail.abstract: This study challenges the empirical foundations of the widely-cited "Texas model" of economic development through comprehensive analysis of employment statistics, fiscal transfers, and methodological artifacts that systematically distort measures of genuine economic performance. Drawing on administrative data from the Texas Workforce Commission, Bureau of Labor Statistics surveys, unemployment insurance claims patterns, and comparative interstate fiscal analysis, this research demonstrates that Texas's celebrated employment growth depends critically on factors unrelated to the conservative policy prescriptions commonly attributed as causal mechanisms. The analysis reveals that government hiring accounts for approximately 26% of job gains, net in-migration inflates employment statistics by 25-30%, and seasonal adjustment procedures systematically misrepresent actual labor market conditions. More significantly, supposed fiscal conservatism primarily involves sophisticated cost-shifting mechanisms that transfer employment and service responsibilities from state to local governments, creating efficiency illusions while increasing aggregate tax burdens through property assessments and local fees. These findings suggest that policy prescriptions based on superficial analysis of Texas employment statistics may be built on methodologically questionable foundations, with implications extending beyond Texas to fundamental questions about evidence-based economic policy evaluation in federal systems. The research contributes to understanding how statistical complexity, federal institutional structures, and political incentives interact to create systematic biases in regional economic development assessment.

title: Shared Waters, Diverging Stakes: Towards a Multi-Actor Techno-Economic Assessment for Offshore Wind Decommissioning
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, Ghent University, affiliation not provided to SSRN, University of Antwerp and University of Antwerp - Department of Engineering Management

detail.title: Shared Waters, Diverging Stakes: Towards a Multi-Actor Techno-Economic Assessment for Offshore Wind Decommissioning
detail.abstract: The end-of-life phase of offshore wind farms presents a growing challenge for sustainable energy transitions, as decommissioning remains shaped by substantial technical, economic, and regulatory uncertainty. This study develops a novel Multi-Actor Techno-Economic Assessment (MATEA) framework to evaluate offshore wind decommissioning scenarios, explicitly integrating the diverging interests of wind farm owners and marine contractors. Grounded in a collaborative industry-informed approach, this framework is applied to a Belgian offshore wind case study. Results demonstrate that choices about how to carry out removal, such as vessel selection and dismantling methods, tend to have a greater influence on costs than what must be removed from the seabed. The removal of turbine foundations represents the most expensive process for wind farm owners, while also generating the highest profits for marine contractors, revealing split incentives that may hinder collaborative decision-making. Weather-related delays are identified as the largest source of economic uncertainty for wind farm owners, due to their direct exposure to extended offshore operations. In addition, vessel day rates emerge as a critical cost driver, with limited vessel availability amplifying price-setting power for marine contractors. These findings challenge the prevailing perception that full removal of offshore infrastructure is economically prohibitive and highlight the need for regulatory clarity based on operational and technical realities rather than cost assumptions. The proposed framework provides a transparent basis for evaluating decommissioning strategies, contributing to more robust financial planning, risk management, and sustainable end-of-life practices in offshore renewable energy.

title: Do Limits to Campaign Contribution Laws Affect Welfare Policy? Evidence from the US States
affiliations: East Central University

detail.title: Do Limits to Campaign Contribution Laws Affect Welfare Policy? Evidence from the US States
detail.abstract: How do campaign contribution laws affect welfare policies? The US political system is highly unequal as policy preferences of high-income citizens are often prioritized compared to low-income groups. It is also widely believed that interest groups employ campaign contributions to exercise bargaining power over political candidates. Evidence shows that stricter campaign contribution laws can reduce the bargaining power of interest groups over candidates and increase the say of low-income groups in policy matters. Thus, the effect of stricter contribution laws should also manifest as a shift towards relatively generous welfare policies. This paper analyzes the relationship between stricter campaign contribution laws and welfare policy across the statewide legislative races from 1980 to 2018. The empirical results indicate that stricter contribution laws increase state real minimum wage and EITC rates. The effect of relatively stringent laws on welfare policy generosity is also evident when alternative welfare policy proxies are used.

title: Leveraging Green Opportunities to Harmonize Energy Transition and Ecological Preservation in the GCC Economies
affiliations: Drexel University - Lebow College of Business and Ayandegan Institute of Higher Education

detail.title: Leveraging Green Opportunities to Harmonize Energy Transition and Ecological Preservation in the GCC Economies
detail.abstract: This research investigates the relationship between Renewable Energy Transition (RET) and ecological conditions in the economies of the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC), with a particular focus on the moderating roles of Green Technology Innovation (GTI) and Information and Communication Technology (ICT). To assess the environmental conditions, the study incorporates ecological footprint (EFP) and load capacity factor (LCF) as key indicators. By employing the Common Correlated Effects Mean Group (CCEMG) estimator, alongside the recently developed Method of Moments Quantile Regression (MMQR) approach as a robustness check, the empirical results suggest the following. (i) RET, GTI, and ICT contribute to the improvement of ecological conditions by enhancing LCF and mitigating EFP in the GCC nations. (ii) Population density and natural resources rent lead to environmental pollution by decreasing LCF and increasing EFP. (iii) The validation of the inverted U-shaped Environmental Kuznets Curve (EKC) assumption is evident when it is analyzed from the perspective of EFP, while the U-shaped load capacity curve (LCC) assumption is supported through the framework of LCF. Finally, with gradual advancements in the GTI and ICT sectors, the environmental benefits of RET have become increasingly evident. In light of these findings, policymakers in GCC economies are encouraged to leverage technological innovations and ICT in the energy transition process to improve the ecological conditions and achieve sustainable development goals.

title: Accounting and Fiscal Reporting in EU Countries
affiliations: International Monetary Fund (IMF), Independent and Università degli Studi di Napoli “Parthenope”

detail.title: Accounting and Fiscal Reporting in EU Countries

publicationDetails.journalName: International Monetary Fund (IMF) Research Paper Series

detail.abstract: This Working Paper explores the relationship between the uptake of accrual basis of accounting in government and the use of the resultant accrual information in fiscal statistics, using the European Union (EU) as a case study. The Paper looks at the current state of accounting practices in the general government sector (GGS) of the 27 EU member states. The study of accounting practice is based primarily on two sources that provided a comprehensive picture of government accounting in all the 27 member states, namely the PwC/Eurostat survey of Accounting Maturities of EU Governments and the International Federation of Accountants and the Chartered Institute of Public Finance and Accountancy (IFAC/CIPFA) International Public Sector Financial Accountability Index. The analysis then uses data compiled by Eurostat, the EU statistical office, to explore the extent to which the accrual information is being used in the separate statistical reporting of EU member state public finances. The study draws out some general observations which may be of relevance to all countries during accounting and fiscal reporting reforms.

title: Eradicating the Exceptional: The Role of Territory in Structuring International Legal Thought
affiliations: Edinburgh Law School

detail.title: Eradicating the Exceptional: The Role of Territory in Structuring International Legal Thought
detail.abstract: This paper examines the idea of the sui generis in international law and explores how these exceptions structure international legal thought. Exceptions are useful to international law theorising because they create easy manageable narratives which explain situations not fitting traditional paradigms, yet as a category in their own right-specifically how they are structured and how they operate-, they are often undertheorized. The two examples explored in this article are sui generis actors and the concept of extraterritorial jurisdiction. I demonstrate the foundational role played by (state-)territorialized thinking in the creation of oppositional categories: state and non-state and the non-exceptional and exceptional exercise of jurisdiction. The category of exceptions has significantly expanded from the likes of the Holy See and irregular exercise of extraterritorial jurisdiction to a broad array of actors, such as international organizations and transnational corporations, playing growing and varied roles in contemporary law-making and governance and the regular exercise of extraterritorial jurisdiction by states. Rather than continuing with this overextended category, the article argues it is instead possible, by rethinking international law's spatial imaginary, to first, better understand the spaces of non-state actors and regularized exercise of extraterritorial jurisdiction and second, eradicate the now overstretched legal category of 'sui generis'.

title: Does the ESG Rating Methodology Matter to Investors? Insights from Breadth of Ownership
affiliations: ESADE Business School, Catholic University of Lille - IESEG School of Management and IÉSEG School of Management

detail.title: Does the ESG Rating Methodology Matter to Investors? Insights from Breadth of Ownership

declarations.funderStatement: Ariadna Dumitrescu is thankful for financial support from the Government of Spain FEDER/MICIU–AEI/PID2021-123748NB-I00 and Banc Sabadell.

detail.abstract: This paper studies the impact of the Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) rating methodology on investor decision-making as revealed by the firms' breadth of ownership. We leverage the quasi-experimental setting created in 2010 when MSCI changed their data collection criteria for MSCI-KLD ESG Stats following the acquisition of RiskMetrics Group. This exogenous shock allows us to examine whether firms that experienced an increase or decrease in their ratings solely due to the methodological change also saw significant changes in their breadth of ownership. We find that firms with increased ratings saw a significant rise in the number of individual investors. Further tests show that firms' visibility and stock familiarity are the main drivers of individual investors' reaction. Conversely, the breadth of institutional investors is unaffected by the change in the rating methodology. Our study contributes to the literature by highlighting the critical role of ESG raters in shaping investor behavior and providing insights into the underlying mechanisms.

title: Interpreting Machine Learning Models: A Practical Guide for Applied Economists
affiliations: Middle Tennessee State University

detail.title: Interpreting Machine Learning Models: A Practical Guide for Applied Economists

declarations.ethicsApproval: Paper is written using simulated data. No real subjects.

detail.abstract: This paper provides a practical guide for economists seeking to interpret machine learning models with the same statistical rigor expected in traditional econometric analysis. Using simulated data with known functional relationships, I demonstrate how to identify important features and understand their directional effects using model-agnostic interpretation tools. Three complementary approaches for measuring feature importance are examined: built-in measures, permutation importance, and SHAP-based methods. For understanding directional relationships, I show how partial dependence plots, individual conditional expectation (ICE) plots, and SHAP values with bootstrapped confidence intervals can reveal both average effects and heterogeneity across observations. These tools successfully recover the known nonlinear relationships in the simulated data, including quadratic terms, exponential functions, and interaction effects, without requiring researchers to specify functional forms a priori. The interpretation methods build naturally on familiar econometric concepts such as marginal effects, bootstrapping, and statistical significance testing, making them accessible to applied researchers. Rather than replacing traditional econometric reasoning, these tools extend it, particularly when relationships are nonlinear or unknown. This framework enables economists to harness the predictive power of machine learning while preserving the interpretability and inferential standards central to empirical research.
