detail.abstract: Retirement behavior in the U.S. exhibits two well-documented anomalies: most individuals claim Social Security benefits early, before reaching the full retirement age (FRA), and retirees decumulate assets more slowly than predicted by standard life-cycle models. This paper employs a controlled laboratory experiment to provide clear evidence of these seemingly inconsistent behavioral patterns and offers a behavioral model that provides possible mechanisms. Specifically, we examine behavior in an individual decision-making experiment simulating retirement, where the sole motive for saving is to insure against longevity risk and delaying Social Security claims beyond the FRA is always optimal. In a baseline treatment calibrated to current U.S. Social Security rules, we confirm the early claiming of benefits and slower-than-optimal asset decumulation phenomena. Replacing greater annuities with lump-sum incentives in two alternative treatments works to accelerate asset decumulation but not to delay claiming. These findings are robust across both a student sample and an older sample aged 45-55. We show that a behavioral model with random attention, misperceived continuation probabilities, and noisy signals can account for the observed patterns.

title: Empirical Analysis of the Feasible Solution to Mitigate the CO2 Emission: Evidence from Next-11 Countries
affiliations: Comilla University - Department of Economics and Shandong University - School of Economics

detail.title: Empirical Analysis of the Feasible Solution to Mitigate the CO2 Emission: Evidence from Next-11 Countries
detail.abstract: From the empirical findings, economic growth, energy consumption, fossil fuel use, and infrastructure all have a positive impact on CO 2 emissions. Forest rent and industrialization show a mix of results to explain CO 2 emissions in N-11 countries. Forest and agriculture have negative coefficients in most of the estimations which indicate the reduction of CO 2 emissions in 11 countries. Through the evidence of variance decomposition (VD) analysis, this study found an inverted U-shaped EKC hypothesis in the long run. Moreover, through the econometric analysis, it is clear that forest area is important to reduce CO 2 emissions in N-11 countries, where forest investment and planning would be effective for carbon reduction. Agricultural activities and production with green investment play an important role in mitigating CO 2 emissions in N-11 countries.

title: Mutual Fund Carbon Footprint Around the World
affiliations: University Paris-Saclay - RITM

detail.title: Mutual Fund Carbon Footprint Around the World
detail.abstract: Although fund carbon footprint attracts the attention of investors, asset managers, and regulators, very little research has focused on this metric. We explain funds' carbon footprint around the world. Using a sample of equity mutual funds domiciled in 17 countries, representing more than 80% of the equity fund worldwide market, we can explain fund carbon footprint by fund characteristics such as style of management and investment sectors. Even after controlling for fund characteristics, differences across countries remain. Funds domiciled in Scandinavian countries appear to have the lowest carbon footprint. The most robust factors explaining these cross-country differences in carbon footprint are the average level of education, reflecting investor sophistication and awareness about environmental issues, and fund investment zone's environmental performance. Fund carbon footprint is lower in countries with a high education level and investment zones with a higher environmental performance index.

title: How to Turn 100 Million Workers into Passive Shareholders
affiliations: Boise State University, College of Business and Economics, Department of Accountancy

detail.title: How to Turn 100 Million Workers into Passive Shareholders
detail.abstract: It is widely recognized that the United States retirement system has rapidly shifted away from defined benefit pension plans and towards defined contribution plans and Individual Retirement Accounts. Less recognized is the fact that most of these retirement plans now invest in essentially the same assets: passive index funds, predominantly based on equity indexes such as the S&P 500. There is growing concern that this system could pose serious risks for the entire financial system, yet it has received no scrutiny from lawmakers and regulators, who have instead acted to foster it. Despite the massive size and importance of the retirement system, there is little understanding of how and why it has taken its current form. This article aims to understand the sources of the current retirement savings regime by analyzing for the first time the history of its development. This analysis reveals three consistent factors helping to shape the current system. First, a long-running, elite-led belief in the value of encouraging employee capital ownership; second, academic theories favoring low-cost investing in broad market indexes; and third, the influence of large financial institutions.

title: Quantifying Trade-Offs in the Low-Carbon Transition of Energy System Towards Carbon Neutrality: A Case Study in China
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, University of Electronic Science and Technology of China (UESTC), University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, Utrecht University, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Aalborg University, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Quantifying Trade-Offs in the Low-Carbon Transition of Energy System Towards Carbon Neutrality: A Case Study in China
detail.abstract: Abstract —The low-carbon transition of energy systems is crucial for meeting global climate commitments. However, its trajectory is profoundly shaped by environmental, economic, and security requirements. A scientific gap occurs in how to plan energy system transition considering these multifaceted requirements, and in how to quantify their impacts on technology selection. This challenge becomes particularly acute under ambitious decarbonization targets, such as carbon neutrality. To address it, this study develops a hybrid planning framework that integrates an hourly smart energy system simulation tool and multi-objective optimization algorithms, comprehensively considering all energy sectors, key cross-sectoral measures and natural resource constraints. Utilizing China's energy system as a case study, the proposed framework systematically evaluates the feasibility of achieving carbon neutrality by 2060 and identifies the transition schemes under these multifaceted requirements. The results indicate that achieving carbon neutrality in China is feasible, with diverse technology combinations capable of meeting this goal. Compared with traditional scenario development, the optimal scheme determined by the framework achieves a reduction of 7.64 million tons of CO2 emissions alongside a 2.5% decrease in energy system cost, highlighting its ability to coordinate multiple objectives. Furthermore, this study reveals that technology development trends in the low-carbon transition depend on the prioritization of different objectives. In summary, the proposed planning framework can be applied to design low-carbon transition schemes for energy systems across diverse regions, providing deep insights into achieving ambitious decarbonization targets.

title: The Effect of Subsidies on Training: Evidence from the United States
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: The Effect of Subsidies on Training: Evidence from the United States
detail.abstract: Pursuing training programmes reinforces lifelong learning and is becoming increasingly important to prevent human capital obsolescence in aging societies. Non-formal training programmes rapidly adapt to labour market trends and flexibly impart relevant skills to the workforce. The United States Department of Labor facilitates training through Registered Apprenticeship. It has distributed subsidies to incentivise employer participation in this programme. The first such subsidy was the American Apprenticeship Initiative (AAI), whose aim was to increase the number of Registered Apprentices in eligible states in advanced manufacturing, information, and healthcare industries. I analyse the AAI’s causal effect on the number of new Registered Apprentices using federal Department of Labor administrative data. I exploit state, time, and industry variation in AAI treatment eligibility to conduct difference-in-difference and triple-difference estimation. I additionally leverage spatial variation to perform spatial regression discontinuity and spatial difference-in-discontinuity regressions. Results indicate that the AAI has not led to growth in the number of new Registered Apprentices. I discuss potential statistical and economic reasons behind this result and offer policy implications.

title: Does Course Selections Matter for College Degree Completion?
affiliations: Yale University

detail.title: Does Course Selections Matter for College Degree Completion?
detail.abstract: I develop a novel measure, coherence, for the quality of students’ course selections. I find that poor course selection is associated with higher dropout rate and, particularly, with higher late dropout rates. In addition, I find that both student and college characteristics are correlated with coherence production. Leveraging the staggered introduction of DegreeWorks in Texas, I find that web-based advising tools can be effective in improving the quality of course selections. The introduction of DegreeWorks also provides quasi-experimental variations in coherence, which I use to validate the effects of coherence on dropout rates.

title: Can Italy Decarbonise Without Raising Bills? A Scenario-Based Assessment of Renewable, Flexibility and Adequacy Policies on Power System Costs Through 2035
affiliations: Department of Law - University of Naples Federico II and Althesys Strategic Consultants

detail.title: Can Italy Decarbonise Without Raising Bills? A Scenario-Based Assessment of Renewable, Flexibility and Adequacy Policies on Power System Costs Through 2035
detail.abstract: This paper assesses the potential evolution of the Italian electricity market under two alternative policy configurations: long-term Contracts for Difference (CfD), reflecting recent reforms, and pure merchant investment under the System Marginal Pricing (SMP) regime. Motivated by recent energy price volatility and investment uncertainty, we investigate whether Italy’s policy shift can achieve key objectives: supporting decarbonisation, enhancing energy security and ensuring affordability. We employ the NET model — a system-dynamics framework calibrated on national data and policy targets — extended to incorporate CfD auctions, the MACSE storage-procurement mechanism, capacity-remuneration tools and Terna’s planned grid upgrades. Using 12-year Monte Carlo simulations (2024–2035), we compare outcomes in terms of renewable energy deployment, system-cost efficiency and consumer-price dynamics, and test robustness via sensitivity analyses. Our results demonstrate that renewables reduce consumer bills and narrow future price volatility, yet neither CfD nor SMP alone meets the National Energy and Climate Plan’s 2030 decarbonisation target — a shortfall driven by low ceiling prices in CfD auctions and moderate fossil-fuel price forecasts under SMP. While electricity price differences between the two market designs remain modest, beyond a certain RES penetration threshold, CfD is more effective at containing price spikes, whereas SMP facilitates faster long-term price declines via accelerated RES investment. These findings imply that policymakers should periodically recalibrate CfD auction parameters — particularly ceiling prices — to maintain alignment with evolving market conditions. Conversely, relying solely on merchant initiatives risks subjecting policy targets to uncontrolled fossil-fuel price fluctuations.

title: Robust Co-Optimisation of Multi-Microgrid Distributions Accounting for Wind-Scenery Uncertainty and Shared Energy Storage Operators
affiliations: Northeast Electric Power University, Northeast Electric Power University, Northeast Electric Power University, Northeast Electric Power University, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Northeast Electric Power University and Northeast Electric Power University

detail.title: Robust Co-Optimisation of Multi-Microgrid Distributions Accounting for Wind-Scenery Uncertainty and Shared Energy Storage Operators
detail.abstract: This paper addresses challenges such as the stochastic nature of wind and solar power output and the low utilization of energy storage resources in multi-microgrid systems by proposing a distributed robust collaborative optimization strategy that incorporates shared energy storage operators (ESO). A novel two-layer collaborative architecture is proposed, comprising a 'non-cooperative game (dynamic power trading among microgrids)' and a 'master-slave game (ESO–microgrid aggregation)' framework. The lower layer employs real-time electricity prices to guide distributed autonomous decision-making within microgrids while ensuring data privacy. The upper layer, managed by the ESO, establishes dynamic charging and discharging price incentive strategies to enable global coordination. To manage the uncertainty of wind and solar power, a distributed robust chance-constrained (DRCC) model based on the Wasserstein distance is developed, optimizing the worst-case probability distribution within a data-driven ambiguity set. This model effectively balances economic efficiency and robustness by overcoming the limitations of stochastic optimization (SO), which ignores distributional bias, and robust optimization (RO), which tends to be overly conservative. An ADMM-based alternating iterative algorithm is proposed to efficiently solve the two-layer optimization model. Simulation results indicate that, compared to independent operation, the proposed strategy enhances system efficiency by 1.5%–4.26%; the inclusion of ESO further reduces total costs by 5,689.14 yuan. Compared to SO and RO, the DRO approach achieves an optimal trade-off between conservatism and economic performance, providing a robust solution for the coordinated scheduling of high-renewable-penetration microgrids and shared energy storage.

title: Multi-Objective Optimal Scheduling of Large-Scale Hydrogen Production Systems Powered by Renewable Energy Considering Source-Load Interaction

detail.title: Multi-Objective Optimal Scheduling of Large-Scale Hydrogen Production Systems Powered by Renewable Energy Considering Source-Load Interaction
detail.abstract: This study presents a multi-objective optimization scheduling method for grid-connected renewable energy hydrogen production systems (H2-RES) using an improved proximal policy optimization with clipping algorithm (IPPO-clip). The approach addresses three key challenges: optimizing supply-demand interactions, enhancing renewable energy utilization, and reducing costs and emissions. The methodology involves four main components: (1) mathematical modeling of H2-RES components with an enhanced demand response model for improved load flexibility; (2) formulation of the scheduling problem as a Markov Decision Process (MDP); (3) integration of entropy regularization and nonlinear convergence factors in IPPO-clip to balance exploration and exploitation; (4) conversion of optimization objectives into reward-penalty functions for continuous state-action space decision-making. Case studies demonstrate the method's effectiveness in resolving supply-demand conflicts and improving load factors. Comparative analysis shows superior performance over MOPSO in multi-objective optimization and long-term decision-making, while outperforming conventional PPO in scheduling effectiveness, highlighting its practical potential for renewable energy systems.

title: The Impact of New Urbanization on Ecological Environment Quality and its Spatiotemporal Effects: A Case Study of Henan Province，China
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, Henan University, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: The Impact of New Urbanization on Ecological Environment Quality and its Spatiotemporal Effects: A Case Study of Henan Province，China
detail.abstract: With the rapid economic growth and accelerated urbanization process in developing country, numerous environmental and ecological challenges have emerged. Consequently, promoting a new urbanization that emphasizes coordinated development between the economy and the ecological environment has become increasingly significant. This study examines the impact of new urbanization on the ecological environment using data from 18 regions in Henan Province of China spanning from 2010 to 2021. After evaluating the quality of new urbanization and ecological environment and validating the model's applicability, a dynamic spatial Durbin model is constructed to empirically analyze the impact of new urbanization on the urban ecological environment. The findings indicate that the levels of new urbanization and ecological environment quality in Henan province are experiencing a volatile yet upward trend from 2010 to 2021, exhibiting significant spatial differentiation and polarization in their distribution. New urbanization in Henan province has a significant positive impact on regional ecological environment quality and exerts a notable spatial promotion effect on neighboring areas' ecological environments. Besides new urbanization, government intervention and financial development also have a significant positive impact on the quality of the urban ecological environment. Policy recommendations are provided based on the research conclusions.

title: The Reversal Rate Before Zero: Net Interest Margin Pressure and Business Restructuring in Small and Medium-Sized Banks
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Jiangsu University and Shandong Management University

detail.title: The Reversal Rate Before Zero: Net Interest Margin Pressure and Business Restructuring in Small and Medium-Sized Banks
detail.abstract: Previous research has typically viewed the "reversal rate" as a phenomenon unique to low and negative interest rate policy environments. However, can the pressure on net interest margins (NIMs), induced by structural financial frictions, cause a reversal-rate-like effect to emerge prematurely even under a conventional monetary policy framework? In the context of China's tiered banking industry structure, small and medium-sized commercial banks (SMEs) face intense deposit competition, making them an ideal sample for this study. Using data from 183 SMEs from 2009 to 2023, we construct exogenous monetary policy shocks via a high-frequency identification method and employ multiple econometric methods to test our hypotheses. The study finds that an expansionary monetary policy shock causes a significant short-term decline in NIMs, prompting a defensive business restructuring. This restructuring manifests as a "loan-to-securities" asset shift and a pivot toward non-interest income, with the response being particularly pronounced for high-NIM banks. This asymmetric response results in an initial contraction in credit supply, where the bank risk-taking channel temporarily overpowers the credit channel. Our central contribution is to uncover the mechanism through which structural banking frictions alter the dynamic path of monetary policy transmission. We demonstrate that "cost rigidity" on the liability side can lead to an initial reversal of policy effects, creating a novel and challenging policy trade-off for central banks in economies with less developed financial systems. These findings show that the "reversal rate" is not just a ZLB-specific issue but a broader phenomenon rooted in market structure, with significant implications for financial stability and macroeconomic management.

This study approaches energy security from the perspective of energy transition and comprehensively analyzes key issues and cases of international cooperation in the area of carbon neutrality and energy security. Building on this analysis, the study offers implications for governmental measures to enhance energy security while facilitating the transition towards carbon neutrality.

title: Multi-Stakeholder Optimization of a Lithium Supply Chain Approach for Brazil's Energy Transition: Sustainable Advantages of Lioh Production Over Li2co3

detail.title: Multi-Stakeholder Optimization of a Lithium Supply Chain Approach for Brazil's Energy Transition: Sustainable Advantages of Lioh Production Over Li2co3
detail.abstract: This paper presents a comparison among several scenarios to assess the implementation of a multi-stakeholder approach within the lithium supply chain. The proposed framework integrates both economic and environmental concerns across the entire value chain, including virgin spodumene extraction, concentration, chemical conversion to Li2CO3 and LiOH, and distribution stages. A detailed appraisal of water requirements is conducted for each process, such as spodumene concentration and lithium compounds production, joined by the absolute material impact indicator (DMA) from a circular economy perspective. Furthermore, an innovative metric is proposed to account for greenhouse gas emissions, particularly CO2, enabling a broader, comprehensive environmental evaluation of the supply chain. To ensure precision and robustness in the results, a Mixed-Integer Non Linear Programming model is proposed, incorporating multiple levels of stakeholder interests. Then, the approach is applied to the case study of Brazil. Therefore, an accurate strategy for the national development of its lithium industry, as well as key challenges that must be addressed, is argued. Results showed that spodumene concentration is the most water-intensive stage, accounting for 83% of total consumption. In addition, from both economic and environmental perspectives, LiOH production in Brazil is more sustainable, supporting a strategic and progressive change from Li2CO3. Accordingly, this study contributes to enhancing widespread electromobility in Brazil by aligning the lithium supply chain with global sustainability goals and resource efficiency principles.

title: When Simulator Experiences Shape Later Choices: Measuring Behavioural Spillover on Travel Preferences
affiliations: Norwegian University of Science and Technology (NTNU), University of Leeds and Norwegian University of Science and Technology (NTNU)

detail.title: When Simulator Experiences Shape Later Choices: Measuring Behavioural Spillover on Travel Preferences
detail.abstract: Behavioural spillover, where one behaviour affects others, is widely studied in psychology but underexamined in transport, despite its potential to improve sustainability. We offer a novel contribution by combining immersive driving simulator data with stated choices to test spillover effects on preferences for travel time and carbon emissions. Our design captures how real-time, experience-based feedback, augmented by personalised driving advice, influences behaviour. We find evidence of behavioural shifts, and a link between those shifts in preferences and behaviour in the simulator. Crucially, we reveal substantial heterogeneity in responses, underscoring the need to move beyond homogeneous assumptions. The willingness to accept longer journeys in return for reduced CO2 emissions increases from 22.6 mins per kg to 39.87 mins per kg after seeing the driving advice information. The findings have implications for designing policies that harness spillover mechanisms to reduce transport-related emissions, making a valuable contribution to environmental research and transport policy.

The Korean government must strike a balance between the goals of achieving climate neutrality and sustaining economic growth. These two issues represent a kind of Gordian knot, notoriously difficult to untangle. Yet, the reality is stark, and the urgency of the climate crisis is undeniable. In this context, this paper aims to introduce the theory of the climate club. Utilizing this framework, we examine the G7-initiated climate club and the GSSA as real-world case studies. (The rest omitted)

title: The Data Union Strategy: Twelve Recommendations from a Researcher’s Perspective
affiliations: KU Leuven - Centre for IT & IP Law (CiTiP), KU Leuven - Centre for IT & IP Law (CiTiP), KU Leuven, Centre for IT & IP Law (CiTiP), Students, KU Leuven - Centre for IT & IP Law (CiTiP) and KU Leuven - Centre for IT & IP Law (CiTiP)

detail.title: The Data Union Strategy: Twelve Recommendations from a Researcher’s Perspective

contentType.other: Contribution to a public consultation of the European Commission

detail.abstract:
The Data Union Strategy Consultation aims to unlock the full potential of data to strengthen the European economy through enhanced data sharing possibilities. In our contribution to the consultation, we want to highlight four aspects that based on our research would be important for any future activity of the European Union (EU) with regards to data.

First, we want to stress that the approximation of laws should not compromise fundamental rights like privacy and data protection. While simplification of laws can reduce burdens for businesses, doing so without caution risks undermining essential fundamental rights protections, especially those enshrined in the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR). Given the private sector's growing power and the persistent gaps in safeguarding rights amid technological advances, any regulatory reform should prioritise the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. A balanced, research-informed approach is necessary to ensure that competitiveness does not come at the expense of ethical and legal safeguards.

Second, data sharing requires particular care with the quality of the shared information. The legal basis for the European Commission's Communication itself is Article 114 of the Treaty on European Union (TEU). Although the Communication states that a range of initiatives with different legal bases is expected, the legal basis in which the European Commission decided to ground the call for Evidence raises concerns. Data governance instruments require tailor-made solutions. However, if the focus remains legal instruments, the European Commission risks to overlook the potential of non-legal instruments to govern data sharing with the detail required by the high level of protection conferred to personal data in the EU. Also, further research is required to clarify the purposes and effects of data spaces, data hubs and AI regulatory sandboxes.

Third, non-commercial purposes of data processing, such as research, public interest, societal and democratic participation, should be explicitly addressed in the Data Union Strategy Communication. Unlocking the full potential of data depends on exploring and investing in discussions and solutions around non-commercial (re-)uses of data. Research should occupy a leading role in the Data Union Strategy, allowing the development of fundamental concepts and recommendations for data governance.

Finally, the Data Union Strategy should reflect on recent lessons from regulating data intermediaries under the Data Governance Act (DGA). Current definitions lack clarity, fragment governance, and can discourage responsible data sharing. We encourage the European Commission to support research into how these organisations and data governance frameworks function in practice, whether they build trust, interoperability, and public value, and whether regulation is proportionate for an emerging market. Issues such as the uncertain status of Collective Management Organisations (CMOs) underscore the need for better alignment between copyright law and broader frameworks regulating intermediation services, such as the Digital Services Act (DSA) and the Digital Markets Act (DMA). The Strategy should seize this opportunity to address these challenges, enhance legislative coherence, and ensure that future interventions are integrated, proportionate, and grounded in robust research - laying the foundation for more coherent and effective data governance.

These four points are further developed in the position statement attached to our contribution, where we also develop twelve concrete recommendations on how to tackle each area.

title: Changes in the Hedonic Valuation of Amenities and Characteristics in Post-pandemic Residential Property Markets
affiliations: University of Sheffield

detail.title: Changes in the Hedonic Valuation of Amenities and Characteristics in Post-pandemic Residential Property Markets

publicationDetails.journalName: CESifo Working Paper Series

detail.abstract: This study examines whether the COVID-19 pandemic led to lasting shifts in residential housing valuation in the UK, focusing on Greater London and seven major cities. The following questions are addressed: a) Was this change in residential valuations temporary, or is it likely to be permanent? b) For what other characteristics do we see a fundamental shift in valuation by home buyers? c) Did seven other cities follow a consistent change with Greater London? Using transactions data for more than 1.5 million house sales from 2017 to 2023, and detailed neighborhood information, we find a persistent flattening of the CBD-distance price gradient: by 7.7% (from -0.683 to -0.63) in Greater London and 9.6% (from -0.135 to -0.122) in major UK cities. An event study confirms the change is stable over time. Hedonic price models show that this effect holds after controlling for amenities, with post-pandemic buyers placing greater emphasis on school quality and property type. Notably, demand shifts toward large homes, with premiums rising for terraced, detached, and semi-detached houses, and falling for apartments (flats). Effects of crime and density vary by region, showing stronger negative valuation in London and weaker or even positive effects elsewhere.

title: Portfolio Construction: Blending Fundamental and Technical Analysis
affiliations: Columbia University - Columbia Business School

detail.title: Portfolio Construction: Blending Fundamental and Technical Analysis
detail.abstract: This paper explores the interplay between fundamental and technical analysis in long/short equity portfolio construction. Rejecting the binary thinking that separates the two disciplines, it demonstrates how successful portfolio managers routinely combine both methods. Through case studies, practical frameworks, and technical screening exercises, the analysis highlights how momentum, valuation metrics, and relative strength can enhance idea generation, risk management, and capital allocation. This integration is especially valuable within hedge fund environments characterized by short-term pressures and high idea velocity demands. The paper aims to provide both a theoretical and operational guide to blending these approaches for improved investment outcomes.

title: Reclaiming the Right to Water: Commoning, Degrowth and Eco-Socialist Transformations
affiliations: University of London - School of Oriental and African Studies (SOAS)

detail.title: Reclaiming the Right to Water: Commoning, Degrowth and Eco-Socialist Transformations
detail.abstract: This chapter critically examines the human right to water through the lens of eco-socialist degrowth. While access to safe water is internationally recognised as a human right, contemporary water crises are deeply embedded in a political economy shaped by capitalist growth. Water injustices are not just technical or legal issues, but structural outcomes of an economic model that prioritises accumulation and profit. Despite its normative achievements, the right to water has often been operationalised within this very framework-focussing narrowly on minimum access to water, while remaining compatible with privatised, corporatised and commodified water regimes. Against this backdrop, this chapter argues for a radical reconceptualization of the right to water. Drawing on ecosocialist and degrowth scholarship, it situates water (in)justices within this broader landscape of capitalism, calling for a shift in how we frame, think and struggle for a HRtW. In doing so, the chapter acknowledges the limits and contradictions of rights discourse, while insisting that rights can still be mobilised strategically-as part of a broader counter-hegemonic project-to challenge systemic injustices and construct alternative post-growth futures.

title: Disconnecting Women: Gender Disparities in the Impact of Online Instruction

detail.title: Disconnecting Women: Gender Disparities in the Impact of Online Instruction

publicationDetails.journalName: CESifo Working Paper Series

detail.abstract: We study the impact of online instruction with a field experiment that randomly assigns 1,344 university students to different proportions of online and in-person lectures in multiple introductory courses. Increased online instruction leaves men’s exam performance unaffected but significantly lowers women’s performance, particularly in math-intensive courses. Online instruction also reduces women’s longer-run performance and increases their study dropout. Exploring mechanisms, we find that women exposed to more online lectures report greater difficulty in connecting with peers, less engaging instructors, and lower course satisfaction. Our findings suggest that shifting toward more online instruction may disproportionally harm women.

title: For (Un)Love or (of) Taxes? How Taxing Bachelors Empowered Italian Women
affiliations: University of Lausanne

detail.title: For (Un)Love or (of) Taxes? How Taxing Bachelors Empowered Italian Women

publicationDetails.journalName: CESifo Working Paper Series

detail.abstract: Unpaid domestic work continues to fall largely on women, despite their growing presence in the workforce. This paper asks whether policies changing the relative bargaining position of spouses can disrupt this pattern. I use the introduction of a bachelor tax in fascist Italy to show that altering men’s incentives to marry shaped the allocation of domestic work. Men in tax-induced marriages took on more domestic work, while their wives gained time, agency, and better economic outcomes. Effects are longlasting and transmitted across generations: women raised in households with more equitable labor divisions also perform less housework. The findings suggest shocks in bargaining power can loosen the hold of social norms and reconfigure domestic life.

title: A Transaction Cost Framework: Social Capital Perspective
affiliations: Istanbul Esenyurt University

detail.title: A Transaction Cost Framework: Social Capital Perspective

declarations.declarationOfInterest: No conflict of interest.
declarations.funderStatement: No funding.

detail.abstract:
This study explores the synergistic relationship between Transaction Cost Economics (TCE) and the concept of social capital, arguing that the latter provides a crucial, often overlooked, mechanism for mitigating transaction costs within economic systems. Traditional TCE, pioneered by Oliver Williamson, posits that firms and markets choose organizational structures to minimize the costs associated with economic exchanges, including search and information costs, bargaining and decision costs, and policing and enforcement costs. While TCE effectively explains the boundaries of the firm and the choice between market and hierarchy based on these costs, it frequently operates under assumptions of bounded rationality and opportunism, often treating trust and informal norms as exogenous or secondary.

The integration of social capital into a transaction cost framework offers a more comprehensive understanding of economic organization and performance. It explains why certain economic activities are more efficiently conducted within particular social contexts, highlighting the non-market factors that influence economic efficiency. Lower transaction costs, facilitated by robust social capital, can lead to enhanced market efficiency, improved firm performance, and accelerated regional economic development. However, it is also crucial to acknowledge that social capital is not uniformly beneficial; its effects can vary depending on its type (e.g., bonding versus bridging) and can, in some instances, lead to exclusion or inhibit innovation. Nevertheless, incorporating social capital provides a richer, more behaviorally informed perspective on how economic actors navigate the complexities of exchange.

publicationDetails.detailsText: NETWORKS, PLATFORMS, AND UTILITIES, Ganesh Sitaraman, Morgan Ricks, Shelley Welton, & Lev Menand, eds., Oxford University Press, Forthcoming 2025

detail.abstract: Comparing the roles of the state and of social enterprises in supporting health care and public health in Europe and the United States shows how common goals of “systemness” can be undercut by legal and political frameworks that articulate very different commitments to social solidarity. Europe emphasizes universal healthcare coverage through explicitly public systems and general taxation.  Although there is no “European health care system,” EU jurisdictions generally share the same values and organisational patterns. Member States’ healthcare systems are universal, accessible at the point of service, and based on public law.  Care supplied by private organisations is formally “incorporated” into a public system by contract.  The US spends approximately twice as much per capita as Europe on health care, but channels it largely through private insurance and provider organizations that are neither designed nor operate as a unified system, a reality that has been obscured by longstanding legislative accommodation of physician authority.  By overstating the role of market competition and concealing the centrality of public support, the US approach also leaves healthcare vulnerable to the second Trump administration’s ongoing assault on scientific and public health expertise and its proclaimed intent to slash health services funding for low-income groups.

title: Measuring Equity in Environmental Care: Methodology and an Application to Air Pollution
affiliations: University of Salerno - Dept. of Economics and Statistics, University of Salerno - Dept. of Economics and Statistics and University of Genova

detail.title: Measuring Equity in Environmental Care: Methodology and an Application to Air Pollution

publicationDetails.journalName: FEEM Working Paper Series

detail.abstract: The implementation of environmental policies varies substantially across geographical areas. This paper proposes a conceptual and methodological framework-adapted from the health economics literature-to assess equity in the allocation of environmental policy effort. We define "environmental care" as the set of local policy interventions aimed at improving environmental quality within an area, and evaluate its distribution relative to environmental need. Using direct and indirect standardization techniques, we measure horizontal inequity (unequal care among areas with similar need) and vertical inequity (differential care in response to differing needs). Applying this framework to traffic-related air pollution policies in Italian municipalities from 2012 to 2021, we find that the observed reduction of overall inequality in environmental care is mostly driven by a decline in horizontal inequity. However, we find evidence of persistent socioeconomic disparities, with lower-income municipalities receiving disproportionately less policy effort relative to their environmental needs.

title: Political Participation and Competition in Concurrent Elections: Evidence from Italy
affiliations: Fondazione Eni Enrico Mattei (FEEM), Milan

detail.title: Political Participation and Competition in Concurrent Elections: Evidence from Italy

publicationDetails.journalName: FEEM Working Paper Series

detail.abstract: This paper investigates how concurrent national and local elections affect the local political participation and competition. Leveraging a quasi-experimental framework provided by Italy's staggered electoral timing, the paper employs a difference-indifferences design. Estimates reveal that municipalities holding concurrent elections exhibit lower levels of local participation and competition. Moreover, the concurrent election increases participation by candidates with nationally-established parties, while decreases participation with independent parties. This further translates into a higher votes share for nationally-established parties and a consequent higher probability of election. Elected mayors tend to have lower education and experience in office, while they are more likely to be from the municipality they were elected in. Further, elected mayors are able to attract more intergovernmental transfers, without substantially affecting local spending patterns.

title: Bao Game Analysis Via Visibility Graphs: A Complex Network Approach to Cultural Gameplay Dynamics
affiliations: University of Dar es Salaam

detail.title: Bao Game Analysis Via Visibility Graphs: A Complex Network Approach to Cultural Gameplay Dynamics
detail.abstract: The Bao game, a traditional African board game with deep strategic elements, is modeled in this study using the Visibility Graph (VG) approach. We convert sequences of Bao moves into time series and then map them into complex networks using visibility graph methods. By analyzing properties such as degree distribution, clustering, and centrality, we uncover structural signatures of strategic play. The results demonstrate that visibility-based graphs can effectively capture the hidden dynamics and planning depth of Bao, revealing useful insights for computational ethnomathematics and game AI development.

title: Macroeconomic Determinants of Unemployment in V4 Countries: A Longitudinal Time Series Analysis
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Macroeconomic Determinants of Unemployment in V4 Countries: A Longitudinal Time Series Analysis
detail.abstract: Research background: The rising unemployment rate is a serious problem within a market economy. Effectively addressing this phenomenon requires a thorough understanding of its causes. This article focuses on identifying long-term factors influencing unemployment in the Visegrad Group (V4) countries in the period from January 2005 to December 2022.Purpose of the article: The aim of the study is to analyze seasonal fluctuations in unemployment in the V4 countries, identify relevant macroeconomic determinants of long-term unemployment, quantify their impact, and at the same time point out differences between the individual countries of this group.Methods: To identify seasonality, autocorrelation analyses of unemployment time series were applied. Subsequently, seasonal decomposition was used to quantify deviations from the trend. Long-term determinants of unemployment were identified using SARIMA modeling. More than 20 macroeconomic variables were evaluated – for example, interest rates, minimum wage, GDP, inflation, exports, foreign direct investment, corruption rate, tax burden and social benefits. The quality of the models was verified using graphical analysis of predictions, autocorrelation of residuals and indicators such as MAPE and BIC.Findings & value added: The results confirm the presence of seasonal fluctuations in the unemployment rate, while their intensity and periodicity differed between countries. The most pronounced seasonality was recorded in Poland, the weakest in Slovakia. The most significant long-term factors affecting unemployment included state spending on the labor market, social benefits, inflation, interest rates, tax revenues, business confidence, corruption rate and foreign investment inflow. The impact of these factors varied by country, direction of effect and time lag.

title: Co-opetition on the Seven Seas: Global Strategic Alliance in the Container Shipping Industry
affiliations: Cornerstone Research, Inc. - Boston Office

detail.title: Co-opetition on the Seven Seas: Global Strategic Alliance in the Container Shipping Industry

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The views and opinions expressed in this paper are solely those of the author and do not necessarily reflect the views of any affiliated institutions or the company the author is employed by.

detail.abstract: Global strategic alliances have become a defining feature of the container shipping industry, allowing firms to pool resources and coordinate operations to achieve efficiency gains. However, these alliances also raise concerns about their potential to limit competition and enhance market power. This paper examines the formation and dissolution of global strategic alliances in the container shipping industry, with a particular focus on the 2M Alliance between Maersk and MSC. Using empirical data and a multi-market Cournot oligopoly model with capacity constraints, we analyze the incentives behind alliance formation, the efficiency gains from vessel reallocation, and the impact on market competition and consumer welfare. The findings reveal that vessel reallocation plays a crucial role in enhancing supply-side efficiency, but the extent of these gains depends on the comparative advantage of alliance members and aggregate market conditions. Counterfactual simulations demonstrate that alliances can increase efficiency and consumer welfare when members have distinct fleet compositions, but they may also enhance market power under certain conditions. The study concludes with policy implications regarding the regulation and long-term viability of global strategic alliances in the shipping industry.

title: Navigating Climate Change: How Do Adaptation Initiatives Affect Bank versus Bond Financing?
affiliations: Ecole de Management de Normandie, The Chinese University of Hong Kong (CUHK) - CUHK Business School, Xiamen University - School of Economics and University of Massachusetts Lowell

detail.title: Navigating Climate Change: How Do Adaptation Initiatives Affect Bank versus Bond Financing?
detail.abstract: Climate change adaptation initiatives are designed to increase climate resilience, which requires scaling up climate finance. It is therefore essential to consider the financial resources that underpin the process of navigating climate change. Employing the staggered introduction of U.S. state-level climate change adaptation plans (CLAPs) as quasi-exogenous shocks, we examine how climate change adaptation polices affect corporate debt choice, i.e., the mix of firm-level bank versus bond financing. We find that initiating such plans significantly increases the reliance of affected firms on bank debt relative to public debt. This effect is more pronounced among firms prone to suffer from climate risks, with more fragile fundamentals and higher information asymmetries. Furthermore, we find that the spreads of newly issued bank loans rather than corporate bonds decrease significantly after the finalization of CLAPs. Our overall findings indicate that relative to public debtholders who are lacking of capacities to acquire firm-specific information, banks are able to distinguish climate-resilient borrowers, which shed light on how debt instruments should be designed to better adapt to climate change.

title: Rational Mapping, Probabilistic Convergence, and Temporal Intervention: A Systematic Construction of the Unique Romantic Solution
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: Rational Mapping, Probabilistic Convergence, and Temporal Intervention: A Systematic Construction of the Unique Romantic Solution
detail.abstract: This paper explores whether romantic relationships possess a “Unique Solution,” and proposes a model grounded in rational deduction, probabilistic convergence, and systemic intervention. By defining love as a five-element tuple—comprising projection, resonance, irreducibility, entropy, and convergence—we argue that individuals, through rational modeling and probabilistic reinforcement, can derive such a “unique solution” within a finite lifespan. Furthermore, we assert that by actively intervening in the timeline, this process itself constitutes a form of fate interference, suggesting that the Unique Romantic Solution is not merely a theoretical construct but a result that can be achieved through the intertwining of temporal decisions. The paper discusses the philosophical implications, social functions, and potential applications of this theory in emotional decision-making.

title: IP in Superposition: Patents, Trade Secrets and Open Innovation in Quantum Information Technology
affiliations: University of Copenhagen - Centre for Advanced Studies in Biomedical Innovation Law (CeBIL), University of Copenhagen - Centre for Advanced Studies in Biomedical Innovation Law (CeBIL) - Faculty of Law and LML, University of Cambridge

detail.title: IP in Superposition: Patents, Trade Secrets and Open Innovation in Quantum Information Technology

Content may change during peer review and production; please do not quote or copy from this version without permission. detail.abstract: This chapter analyzes the intellectual property (IP) strategies deployed in quantum information technologies (QIT), showing that firms operate in a "superposition" of approaches: selectively combining patents, trade secrets, and open innovation across different layers of the quantum stack. While patent filings have increased significantly, trade secrecy remains important due to the tacit, context-specific nature of key processes and the constraints of exportcontrol regimes. At the same time, openness is a scientific and often strategic lever, enabling interoperability, cumulative research, and ecosystem formation through mechanisms such as open-source frameworks and cloud-access platforms which can lead to competitive advantage through network effects. Using a governance-stack heuristic that links legal instruments to specific technical layers-from hardware and control systems to software and interfaces-the chapter maps how exclusivity, confidentiality, and collaboration are configured in practice. This layered combination, involving the superposition and entanglement of IP and open innovation, shows that QIT competitive strategy depends not on choosing between proprietary and open models, but on calibrating their combination to fit technical, commercial, and policy objectives. The chapter reframes the prevailing debate in quantum innovation: rather than asking whether patents or secrecy are appropriate for quantum technologies, the key question becomes when, where, and in what form each instrument best serves both private incentives and public goals.

title: How (Not) to Identify Demand Elasticities in Dynamic Asset Markets
affiliations: University of Pennsylvania - The Wharton School, University of Pennsylvania - The Wharton School and University of Rochester - Simon Business School

detail.title: How (Not) to Identify Demand Elasticities in Dynamic Asset Markets
detail.abstract: We evaluate approaches to estimating demand elasticities in dynamic asset markets, both theoretically and empirically. We establish strict, necessary conditions that the dynamics of instrumented asset price variation must satisfy for valid identification. We illustrate these insights in a general equilibrium model of dynamic trade and derive the magnitude of biases that arise when these conditions are violated. Estimates based on static IO models are severely biased when the instrumented price variation is persistent or predictable. Empirically, we show that commonly used instruments yield elasticity estimates that are off by orders of magnitude, or even have the wrong sign. Our findings have direct implications for assessing the efficacy of persistent asset market interventions, such as Quantitative Easing (QE).

title: Corporate Raiding, Secrets, and the Battle for Domination of the Computer Chip Industry: An Analysis Of Apple Inc. V. Rivos Inc
affiliations: Minnesota State University, Mankato - Department of Accounting and Business Law and Minnesota State University, Mankato - Department of Accounting and Business Law

detail.title: Corporate Raiding, Secrets, and the Battle for Domination of the Computer Chip Industry: An Analysis Of Apple Inc. V. Rivos Inc
detail.abstract:
This article examines a lawsuit that arose when a new computer chip upstart, Rivos, Inc., recruited and hired approximately 50 chip engineers from Apple in 2021-22. Apple sued six of the departing employees for misappropriation of trade secrets in violation of the Defend Trade Secrets Act and for breaching its Intellectual Property Agreement and misappropriating its trade secrets. The defendants countersued, alleging that Apple’s overbroad restrictive contracts functioned as noncompetition agreements in violation of California law.

The Apple Inc. v. Rivos, Inc. et. al. litigation illustrates the practical, strategic, and legal issues that arise in corporate raiding lawsuits in general and, more specifically, the tension between overreaching and enforcement of trade secrets, confidentiality/nondisclosure agreements, and non solicitation provisions imposed against departing employees. The authors argue that, in striking the balance between legitimate protections of corporate secrets and employee mobility, particularly in settings where noncompetition agreements are prohibited, parties and courts should narrow their employee restrictions to be more consistent with statutory trade secrets law.

title: Beyond Bias: AI as a Proxy Advisor
affiliations: University of Rhode Island and University of South Carolina - Darla Moore School of Business

detail.title: Beyond Bias: AI as a Proxy Advisor
detail.abstract: After documenting a trend towards increasingly subjective proxy advisor voting guidelines, we evaluate the use of artificial intelligence as an unbiased proxy advisor for shareholder proposals. Using ISS guidelines, our AI model produces voting recommendations that match ISS in 79% of proposals and better predicts shareholder support than ISS recommendations alone. Disagreements between AI and ISS are more likely when firms disclose hiring a third-party governance consultant, suggesting these consultants-often the proxy advisor itself-may influence recommendations. These findings offer insight into proxy advisor conflicts of interest and demonstrate AI's potential to improve transparency and objectivity in voting decisions.

title: Emissions Accounting in Global Supply Chains: An Input-Output Model Approach

declarations.declarationOfInterest: None

detail.abstract: As businesses and policymakers intensify efforts to measure and mitigate carbon emissions, the need for accurate and comprehensive accounting methods has never been greater. Multi-Regional Input-Output (MRIO) models provide a powerful tool for estimating both production and consumption-based emissions, as well as the Scope 1, 2, and 3 greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions that companies are now required to report. They offer a systematic approach that captures the complexities of global supply chains, energy use, and cross-border trade. This report provides a detailed yet accessible introduction to the application of environmentally extended MRIO models to the analysis of GHG emissions from global supply chains.

title: Salinization and Development
affiliations: Technology University of Braunschweig and Technology University of Braunschweig

detail.title: Salinization and Development
detail.abstract: We study the impact of saltwater intrusion-a process intensified by climate change-on the livelihoods of farmers in the Vietnamese Mekong Delta, a large rice exporter. To capture spatiotemporal variations in salinization, we develop a localized index based on river salinity measurements and unique geodata on the extensive regional canal network. Our findings show that salinization significantly reduces rice yields while generates disproportionately large decreases in agricultural revenues. To explain this difference, we document a sizable contraction of land under rice cultivation, with only minimal shifts toward alternative uses such as salt-resistant crops. This suggests a lock-in effect in rice farming and highlights limited short-term agricultural adaptation potential. Our results from household and firm data further indicate farmers' lower probability of working own-farm jobs and simultaneously friction in their reallocation to local, nonagricultural sectors. However, we observe long-term intergenerational adjustments, as farmer households increase relative investments in their children's education. We interpret this result to be a strategic response by households to an anticipated high-salinity future, where urban, high-skilled employment becomes more attractive.

title: Women's Agency and the Future of Farming: A Regional Comparison from the Marshlands in the Democratic Republic of Congo
affiliations: University of Lubumbashi, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Women's Agency and the Future of Farming: A Regional Comparison from the Marshlands in the Democratic Republic of Congo
detail.abstract: Contrary to dominant narratives portraying rural women as voiceless subsistence farmers, this study draws on survey data from marshland farmers in two regions of the Democratic Republic of Congo to highlight their active roles in decision-making regarding crop selection, control over harvest income, and entrepreneurial aspirations beyond smallholder agriculture. Findings reveal regional differences in women's willingness to remain engaged in farming, shaped by perceived socioeconomic and environmental conditions. These insights challenge reductive portrayals and underscore the need to recognize rural women’s agency and entrepreneurial ambitions in income-generating activities beyond family farming.

title: Behavioral Finance in Emerging Markets: Towards an Investor Sentiment Index for India And Argentine Sovereign Bonds
affiliations: NITTE School of Management, Vivekananda Global University and Cuoyo University

detail.title: Behavioral Finance in Emerging Markets: Towards an Investor Sentiment Index for India And Argentine Sovereign Bonds
detail.abstract: This paper explores the critical role of investor sentiment in understanding market behavior, with a particular focus on emerging markets, specifically India and Argentine. Drawing on the theory of behavioral finance, we examine how sentiment-driven factors-such as emotions, cognitive biases, and social influences-shape investor decision-making in these volatile markets. By analyzing both theoretical perspectives and real-world market data, we highlight how investor sentiment can lead to market inefficiencies, increased volatility, and sudden shifts in asset prices. The paper also delves into the potential of artificial intelligence (AI) to enhance sentiment analysis, offering a more accurate and timely understanding of market dynamics. Through AI techniques such as natural language processing (NLP) and machine learning, investors can better gauge sentiment trends and predict market movements, providing a competitive edge in emerging economies. The case studies of India and Argentine illustrate the complex interplay between sentiment and market behavior in environments characterized by political instability, economic uncertainty, and external shocks. Finally, the paper discusses the possibility of building an Investor Sentiment Index for India and Argentine Sovereign Bonds, and the implications for investors and policymakers in managing sentiment-induced volatility, as areas for future research in the integration of AI and behavioral finance in emerging markets.

title: Erroneous Beliefs Impede the Implementation of Cooperation-Inducing Mechanisms
affiliations: University of Münster, University of Münster, Ruhr-University Bochum, University of Gothenburg, REWE Group, University of Hamburg, RWTH Aachen University, Ruprecht Karls University, Technical University Munich, Otto-von-Guericke University, Magdeburg, Technical University Munich, Technical University Munich, Charité - Universitätsmedizin Berlin, Université Aix Marseille, University of Mannheim and University of Mannheim

detail.title: Erroneous Beliefs Impede the Implementation of Cooperation-Inducing Mechanisms

publicationDetails.journalName: CESifo Working Paper Series

detail.abstract: In social dilemmas, cooperation failures often arise due to the absence of mechanisms that prevent free-riding and enhance cooperation. Given the critical role these mechanisms play in sustaining cooperation, why are they so frequently missing? To explore this, we conducted an online experiment testing whether individuals choose to implement such cooperation-inducing mechanisms and why they might refrain from doing so. Participants were introduced to the rules of two public goods games, one of which includes a cooperation-inducing mechanism, while the other does not. Regarding the likelihood of successful cooperation, we found that participants were overly optimistic in the absence of the mechanism and overly pessimistic in its presence. As a result, a majority of subjects preferred the game without the cooperation-inducing mechanism. However, when we corrected participants’ beliefs about the actual payoffs obtained in the two games, a majority shifted their preference toward the game with the cooperation-inducing mechanisms in place.

title: Spatial Patterns in the Formation of Economic Preferences
affiliations: The University of Sydney, Max Planck Institue for Research on Collective Goods, Heinrich-Heine-Universität Düsseldorf, Max Planck Institute for Research on Collective Goods and Max Planck Institute for Research on Collective Goods

detail.title: Spatial Patterns in the Formation of Economic Preferences

publicationDetails.journalName: CESifo Working Paper Series

detail.abstract: We investigate how strongly the local environment beyond the family can contribute to understanding the formation of children’s economic preferences. Building on precise geolocation data for around 6000 children, we use fixed effects, spatial autoregressive models and Kriging to capture the relation between the local environment and children’s preferences. The spatial models explain a considerable part of so far unexplained variation in preferences. Moreover, the “spatial stability” of preferences exceeds the village level. Our results highlight the importance of the local environment for the formation of children’s preferences, which we quantify to be as large as that of parental preferences.

title: Lobbying in Disguise
affiliations: Georgia State University, University of St. Gallen - Swiss Institute for International Economics and Applied Economic Research and Harvard Business School

detail.title: Lobbying in Disguise

publicationDetails.journalName: CESifo Working Paper Series

detail.abstract: The ability of private interests to influence the political process is an important topic in economics and political science. While some of these efforts appear as campaign finance and lobbying expenditures in the official record, private interests may also engage in “covert” influence through media capture. In this paper, we systematically examine whether and to what extent corporations in the United States with an interest in slowing climate action might have used corporate advertisement in media outlets as a strategic tool to align such outlets’ coverage with their views. Based on several complementary empirical strategies, we find that advertisement spending by such actors (i) increases during election periods and (ii) is associated with both lower and more skeptical-leaning coverage of climate change and climate policy.

title: Redistributive Bargaining under the Shadow of Protests
affiliations: Princeton University - Department of Politics and Yale University - Department of Economics

detail.title: Redistributive Bargaining under the Shadow of Protests
detail.abstract: We consider an alternating-offers redistributive bargaining model where an affected third party can protest against proposals under review. Protests are costly and only stochastically successful. When successful, they secure the status quo. Stationary equilibria feature either inefficient protests or excessive accommodation to the third party. In both cases, the bargainers do not extract the full surplus. Strategic delay is necessary and sufficient to curb this issue: By delaying a harmful agreement with positive probability only after acquiescence, the bargainers create an endogenous punishment device that allows them to extract more surplus from the third party without triggering protests. The bargainers' misaligned interests are key for this result: If they internalized each other's payoff, strategic delay would not be credible.

title: The More the Merrier? The Role of Green Research and Development Subsidies under Different Environmental Policies
affiliations: Kiel Institute for the World Economy

detail.title: The More the Merrier? The Role of Green Research and Development Subsidies under Different Environmental Policies

publicationDetails.journalName: CESifo Working Paper Series

detail.abstract: I study the role of green research and development (R&D) subsidies under different environmental policies. Using a stylized equilibrium model calibrated to the European electricity sector, I analyze the effects of R&D subsidies under (1) an emission tax, (2) an emission cap, and (3) no environmental policy, focusing on competitiveness, environmental outcomes, and welfare. I find that increasing R&D subsidies increases knowledge accumulation and clean-sector output, displacing dirty-sector production. This raises overall output, lowers production costs, and enhances sectoral competitiveness. However, environmental benefits from R&D subsidies occur only under an emission tax or in the absence of environmental policy. Under an emission cap, emission prices fall from an increase in the R&D subsidy, reducing compliance costs without lowering total emissions. Our calibration further reveals interaction effects between environmental policy stringency and the effectiveness of the R&D subsidy under an emission tax, emission cap, or in the absence of an environmental policy.

title: Critical Perspectives in Canadian Tax Law
affiliations: University of Ottawa - Common Law Section and McGill University - Faculty of Law

detail.title: Critical Perspectives in Canadian Tax Law

declarations.funderStatement: This article draws on research supported by the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council.

detail.abstract: The purpose of this article is to spotlight the role of critical tax law scholarship in Canada. We argue that critical perspectives are essential to identifying inequities in Canadian tax law, from the most specific tax rules to the core structure of tax regimes. We begin by focusing on the contribution of critical perspectives in analyzing specific tax rules, using examples of tax relief for trans medical expenses and the exemption of menstruation products from sales tax.   We then focus on the importance of critical perspectives in the analysis of tax law regimes and show how critical legal scholars reveal the colonialism reflected in Canada’s tax relationships with First Nations and with other states. We demonstrate that a core challenge for critical tax law scholars is to navigate the disparity that arises between harmful tax policy choices that prompt reform and those which meet silence. We conclude that a major contribution of critical tax law scholarship in Canada to date has been to demonstrate that tax law cannot be exclusively delegated to technical experts but requires broad and inclusive policy attention.

title: A Framework for Applying Copyright Law to the Training of Textual Generative Artificial Intelligence
