detail.title: A Framework for Applying Copyright Law to the Training of Textual Generative Artificial Intelligence

publicationDetails.detailsText: Texas Intellectual Property Law Journal Vol. 32, No. 3 (June 2024).

detail.abstract:
The rise in the popularity of consumer-facing generative artificial intelligence (“GenAI”) has created considerable confusion and consternation among some copyright owners. Copyright owners argue that GenAI’s ability to automatically generate works is made possible by large-scale direct infringement by OpenAI, Microsoft, and other major GenAI developers. This article explores the application of copyright law to the training of OpenAI’s ChatGPT, specifically focusing on the legal issues surrounding the unauthorized use of copyrighted textual works in the GenAI training process.

The large language models (“LLMs”) that drive ChatGPT and similar GenAI can summarize written works, generate movie scripts, write poetry, and compose stories nearly instantaneously. LLMs can only function in this way due to the use of vast, diverse training datasets comprised of billions of websites and expansive repositories of books. These datasets are processed to derive the functionality and syntax of language, allowing the LLMs to generate new works.

This article discusses the recent lawsuits launched by high-profile authors and copyright owners against OpenAI and Microsoft, claiming direct, vicarious, and derivative infringement. Authors such as George RR Martin, Sarah Silverman, Christopher Golden, and professional organizations such as the Authors Guild contended their works were infringed upon to turn OpenAI into an $80 billion company.

In considering the merits of these lawsuits, we discuss the curation and content of training datasets used in the known iterations of ChatGPT, and characterize the protectability of the different works the datasets included. We then explore whether the transitory nature of OpenAI’s training process uses acceptable, non-infringing copies and how that undermines claims of direct infringement.

The article then looks at the applicability of current fair use precedent to textual GenAI and the various types of works used in training datasets. To do so, we apply settled caselaw and leading decisions to discuss OpenAI’s use of copyrighted works regarding purpose and character, nature of the original work, the amount and substantiality of the works used, and the impact on the market value of the works by ChatGPT. We pay special attention to other innovative technologies that rely on a fair use defense to draw analogies and comparisons to GenAI.

Finally, this article considers the policy and legislation of other countries and their approach to ChatGPT and copyright. In doing so, policy considerations are taken into account to argue the necessity of a finding of fair use to maintain international competitiveness and to prevent an erosion of fair use in other sectors outside of GenAI. The article concludes that there is substantial support for arguments that GenAI training involves only transitory, non-actionable copying, and is also permissable under fair use.

title: The Twin Disruption of Generative AI: Unbundling Capability and Responsibility in Creative Work
affiliations: RMIT and Royal Melbourne Institute of Technolog (RMIT University)

detail.title: The Twin Disruption of Generative AI: Unbundling Capability and Responsibility in Creative Work
detail.abstract: We provide a conceptual and empirical framework to analyse the twin disruption of AI: as it enhances task performance (capability disruption), responsibility for outcomes simultaneously unbundles from human workers (responsibility disruption). Our new methodology, applied to 126 Australian creative occupations, measures this twin disruption across eight AI risks: privacy, cybersecurity, professional standards breach, bias, misinformation, accountability, harm and intellectual property. We identify five job-zones of responsibility disruption, where generative AI is changing the allocation of responsibility alongside productivity.

title: Herbert Simon Meets F.A. Hayek on Institutions
affiliations: Southern Methodist University (SMU)

detail.title: Herbert Simon Meets F.A. Hayek on Institutions
detail.abstract: The evolutionary theory of F.A. Hayek remains both controversial and influential. In his mature view, Hayek asserted that institutional change beyond "tinkering" to be civilizationally dangerous. Although Hayek's evolutionary perspective on institutions has been analyzed and reanalyzed by a multitude of perspectives, none have approached it from the arguments articulated by Herbert Simon. Simon recognized the high level of complexity involved in institutional reform, but denied that evolutionary forms of significant institutional change are plausible in the context of local maxima in the space of institutions. For Simon, institutional change occurs when societal objectives (rightly or wrongly) shift, and policymakers satisfice in finding a "good enough" solution that is in no way optimal. Speculatively, changes in monetary policy leading to the Great Moderation exemplify satisficing behavior on the part of governments.

title: A New and Generalized Family of Heavy-Tailed-Topp-Leone-Type Ii Exponentiated Half Logistic-G Distribution
affiliations: University of Botswana, Botswana International University of Science and Technology (BIUST), Botswana International University of Science and Technology (BIUST) and Botswana International University of Science and Technology (BIUST)

detail.title: A New and Generalized Family of Heavy-Tailed-Topp-Leone-Type Ii Exponentiated Half Logistic-G Distribution
detail.abstract: We develop a novel family of distributions named heavy-tailed Topp-Leone-type II exponentiated half logistic distribution. Several mathematical properties including linear representation, Rényi entropy, quantile function,probability weighted moments, and distribution of order statistics are obtained. Estimation methods including maximum likelihood estimation, Anderson-Darling, right-tail Anderson-Darling, ordinary least squares and weighted least squares are  compared using simulation studies to identify which method is most appropriate for the new distribution. Several baseline distributions are used to demonstrate the flexibility of the density and hazard rate functions of the new distribution. In addition, several actuarial measures including tail value at risk, tail variance, value at risk and tail variance premium are explored and their numerical studies are conducted to verify that the new distribution is heavy-tailed. A special model of the new distribution is used to show its usefulness in a real life discipline.

title: Gold Shares underperform Gold Bullion
affiliations: University of Western Australia - Business School, The University of Western Australia and The University of Western Australia

detail.title: Gold Shares underperform Gold Bullion
detail.abstract: This paper studies the performance of gold miners relative to gold bullion. Gold miners provide leveraged exposure to gold and additional exposure to equity and mining-related risks. On average, miners underperform, especially over long horizons, during crises and in gold bear markets, with only marginal underperformance in gold bull markets. The underperformance is due to finite mine lives which implies that miners must continually replace the gold that they mine with new reserves to match the returns of physical gold. While a selection of gold mining firms outperform gold bullion, a portfolio of gold miner shares diversifies away the idiosyncratic upside of individual miners and is a less attractive investment compared to a direct holding in gold bullion.

title: Separating Complementarity and Variety Effect in Demand Estimation: A Structural Approach
affiliations: Shanghai University of Finance and Economics - College of Business and Shanghai University of Finance and Economics - College of Business

detail.title: Separating Complementarity and Variety Effect in Demand Estimation: A Structural Approach
detail.abstract: We develop a structural demand model that jointly captures complementarity and the variety effect in consumer preferences. Although these two forces often shift demand in the same direction, they arise from different mechanisms and carry distinct policy implications. Our flexible framework allows for the separate identification of these relationships using either order-level or consumer-level data. Building on Gentzkow (2007), we leverage variation from product entry and bundle choices to disentangle the underlying sources of demand correlation. We show that standard discrete choice models confound complementarity and variety effects, resulting in biased parameter estimates. Monte Carlo simulations confirm the accuracy and robustness of our identification strategy. To illustrate the policy relevance of our model, we simulate a cross-market merger between complements. Our results demonstrate how demand correlation, particularly a strong variety effect, shapes post-merger incentives for bundling and non-interoperability.

title: The National Security Council and the Prime Minister
affiliations: University of California, Berkeley, College of Letters & Science and Independent

detail.title: The National Security Council and the Prime Minister
detail.abstract:
This paper addresses the ongoing debate over the functions of the UK's National Security Council, established by David Cameron in 2010. Locating the NSC's formation in wider debates on the UK's constitution, the executive authority of the Prime Minister within Cabinet government, and the role of military intelligence in policymaking, it proposes two major changes to the NSC's role and its associated regulatory framework.

Firstly, it is proposed that the NSC be placed on a statutory footing as an amendment to current legislation in the Intelligence Services Act (1994). Defining the NSC’s existence and requiring its decision on certain executive powers such as the declaration of war would, in this paper’s estimation, act as a valuable constitutional check on Prime Ministerial power.

Secondly, a strengthened framework is proposed for the regulation of the NSC by Parliament, though the Intelligence & Security Committee. The case is made that, if national security in the 21st century may be defined as a public confidence that normal life may be conducted without personal or national danger, the public interest is served by more open scrutiny of high-level security policy, thereby increasing public confidence and accountability.

title: Mojo: Multi-Llm Optimised Joint Objective Generative Artificial Intelligence for Multi-Criteria Decision Analysis Framework
affiliations: University of Auckland

detail.title: Mojo: Multi-Llm Optimised Joint Objective Generative Artificial Intelligence for Multi-Criteria Decision Analysis Framework
detail.abstract: This study introduces the Multi-LLM Optimised Joint Objective (MOJO), a novel generative artificial intelligence (Gen-AI) driven multi-criteria decision analysis (MCDA) framework. MOJO uniquely integrates human expertise with multiple large language models (LLMs) to address limitations in traditional MCDA approaches. The information fusion framework combines risk-adjusted utility scoring, performance equilibrium, and reliability scoring, producing consensus-driven rankings that effectively account for uncertainty and non-linear risk preferences. Grounded in principles from prospect theory and utility theory, MOJO captures complex behavioural factors such as loss aversion and probability distortion. An ensemble of LLM outputs automates MCDA tasks, enhanced by systematic bias correction to reduce cognitive load and improve transparency. MOJO also incorporates a comprehensive illustrative case study evaluating treatments for Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD), demonstrating its applicability to complex scenarios involving clinical, operational, and ethical criteria. Results from validation experiments involving multiple LLMs and decision-makers across diverse scenarios highlight MOJO's robustness, reliability, and transparency, demonstrating its significant potential in high-stakes fields such as healthcare, engineering, and public policy.

title: Foul Play? Commonality and Referee Bias
affiliations: Hamilton College - Economics Department and Hamilton College - Economics Department

detail.title: Foul Play? Commonality and Referee Bias
detail.abstract: European soccer provides a unique setting in which players and referees from around the world interact in high-stakes matches where referees are expected to make instantaneous and unbiased decisions based on the laws of the game. Using player-by-match level data from more than 10 years of competitions, we find that players who grow up in countries with a native language that differs from the lingua franca (English) and is shared with the referee are 1.6 percentage points less likely to receive a yellow card. The effect that we document is driven by referees from ethnically or linguistically homogeneous countries.

detail.abstract: This paper presents a health policy perspective that builds upon and expands a response to a National Institutes of Health (NIH) Request for Information (NOT-OD-25-117) regarding its strategic plan for Artificial Intelligence (AI). We argue that the NIH is at a critical juncture where the integration of AI promises to revolutionize biomedical research, moving beyond augmentation to fundamentally transform discovery, development, and delivery of medical advances. To maintain the United States' leadership in science and medicine, a decisive and well-funded national strategy is imperative. This paper outlines a strategic framework designed to place the NIH at the core of an AI-native biomedical ecosystem. We propose a vision where autonomous agents drastically shorten discovery timelines and make personalized medicine a widespread reality. Our strategy emphasizes a dual approach: pursuing high-risk, high-reward basic science while simultaneously building a rigorous framework for the clinical translation of AI technologies. We present a phased roadmap that progresses from current semi-autonomous agents to fully autonomous laboratory platforms. This evolution is supported by foundational investments in a national AI research infrastructure, workforce development, and a steadfast commitment to developing ethical, equitable, and trustworthy AI. This document details the strategic necessity for this transformation and provides a comprehensive plan for the NIH to execute this ambitious vision.

title: Writing Matters: Generative AI as an Academic Impact Equalizer
affiliations: University of Rochester - Simon Business School, University of Rochester - Simon Business School, University of Texas at Dallas - Naveen Jindal School of Management and University of Texas at Dallas, Naveen Jindal School of Management, Department of Finance

detail.title: Writing Matters: Generative AI as an Academic Impact Equalizer
detail.abstract: We study the effect of generative AI, specifically ChatGPT, on academic writing quality and subsequent citations. Leveraging a novel dataset of over 120,000 papers from financial economics, management, and political science, we construct detailed writing quality measures using both traditional linguistic metrics and ChatGPT-based evaluations. We find that higher writing quality strongly predicts future citations. Following the release of ChatGPT in late 2022, writing quality improved significantly, particularly for authors from non-English-speaking institutions, those with non-English names, and those with fewer historical citations. These improvements translate into a narrowing of the citation count gap between these groups and their counterparts, and consequently to a more equal distribution of academic impact.

title: A Generalizable Framework for Mitigating Overfitting In Time Series Lstms Via Dropout Regularization
affiliations: Middle East Technical University, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Ankara University

detail.title: A Generalizable Framework for Mitigating Overfitting In Time Series Lstms Via Dropout Regularization
detail.abstract: Regularization remains a key issue when using high capacity deep learning models on complex and unstable financial time series. This study explores whether dropout techniques, combined with information-theoretic penalties, can help a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) network forecast daily gold prices without relying on transformations that enforce stationarity. We evaluate four dropout strategies (fixed, Monte Carlo, dynamic, and adaptive), each paired with fourteen divergence-based penalties. The models are assessed using expanding-window cross-validation and detailed hyperparameter tuning. Results show that all regularized models outperformed the unregularized baseline. A standard LSTM without dropout achieved a Test R2 of only 0.63, whereas regularized models reached values between 0.89 and 0.97. The best result came from a model using adaptive dropout with a Hellinger divergence penalty. These findings suggest that while dropout in general improves forecasting performance, methods that adjust to the data offer a clearer advantage for modeling non-stationary financial series.

title: Navigating Public and Private Funding Options for Conservation Measures: Farmers’ Preferences in the United Kingdom, France, and the Netherlands
affiliations: Osnabrück University, The James Hutton Institute and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Navigating Public and Private Funding Options for Conservation Measures: Farmers’ Preferences in the United Kingdom, France, and the Netherlands
detail.abstract: Evidence in economics highlights the importance of the design of agri-environment contracts for farmers' participation. However, a lack of evidence exists on how European farmers behave towards contracts set up by different organisers using different methods to pay participants while having the opportunity to interact and communicate with other farmers. We apply a discrete choice experiment using an online survey to estimate farmers' preferences for the contract organiser (government, retailer, NGO), the payment method (fixed per hectarepayment, price premium associated with a label), and participation in a farmer cluster regime as part of the contractual arrangement (no farmer cluster, optional participation, mandatory participation) in the United Kingdom, France and the Netherlands. Based on a sample of 767 farmers, respondents prefer, on average, contracts organised by the government over contracts from retailers or NGOs. Farmers prefer fixed per hectare payments over price premium associated with a label and contracts granting the option to join a farmer cluster. Additionally, our results reveal substantial heterogeneity in farmers' preferences.

title: Integrating Fem with Reliability-Based Serviceability Limit State Design for a Test Embankment on Low-Carbon Column-Stabilised Soil
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Integrating Fem with Reliability-Based Serviceability Limit State Design for a Test Embankment on Low-Carbon Column-Stabilised Soil
detail.abstract: Dry deep mixing (DDM) is one of the primary stabilisation methods used to reduce compressibility and increase bearing capacity of soft clays under road embankments. However, geotechnical designers encounter considerable uncertainty in designing DDM columns, arising from the properties of both soil and binder, as well as the stabilization techniques employed. These uncertainties are exacerbated when using novel binders, whose behaviour in real field conditions is still under investigation. In such cases, probabilistic simulation provides a systematic approach to quantifying and managing these uncertainties. This paper presents a reliability-based design framework that combines finite element (FE) analysis using the volume average technique and Monte Carlo simulation. The framework accounts for the uncertainty in the calculation of residual settlements of both soil and stabilised soil parameters in the case of a testing embankment built on low-carbon end-bearing and floating stabilised soil columns. The VAT approach was validated using field measurements and was found to reasonably capture the behavior of length-varying columns. Probabilistic results showed a depth-dependent trade-off: shorter columns produced higher mean settlements as expected, but lower relative scatter. In contrast, longer columns can meet strict serviceability criteria at the expense of much greater relative variability. However, sensitivity analysis revealed that allocating resources for characterizing soil and column properties at shallow depths is crucial for reducing uncertainty. Lastly, failure probabilities were linked with binder carbon emissions, enabling sustainable design and reliability adjustments based on environmental and performance trades-offs.

title: The Impact of Global Supply Chain Pressure on Macroeconomic Activities: A Novel Quantile Perspective
affiliations: Shanxi University, Shanxi University and Department of Economics, Pusan National University

detail.title: The Impact of Global Supply Chain Pressure on Macroeconomic Activities: A Novel Quantile Perspective
detail.abstract: Supply chain disruptions directly affect raw material prices, transportation costs, and macroeconomic operations. This study explores the impact of the global supply chain pressure index (GSCPI) on various economic activities utilising the quantile-on-quantile kernel-based regularised least squares (QQKRLS) approach and wavelet quantile regression (WQR). Our findings show that GSCPI generally exerts a positive impact on agricultural, food, and precious metal prices, particularly when all indices are at high quantiles and in the short term. Conversely, at low and medium GSCPI quantiles, and in the medium to long term, GSCPI positively affects fuel energy prices. At high GSCPI quantiles and in the long term, GSCPI mostly boosts the consumer price indices of the U.S. and China, with a stronger positive impact on the U.S. than on China. Additionally, GSCPI almost always suppresses world industrial production and trade, becoming a stimulator only in extremely long term. Finally, in the short to medium term, GSCPI reduces trade policy uncertainty but heightens U.S.-China tensions.

title: The Carbon Cost of Rising Incomes: Evidence from a Middle-Income Country
affiliations: Universidad EAN, Universidad del Rosario and University of Castilla-La Mancha - Faculty of Economic and Business Sciences

detail.title: The Carbon Cost of Rising Incomes: Evidence from a Middle-Income Country
detail.abstract: As developing countries reduce poverty and expand their middle classes, household consumption tends to shift toward more carbon-intensive patterns. This paper examines the carbon footprint of household consumption in Colombia, one of the world’s most unequal middle-income countries, using microdata from the national household budget survey and an environmentally extended input-output framework. Results reveal a stark concentration of emissions: the top 1% of households account for nearly a quarter of total emissions, while the bottom 10% are responsible for just 0.1%. Carbon emissions are more unequally distributed than household expenditure, underscoring the environmental implications of income inequality. We also estimate the income elasticity of emissions, finding that a 1% increase in income leads to a 0.6–0.85% increase in emissions. These findings highlight the need to integrate distributional concerns into climate policy. Without addressing the carbon consequences of income growth, developing countries risk locking themselves into unsustainable and inequitable development trajectories.

title: App Platform Model
affiliations: University of Virginia - Department of Economics and European University Institute - Economics Department (ECO)

detail.title: App Platform Model
detail.abstract: We model a digital platform that sells devices and operates an app marketplace, earning revenue through device sales and commissions on in-app purchases. Apps differ in quality, and consumers vary in their valuation of quality. Developers choose whether to enter and set in-app prices; consumers decide whether to buy the device and how much to spend. We characterize equilibrium allocations and the platform's optimal fees, identifying distortions in app entry and consumer participation driven by a key ratio of app revenue to consumer surplus. Commission caps increase developer surplus and entry but may reduce consumer welfare, especially under two-sided heterogeneity. Allowing third-party payments replicates the effects of a cap under homogeneous app quality. When the platform self-preferences by introducing its own apps, it lowers commissions but raises device prices, reducing consumer participation while benefiting remaining developers. We also present alternative interpretations of our model: ad-based financed apps, membership apps, video game consoles.

title: Beyond Bonferroni: Hierarchical Multiple Testing in Empirical Research
affiliations: University of California, Davis and University of Maryland - Department of Economics

detail.title: Beyond Bonferroni: Hierarchical Multiple Testing in Empirical Research
detail.abstract: Empirical research in the social and medical sciences frequently involves testing multiple hypotheses simultaneously, increasing the risk of false positives due to chance. Classical multiple testing procedures, such as the Bonferroni correction, control the family-wise error rate (FWER) but tend to be overly conservative, reducing statistical power. Stepwise alternatives like the Holm and Hochberg procedures offer improved power while maintaining error control under certain dependence structures. However, these standard approaches typically ignore hierarchical relationships among hypotheses-structures that are common in settings such as clinical trials and program evaluations, where outcomes are often logically or causally linked. Hierarchical multiple testing procedures-including fixed sequence, fallback, and gatekeeping methods-explicitly incorporate these relationships, providing more powerful and interpretable frameworks for inference. This paper reviews key hierarchical methods, compares their statistical properties and practical trade-offs, and discusses implications for applied empirical research.

title: Economic Relationship between Team Success and Financial Investments within NCAA Basketball Teams in the Big East Conference
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: Economic Relationship between Team Success and Financial Investments within NCAA Basketball Teams in the Big East Conference

declarations.declarationOfInterest: Over the past several decades, the National Collegiate Athletics Association, also referred to as NCAA, has evolved into a multibillion-dollar industry and one of the most popular and widely viewed sports organizations. Basketball, in particular, has seen a spike in attention from fans, media, and stakeholders and has emerged as one of the most popular, revenue-generating sports. This increase in value of the industry made me wonder and want to explore if the money allocated to teams’ in the NCAA had an effect on their performance.
declarations.ethicsApproval: It is important to note that regarding the ethical considerations, the study and all subsequent material have been approved by an informal school-based IRB.

detail.abstract: This research examines the relationship between economic factors and athletic success among NCAA Division 1 men's basketball teams, specifically focusing on the Big East Conference. While previous studies have broadly analyzed general correlations between financial resources and athletic success, this research narrows the scope to assess how specific factors-including but not limited to NIL (Name, Image, and Likeness) funding, ticket revenue, return on investment, and revenue-relate to team winning percentages. The research question is: What are the winning percentages of college basketball teams in the Big East Conference, in relation to their economics (tax dollars paid, tuition, or revenue made from sports events)? This topic is especially relevant as NIL policies and changing revenue structures are reshaping college athletics. To answer this question, a correlational research design and quantitative method were used to conduct the research by gathering economic data and analyzing the relationship between financial investment and winning percentages. The findings suggest that while general financial investment does not guarantee higher winning percentages, targeted spending-particularly in areas like NIL deals and athletic-specific contributions-has a stronger correlation with success. These results are important because they can help athletic directors, administrators, and policymakers optimize both team success and economic gain by understanding the key factors that contribute to performance.

title: Financial Imbalances, Systemic Stress, and Macroprudential Implications
affiliations: International Monetary Fund (IMF) and International Monetary Fund (IMF)

detail.title: Financial Imbalances, Systemic Stress, and Macroprudential Implications

publicationDetails.journalName: International Monetary Fund (IMF) Research Paper Series

detail.abstract: The effectiveness of macroprudential policy framework depends to a large extent on how the process of monitoring and assessing systemic risks and the calibration of macroprudential policy tools are operationalized in practice. This paper has two main contributions. First we propose an enhanced composite indicator, the Systemic Vulnerabilities Index (SVI), which captures the buildup of systemic vulnerabilities. The index is built on an innovative approach that uses optimal aggregation of subindices, and without imposing exogenous constraints. Specifically, making use of the Principal Component Analysis (PCA) for a broad set of relevant input variables, we determine their relative importance in contributing to the buildup of systemic vulnerabilities. Subsequent use of Monte Carlo simulation techniques allows us to select the optimal SVI that best predicts future credit losses. The proposed SVI captures both time and sectoral dimensions of the buildup of risks. We provide evidence showing a superior performance of the SVI, compared to the traditional credit-to-GDP gap in documenting risk accumulation. We investigate the relationship between our SVI and financial condition index and provide evidence of a negative correlation between the two, whereby a loosening of financial conditions is associated with more accumulation of imbalances. Second, we provide a framework that guides on how the SVI can be used for increasing Countercyclical Capital Buffer (CCyB) beyond its neutral level. Specifically, we propose a mapping that shows how the SVI can help determine the timing of setting a CCyB beyond the neutral rate as well as its magnitude.

title: Oil Shocks and Labor Market Developments
affiliations: International Monetary Fund (IMF), International Monetary Fund (IMF) - Policy Development and Review Department and University of Oxford

detail.title: Oil Shocks and Labor Market Developments

publicationDetails.journalName: International Monetary Fund (IMF) Research Paper Series

detail.abstract: This paper examines how oil shocks shape labor market outcomes across 89 countries from 1975 to 2022. Leveraging a high-frequency oil supply shock series and a rich panel of quarterly labor market data, we find that shocks raising oil prices trigger sharp and persistent employment losses, particularly in oil-importing countries, oil-intensive sectors, and among male workers. Delayed but enduring employment declines also emerge in oil-moderate sectors and among female workers, revealing broader labor market implications. In contrast, employment gains in oil-exporting countries, and following expansionary supply shocks, are comparatively modest. Labor force participation responds less consistently, with patterns displaying higher variability. These findings highlight how oil shocks transmit unevenly through labor markets, with lasting impacts across countries, sectors, and demographic groups, extending well beyond short-term macroeconomic fluctuations.

title: Trade Partners’ Responses to Us Tariffs
affiliations: International Monetary Fund (IMF) and International Monetary Fund (IMF)

detail.title: Trade Partners’ Responses to Us Tariffs

publicationDetails.journalName: International Monetary Fund (IMF) Research Paper Series

detail.abstract: Recently announced and enacted US tariffs reduce partners’ access to the US market and lead to trade diversion. Impacted countries may respond in (at least) three ways: imposing retaliatory tariffs on the US, resorting to industrial policy to support their producers, and/or signing trade agreements to find new market access opportunities. Relying on a quantitative trade model, we study the trade and welfare implications of these policy responses. Retaliation hurts US exports, can improve the terms of trade, but also creates distortions. Subsidies can expand exports, making up for lost markets in the US, but they are costly, increase distortions especially for the subsidizers, and worsen trade diversion effects that could eventually lead to new tariffs targeting subsidizers. Seeking deeper integration with other partners can help countries expand trade while reducing distortions. Even in presence of US tariffs, real income for the liberalizing countries and the world is higher when partners choose to deepen integration as part of their policy strategy.
